story:
The Mesoamerican Reef (MAR) Leadership Program selects young, capable fellows from the four countries of the MAR: Mexico, Belize, Guatemala and Honduras, and gives them all the training and resources they need to implement conservation projects. We already have 30 wonderful conservation projects being implemented, and the 2014 cohort is focused on the threat that solid waste means to the coral reef. With your help, we can win this battle!

The Mesoamerican Reef: A Delicate Caribbean Treasure

The Mesoamerican Reef (MAR) region lies within the Caribbean Sea and touches the coasts of Mexico, Belize, Guatemala and Honduras. It contains the largest barrier reef in the Western Hemisphere, stretching nearly 700 miles from the northern tip of the Yucatan Peninsula down through the Honduran Bay Islands. Dazzling arrays of different types of coral form this underwater wilderness, and provide home and food to hundreds of species of fish, marine turtles, and sharks. Along the shores, mangroves provide habitat for fish and shorebirds as well as protect coastal areas from the damage associated with hurricanes and strong storms.

This unique paradise, however, is in danger. Eight million pieces of marine debris enter the ocean every day and up to 10% of that waste is plastic (15% in USA). In the MAR region, dumping domestic waste in open areas is a common behavior; this waste ends up in the reef through river runoffs, dumps, poorly managed landfills, storm water discharge, wrecks and drain systems becoming a major problem that threatens the health and biodiversity of the reef.

Serious impacts of marine debris on the biodiversity to the Mesoamerican Reef include:

  •   Floating trash prevents sunlight from reaching coral and can migrate invasive species;
  •   Wildlife such as turtles and mammals mistake plastic for food, which remains in their digestive system and makes them starve;
  •   Lost or forgotten fishing nets cause fish, turtles, sea birds and marine mammals such as manatees and dolphins to die asphyxiated.

Scientists have also found that plastic in the ocean break down into tiny pieces, microplastics, that enter the food chain and the human body through fish and seafood. So the threat of plastics in the reef is not only an environmental problem, but it is also a threat to the health and livelihoods of adjacent communities, affecting fisheries, tourism and local economies.


What is the Mesoamerican Reef Leadership Program?

The MAR Leadership Program is a joint initiative of the Mexican Fund for the Conservation of Nature (FMCN) and the Summit Foundation, launched in 2010. Our long-term goal is to ensure that the MAR thrives as a healthy, productive ecosystem capable of supporting vibrant economies and providing abundant marine resources for generations to come. To fulfill this goal, we incubate marine conservation projects by strengthening the technical capabilities and leadership skills of young conservationists in Mexico (Quintana Roo), Belize, Guatemala and Honduras who are starting their professional careers, and who are the decision makers of an already near future. The program also creates a seed fund to accelerate the development and effectiveness of the conservation projects brought on by the MAR Fellows.


What do we do?

Every year we recruit a cohort of 12 fellows who design projects on a specific threat. This year, we focus our efforts on the sustainable management of waste, mainly plastic. Through our trainings and network we are helping Monica (Mexico) to develop an online training platform in Cozumel, Mexico, that will teach young students how to handle the waste they produce; and Tzahyrí (Mexico), who is teaching high school kids on how to reuse the materials washed to the island of Holbox and transform them into local arts and crafts; Emerson and Tanya (Belize) work to develop a integrated recycling project in Punta Gorda; Cindy and Laura (Honduras) are working to turn the island of Roatan into a plastic-free island, starting with a primary school kids and teachers and reaching all sectors of the community; Fernando (Mexico) is engaging the hotel industry and implementing solid waste management plans along the region; whereas Melissa (Guatemala) are addressing the problem from the governmental standpoint and are working in reforming solid waste legislation in their countries.


Together, we can make a difference and keep the Mesoamerican Reef clean and healthy!

By 2017, our goal is to reduce the amount of plastic that reach the reef by 30%. But Monica, Tzahyrí, Fernando and the rest of MAR Fellows cannot do it alone: we need your help. 


·  With $10 usd you can help us prevent a turtle from mistaking a plastic bag for food.

Almost 90% of floating marine debris is plastic. Due to its durability, buoyancy, and ability to accumulate and concentrate toxins present in the ocean, plastic is especially harmful to marine life. A plastic bag can take 400 to 1,000 years to decompose, but its chemical residues remain for years after. Americans use roughly 100 billion plastic bags per year.

Gift: MAR Leadership reusable shopping bag


·  With $20 usd you can help us prevent a seabird from getting entangled with a plastic six pack ring.

Entanglement can suffocate or constrict animals, prevent them from being able to eat or defend themselves against predators, swim freely, clean themselves, mate, or raise their young. 92.5% of dead seabirds had ingested plastic in amounts equal to 5% of their body weight.

Gift: Lorenzo Rosenzweig, Mexican Fund for the Conservation of Nature CEO, signed picture of a heron in Placencia, Belize.


·  With $50 usd you can help us prevent a shark from getting caught in a ghost fishing net.

Fishing gear—nets, lines or traps—left at sea often continue to “fish” (ghost-fishing), but the species trapped are never collected and the gear is never recovered. Some of these passive fishing devices can be responsible for the death of thousands of individual organisms,  like dolphins, sharks, turtles and even crabs.

Gift: Saving our sharks bull shark picture


·  With $100 usd you can help us keep a beach free of plastic bottles.

A study of stranded debris on beaches along the Caribbean coast of Panama reported an average density of 3.6 items/m2. Plastic and styrofoam were the most common sorts of debris and many items related to fast-food operations were found.

Gift MAR Leadership Reusable water bottle


·  With $200 usd you can help us remove styrofoam from our reef.

Polystyrene is made from petroleum, a non-sustainable, non-renewable, heavily polluting and fast-disappearing commodity. Therefore polystyrene is not biodegradable so it takes several decades to hundreds of years to deteriorate in the environment. Used polystyrene foam food packaging is generally not accepted in plastics recycling bins. Moreover, it contains toxic substances suspected carcinogens and neurotoxins that are hazardous for both wildlife and human health.

Gift: MAR Leadership reusable coffee mug


·  With $500 usd you can help us prevent coral reef damage.

Debris causes deleterious impacts to coral reefs, sea grass beds, and mangroves, by actively destroying them, by smothering the habitat, and/or by preventing access to it by other species.

Gift: Join us and visit MAR Leadership projects (discover the community ecotourism initiatives of Muyil lagoons with Vicente Ferreyra, help Gaby Nava with her reef nurseries in Puerto Morelos or visit the Xcalak Reef National Park)


*shipping costs are not included, we really appreciate your understanding*


MAR Leaders’ projects work for a healthy ocean,  you can make an impact too!

story: We start  with converting manure of pigs to algae. Annually billions of  kg are produced, which causes a lot of environmental problems because of the minerals in the manure. It also costs farmers a lot of money to get rid of the manure. One thing is that de manure causes problems in water, lakes etc because of too much growth of algae, killing fish life and effecting plantlife at the borders of the lakes and rivers. We use this growth to our advantage (if you cann't beat them, join them)..We grow algae on the manure, harvest the algae and sell the algae to bio-ethanol companies. So we reduce the mineral load of the environment AND help the farmers. We cooperate with a pigfarmer. We must establish the best species of algae to do the job and we need more equipment to do that, f.i. to measure oxygen and salts, to harvest the algae and to dry them. Help Nature, help the farmers, together we can make the world better! We are going to use the money in buying equipment, such as electrodes for measuring the growth of the algae, oxygen and salts, we need to develop a harvesting machine for the algae and to collect the most usefull strains of algae, buying them from university-institutes and collecting them from eutrophic lakes and ditches and we need to rebuild the manurecollecters of the farmer. We are not paying ourselves from this money, just making the circumstances right. This technique is of importance to economy as well as ecology, It is of importance to men as well as animals and plants

It also costs farmers a lot of money to get rid of the manure. One thing is that de manure causes problems in water, lakes etc because of too much growth of algae, killing fish life and effecting plantlife at the borders of the lakes and rivers. We use this growth to our advantage (if you cann't beat them, join them)..We grow algae on the manure, harvest the algae and sell the algae to bio-ethanol companies. So we reduce the mineral load of the environment AND help the farmers. We cooperate with a pigfarmer. We must establish the best species of algae to do the job and we need more equipment to do that, f.i. to measure oxygen and salts, to harvest the algae and to dry them. Help Nature, help the farmers, together we can make the world better! We are going to use the money in buying equipment, such as electrodes for measuring the growth of the algae, oxygen and salts, we need to develop a harvesting machine for the algae and to collect the most usefull strains of algae, buying them from university-institutes and collecting them from eutrophic lakes and ditches and we need to rebuild the manurecollecters of the farmer. We are not paying ourselves from this money, just making the circumstances right. This technique is of importance to economy as well as ecology, It is of importance to men as well as animals and plants

story:
Introduction // Why Should I Care?

My name is Christine Lenches-Hinkel, and I'm a mother of two and Environmental Planning Professional. After years of corporate frustration I felt unable to create the kind of massive change that we’re all aware this world needs, so I turned to entrepreneurship. Seven years ago I founded Waste Less Living, Inc. to combat our growing solid waste problem and the unsustainable pollution that our landfills create. Landfills are a major source of greenhouse gas emissions and toxic wastewater. Even with this glorious mission that we've spearheaded, the life of an “eco-preneur” is so much more challenging than I had anticipated. Lack of funds, personnel, and composting infrastructure have all stood in the way of progress… until now.  

So… how are we saving the world?? It all starts with soil. Nutrient-packed, organism-rich compost is the most effective substance (known to man) at improving soil, protecting and conserving our water, and reducing harmful greenhouse gases. Right now, our compost production is limited to how much food waste we can haul to the closest commercial composting facility – over 40 miles outside of the city! Do you see the problem?

The solution is to go local! We are raising these funds to purchase state-of-the-art composting technology that will allow us to process food scraps and disposable tableware made from plants (not plastic) that we currently collect from our customers. This is a landmark effort to bring commercial composting to urban centers and to introduce this new and innovative way for managing our organic waste.


Fundraising Goal // What's in it for me?

We are raising $25k to expand our composting services within the Pasadena, CA area. This traction will ensure we are properly recognized and considered by CalRecycle (http://www.calrecycle.ca.gov) for their upcoming grant supporting the development of composting facilities. To accomplish this, we will be using the funds to expand our marketing efforts, purchase equipment, and pay our team.   

We are still in the bootstrapping stage of our operations. Most would have given up, but we are convinced this problem is too grave to ignore.  We have come along way to increase awareness!  Beginning as a female solopreneur, the team is now 10 people strong, comprised of extremely talented people and industry professionals. They have been working incredibly hard without pay, and finally we've gained community and government support. The state of California has recognized the urgent need for more composting facilities.  They are making available $15M in grant funding to build out more infrastructure. We've proven ourselves in the community over the years, and have an all-star team that is dedicated to this project. We've educated our local government representatives and gained recognition from both local and state officials. 

Will you support our existing team of experts and professionals already working on the project to bring about this vision for a cleaner, more sustainable world? By signing up for residential composting service, or any of the other perks (for non-Pasadena, CA residents) it will keep alive the team we have now, and accelerate our efforts to raise the investment capital needed to continue our journey and  to fulfill our vision!


Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you aren't in a position to contribute money -- and that's OK. However, that doesn't mean you can't help! Here are some no-cost ways you can help us help the environment: 

  • Spread the word about this revolutionary composting campaign via your Social-Media (Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest, etc.) 
  • Email the link to your family, friends, and co-workers. 
  • Sign-up for our composting newsletter at:  www.WasteLessLiving.com
  • Follow us on social-media. 
  • Remember: it's easy to use the built-in Indiegogo sharing tools provided on this page.

story:
Coopérative d'habitation Cercle Carré


Qui nous sommes

Notre coop d’artistes et de travailleurs culturels, la Coopérative d'habitation Cercle Carré, située dans la Cité Multimédia à Montréal, aimerait transformer son toit en espace vert communautaire.

Nous en sommes à rechercher des fonds pour la Phase 1 de ce projet. Ceci implique de recouvrir plus des 3/4 du côté ouest du toit, soit environ 1800 pieds carrés, d’un système de toiture verte extensive constitué de plantes 100% indigènes du Québec. Les 700 pieds carrés restants seront des terrasses en bois faites de cèdre blanc du Québec, reliées par des sentiers de pierres des champs.

Au cours des années à venir, nous allons aussi chercher à verdir le côté est du toit. Tout en continuant à utiliser des plantes qui sont 100% indigènes au Québec, nous aimerions aussi créer un secteur centré sur l’agriculture urbaine et le jardinage.

En verdissant notre toit, nous ne ferons pas qu’augmenter la biodiversité et contrer l’effet des îlots de chaleur urbain (c’est-à-dire le réchauffement de l’environnement urbain dû à l’abus du béton); nous créerons aussi un espace pouvant être utilisé par les résidents de la coop et la communauté en général, offrant des ateliers sur les toits verts et des événements culturels. Nous espérons ainsi créer un précédent pour notre communauté et pour Montréal dans son ensemble!

Who We Are

Our artist coop, Coopérative d'habitation Cercle Carré, situated in Cité Multimedia in Montreal, would like to transform our roof into a green, community space.
We are seeking funds for Phase 1 of our project. This means covering over 3/4 of roof's west side, or approximately 1,800 square feet, with an extensive green roofing system made up of plants that are 100% indigenous to Quebec. The remaining 700 square feet will be wooden terraces built out of Quebec white cedar, connected by paths made of fieldstones.
In future years, we will seek to green the east side of the roof. Continuing to use plants that are 100% indigenous to Quebec, we would also like to create an area focused on urban agriculture and gardening.
By greening our roof, we will not only increase biodiversity and counter the urban heat island effect (which is the warming of the urban environment due to an excess of concrete), we will also create a space to be used by the coop's residents and the larger community through workshops and cultural events. We also hope to set a green precedent for our community and for all of Montreal!

Ce dont nous avons besoin

Nous avons déjà reçu une généreuse subvention du programme d’Environnement Canada « Éco Action », qui aidera à payer pour des plantes, du substrat, des frais d’architectes et les communications. Notre coopérative a également déjà grandement contribué au projet. Malheureusement, tout cela n’est pas encore assez pour lancer le projet!

C’est ici que vous intervenez. Pour compléter  la phase 1 de notre projet, nous avons encore besoin d’un minimum de $10 000 — dans le meilleur des cas, mais il se peut que nous ayons besoin de plus si les prix sont plus élevés que prévu et pour parer aux imprévus.

Voici ce que procure un don: Des plantes indigènes, les membranes de toiture verte, les terrasses en bois faites de cèdre blanc du Québec, le garde-corps, une partie du travail des contracteurs et bien sûr, la satisfaction de contribuer à un projet qui aide à verdir notre ville et à créer un espace rassembleur pour la communauté.

Si nous n’atteignons pas notre objectif, au lieu de verdir 1800 pieds carrés, nous ne pourrons en verdir que 750, ce qui réduirait considérablement l’impact environnemental de notre projet.

    What We Need

We have already received a generous grant from Environment Canada's “Eco Action” program that will help pay for plants, substrate, architect fees, and communications. Our cooperative has also greatly contributed to the project. Unfortunately, all of this is not quite enough to get the project off the ground!
This is where you come in. To complete phase 1 of our project, we still need a minimum of $10,000—this is a best-case scenario, but we may need more if prices are higher than expected, or for contingency funds.
By donating you will be contributing to: Indigenous plants, the green roofing membranes, wooden terraces made out of Quebec white cedar, the railing, and some of the contracting work, and of course, the knowledge that you are contributing to a project that is helping to green our city and create a space that can bring together our community.
If we don't reach our goal, this means that instead of greening 1,800 square feet, we will only be able to green about 750 square feet, which seriously lessens the environmental impact of our project.

Nos cadeaux

Puisque notre coopérative rassemble des artistes et des travailleurs culturels, nous avons de nombreux merveilleux cadeaux à offrir!


Voici certain des cadeaux que nous offrons pour vous remercier de vos généreuses contributions:

  • Des billets pour des spectacles de danse, des concerts et des pièces de théâtre; des livres, des films et des CDs; des bijoux uniques; du sirop d’érable du Québec et des thés gourmets; des cours de peinture ou de céramique.
  • Des œuvres d’art originales, grandes ou petites, à une fraction du prix! De même que plusieurs reproductions d’art.
  • Un spectacle solo de René Lussier, figure dominante de la musique innovatrice québécoise présenté le 23 mai à l’Espace Cercle Carré.
  • Locations gratuites de notre salle multifonctionnelle Espace Cercle Carré
  • Locations gratuites du toit vert pour dîner ou 5 à 7 privés.

    Our Perks

Since our cooperative is made up of artists and cultural workers, we have many amazing perks to offer! These are some of the gifts we're offering:
  • Tickets to dance shows, concerts and theatre; books, films and CDs; one-of-a-kind jewelry; Quebec maple syrup and gourmet teas; courses in painting or ceramics 
  • Original paintings both large and small – at a fraction of the price! As well as various art reproductions.
  • A solo show by René Lussier, a pillar of innovative music in Quebec, presented on Friday May 23rd at the cooperative's Espace Cercle Carré.
  • Exclusive private rentals of both the rooftop garden once it's complete and a private rental of our multidisciplinary artist space Espace Cercle Carré on the ground floor of our cooperative.

D'autres façons de contribuer

Nous vous invitons à partager le lien de cette campagne dans votre réseau via votre page Facebook ou votre compte Twitter: igg.me/at/cerclecarre

Merci de soutenir ce projet et de contribuer à l'essor du verdissement de Montréal!

http://cerclecarre.coop/site/cooperative

    Other Ways You Can Help

Please help spread the word about our campaign through your Facebook page  and Twitter account: igg.me/at/cerclecarre
Thanks for helping our project become a reality and for taking part in greening our city!
http://cerclecarre.coop/site/cooperative
story_txt:
Coopérative d'habitation Cercle Carré

Qui nous sommes
Notre coop d’artistes et de travailleurs culturels, la Coopérative d'habitation Cercle Carré, située dans la Cité Multimédia à Montréal, aimerait transformer son toit en espace vert communautaire.Nous en sommes à rechercher des fonds pour la Phase 1 de ce projet. Ceci implique de recouvrir plus des 3/4 du côté ouest du toit, soit environ 1800 pieds carrés, d’un système de toiture verte extensive constitué de plantes 100% indigènes du Québec. Les 700 pieds carrés restants seront des terrasses en bois faites de cèdre blanc du Québec, reliées par des sentiers de pierres des champs.Au cours des années à venir, nous allons aussi chercher à verdir le côté est du toit. Tout en continuant à utiliser des plantes qui sont 100% indigènes au Québec, nous aimerions aussi créer un secteur centré sur l’agriculture urbaine et le jardinage.En verdissant notre toit, nous ne ferons pas qu’augmenter la biodiversité et contrer l’effet des îlots de chaleur urbain (c’est-à-dire le réchauffement de l’environnement urbain dû à l’abus du béton); nous créerons aussi un espace pouvant être utilisé par les résidents de la coop et la communauté en général, offrant des ateliers sur les toits verts et des événements culturels. Nous espérons ainsi créer un précédent pour notre communauté et pour Montréal dans son ensemble!Who We AreOur artist coop, Coopérative d'habitation Cercle Carré, situated in Cité Multimedia in Montreal, would like to transform our roof into a green, community space.We are seeking funds for Phase 1 of our project. This means covering over 3/4 of roof's west side, or approximately 1,800 square feet, with an extensive green roofing system made up of plants that are 100% indigenous to Quebec. The remaining 700 square feet will be wooden terraces built out of Quebec white cedar, connected by paths made of fieldstones.In future years, we will seek to green the east side of the roof. Continuing to use plants that are 100% indigenous to Quebec, we would also like to create an area focused on urban agriculture and gardening.By greening our roof, we will not only increase biodiversity and counter the urban heat island effect (which is the warming of the urban environment due to an excess of concrete), we will also create a space to be used by the coop's residents and the larger community through workshops and cultural events. We also hope to set a green precedent for our community and for all of Montreal!Ce dont nous avons besoinNous avons déjà reçu une généreuse subvention du programme d’Environnement Canada « Éco Action », qui aidera à payer pour des plantes, du substrat, des frais d’architectes et les communications. Notre coopérative a également déjà grandement contribué au projet. Malheureusement, tout cela n’est pas encore assez pour lancer le projet!C’est ici que vous intervenez. Pour compléter  la phase 1 de notre projet, nous avons encore besoin d’un minimum de $10 000 — dans le meilleur des cas, mais il se peut que nous ayons besoin de plus si les prix sont plus élevés que prévu et pour parer aux imprévus.Voici ce que procure un don: Des plantes indigènes, les membranes de toiture verte, les terrasses en bois faites de cèdre blanc du Québec, le garde-corps, une partie du travail des contracteurs et bien sûr, la satisfaction de contribuer à un projet qui aide à verdir notre ville et à créer un espace rassembleur pour la communauté.Si nous n’atteignons pas notre objectif, au lieu de verdir 1800 pieds carrés, nous ne pourrons en verdir que 750, ce qui réduirait considérablement l’impact environnemental de notre projet.    What We NeedWe have already received a generous grant from Environment Canada's “Eco Action” program that will help pay for plants, substrate, architect fees, and communications. Our cooperative has also greatly contributed to the project. Unfortunately, all of this is not quite enough to get the project off the ground!This is where you come in. To complete phase 1 of our project, we still need a minimum of $10,000—this is a best-case scenario, but we may need more if prices are higher than expected, or for contingency funds.
By donating you will be contributing to: Indigenous plants, the green roofing membranes, wooden terraces made out of Quebec white cedar, the railing, and some of the contracting work, and of course, the knowledge that you are contributing to a project that is helping to green our city and create a space that can bring together our community.
If we don't reach our goal, this means that instead of greening 1,800 square feet, we will only be able to green about 750 square feet, which seriously lessens the environmental impact of our project.Nos cadeauxPuisque notre coopérative rassemble des artistes et des travailleurs culturels, nous avons de nombreux merveilleux cadeaux à offrir!Voici certain des cadeaux que nous offrons pour vous remercier de vos généreuses contributions:
Des billets pour des spectacles de danse, des concerts et des pièces de théâtre; des livres, des films et des CDs; des bijoux uniques; du sirop d’érable du Québec et des thés gourmets; des cours de peinture ou de céramique.
Des œuvres d’art originales, grandes ou petites, à une fraction du prix! De même que plusieurs reproductions d’art.

Un spectacle solo de René Lussier, figure dominante de la musique innovatrice québécoise présenté le 23 mai à l’Espace Cercle Carré.


Locations gratuites de notre salle multifonctionnelle Espace Cercle Carré

Locations gratuites du toit vert pour dîner ou 5 à 7 privés.
    Our Perks
Since our cooperative is made up of artists and cultural workers, we have many amazing perks to offer! These are some of the gifts we're offering:

Tickets to dance shows, concerts and theatre; books, films and CDs; one-of-a-kind jewelry; Quebec maple syrup and gourmet teas; courses in painting or ceramics 
Original paintings both large and small – at a fraction of the price! As well as various art reproductions.
A solo show by René Lussier, a pillar of innovative music in Quebec, presented on Friday May 23rd at the cooperative's Espace Cercle Carré.
Exclusive private rentals of both the rooftop garden once it's complete and a private rental of our multidisciplinary artist space Espace Cercle Carré on the ground floor of our cooperative.
D'autres façons de contribuerNous vous invitons à partager le lien de cette campagne dans votre réseau via votre page Facebook ou votre compte Twitter: igg.me/at/cerclecarreMerci de soutenir ce projet et de contribuer à l'essor du verdissement de Montréal!http://cerclecarre.coop/site/cooperative    Other Ways You Can HelpPlease help spread the word about our campaign through your Facebook page  and Twitter account: igg.me/at/cerclecarreThanks for helping our project become a reality and for taking part in greening our city!http://cerclecarre.coop/site/cooperative

story:
Bref résumé

Avoir des jardins disponibles en ville, c'est possible même sans balcon... enfin c'est ce que nous croyons et qui nous pousse à lancer un nouveau projet d'agriculture urbaine tout en investissant le marché Jean-Talon ! Nous avons présentement installé deux bacs et planté des semis dont les résultats seront accessibles à tous ceux qui seront dans les parages lorsqu'ils seront mûrs.  Bienvenue au Jardin du Marché.

Lieu (presque ) parfait
L'implication citoyenne est à l'oeuvre ici afin de pouvoir créer un espace vert au sein d'un lieu vacant qui semble parfait pour promouvoir l'agriculture urbaine. Les nombreux passants ainsi que les commerçants et habitants du coin peuvent désormais profiter d'une revitalisation verdoyante. L'eau est disponible à proximité et le soleil bat son plein sur les jeunes pousses ! Le marché est une plate forme idéale à la promotion de l'agriculture urbaine.

Des légumes gratuits au marché ?

Le but de cet espace n'est pas de faire compétition aux commerçants du marché: les quelques piments ne parviendrons pas à nourrir les nombreux clients. Il offre cependant la possibilité de croire en des lieux conviviaux, utiles, beaux qui peuvent offrir une nourriture fraîche et exempt de pesticides aux citoyens des alentours.

*** Les bacs permettent d'éviter la contamination du sol vers les légumes.
 
Les avantages promus par la MAPAQ :
  • Réduction des ilôts de chaleur
  • Nourriture de proximité
  • Socialisation
  • Éducation
  • Absorption des eaux pluviales
  • Esthétique

Ce dont nous avons besoin

Nous avons donc besoin du maximum d'argent possible pour acheter de la terre et du matériel pour construire les bacs. La terre est principalement assez chère à procurer.Nous escomptons récolter 200$ avec cette campagne (chaque dollar sera convertie en matière organique, promis ! ).

Donner au projet vous permettra de vous impliquer sans trop investir de temps. Dites-vous que seulement 5$ nous permet d'acheter assez de terre pour remplir environ un dixième de bac. Avec seulement 10 dons, un autre jardin serait déjà disponible !

Ce que vous obtenez

  • Un accès moral privilégié aux légumes disponibles lorsque vous viendrez au marché ( vous l'aurez mérité votre poivron ! )
  • La satisfaction de rendre la ville plus verdoyante, accueillante et adaptée au mode de vie citadin du 21e siècle.
  • L'espoir que ce type de projet se développe à grande envergure ( les discussions vont bon train entre les groupes citoyens, environnementaux et la ville !)

Risques et défis

Notre "équipe" technique est présentement constituée d'un agriculteur de légumes biologiques et d'une finissante en études environnementales. Les voisins du Jardin du Marché participent en allant arroser, désherber et dispenser de l'amour. La proximité est de mise pour ce genre de projet, mais également l'entraide et l'assiduité. Pour l'instant, les volontaires semblent assez nombreux pour se relayer dans les besoins quotidiens des plantes, mais la constance est de mise !

D'autres façons d'aider

Si vous habitez près et que vous pouvez être disponible pour l'arrosage, contactez-nous afin que nous puissions partager les horaires !

story:
I'm going to Swaziland for three weeks in July on a school trip with Sense Africa. We're raising money to build a soup kitchen for AIDS orphans and vulnerable children in Mgdiza community.

 It's a very rural area with about 60 homesteads. Many of the children who live there do not go to school as they can't afford to, or they need to stay at home to help out. 

Every day an old woman feeds 80 AIDS orphans on an open fire in her back yard. The community has found a place for us to build a proper kitchen, and then they'll build classrooms and a play area. We'll be camping near Tambankula Church, in the sugar estates, and travelling 20 minutes each day to the project site. After we've built it, we'll go back to paint it and have a big opening ceremony. 

We'll also be helping out on conservation projects in the Mbuluzi game reserve, maybe counting game or feeding vultures.

story:
News! We now have a website created by our editor Elizabeth Batt, International Dolphin and Whale Stranding Network, where you will find more information and can track our progress.

Also, we have welcomed systems architect Terran Baylor to the team, to orchestrate IT/Development.

The Goal

We are looking to create a worldwide network for sightings of beached and stranded whales and dolphins. Developing the app for it however, is the most expensive part of the project. We are therefore appealing to all IT experts to step forward and volunteer their design services. If we can achieve donated help with this aspect of our project then our costs will drop significantly. Funds can then be used instead, towards a public awareness campaign.

This will be helpful for strandings that might otherwise go unreported (such as in countries where there is no stranding network in place), and also it will save researchers valuable time by having the data available in one place.

We need to help

To find solutions for whale and dolphin strandings, scientists need more data. One way to achieve this is the creation of an app that can catalog photos of stranded whales and dolphins, worldwide. 

Funds raised for this project will be initially used for the creation of an app that will allow people to post photos of stranded whales and dolphins from anywhere in the world.  Using GPS information from smartphones and other devices, we would be able to record the date and location of the stranded marine mammal. This database will then be made available and accessible to everyone.

Sound is one of the biggest problems for marine animals, and now sonar has conclusively been demonstrated to cause whales and dolphins to strand. 


The Problem

There are a variety of reasons why whales strand themselves, so the goal of this database is to learn as much as possible about human-caused strandings. Typically, these include loud noises produced by industrial practices, military exercises or research conducted in the cetaceans' habitat. 

Whales and dolphins process sound as visual images -- so any loud bursts of sound caused by seismic oil exploration for example, is a multi-sensory overload for them. On just one ship, there can be 90 or more 200-300 decibel air guns firing simultaneously every 20 to 30 seconds, for months on end. 

The effects of this sound can be profound on cetaceans and lead to blast type injuries or drastic alteration in dive behavior. Bleeding in the brain, ear canal, and melon (the forehead), is characteristic of whales and dolphins who beach themselves following exposure to loud sounds. 

The continuous onslaught of sound can also make it difficult for family members to find other pod members in the din. This furthers the chance that pods will intermingle in assemblages not characteristic for them, or find themselves without a pod leader. There is even a chance that in attempting to escape the worst of the sound, dolphins and whales may flee to unfamiliar areas and find themselves lost.


Ocean noise pollution is of special concern for cetaceans, as they are highly dependent on sound as their principal sense. Sound travels very efficiently underwater, so the potential area impacted can be thousands of square kilometres or more. 
The principal anthropogenic noise sources are underwater explosions (nuclear and otherwise), shipping, seismic exploration by mainly the oil and gas industries, and naval sonar operations.
 Strandings and mortalities of especially beaked whales (family Ziphiidae) have in many cases been conclusively linked to noise events such as naval maneuvers involving tactical sonars or seismic surveys, though other cetacean species may also be involved. (The impacts of anthropogenic ocean noise on cetaceans and implications for management)

These bracelets are among the perks you can choose for contributing to this campaign. (Please see sidebar).

Who We Are

We are an informal group of scientists, advocates, and concerned individuals offering support, advice and guidance on the current threats faced by cetaceans. 

Researcher: Candace Calloway Whiting possesses degrees in both marine mammal behavior and oceanography and writes frequently on cetaceans and their environments. 

Editor: Elizabeth Batt is an environmental journalist with a passion for ocean preservation. 

Social Media: Alex Dorer is the president of Fins and Fluke with a deep love for all things ocean-related.

Research: Kerry O'Brien is a volunteer marine mammal medic in New Zealand. Kerry has attended and assisted in marine mammal strandings. 

IT/Development: Terran Vincent Baylor is a Systems Architect by trade who knows how computer systems works, how to get them connected, and how to best design them. 

Once this project is completed, it will be turned over to an international, non-governmental group to manage.

Who They Are

Dolphins and whales are intelligent, benign, and sometimes irrepressible! We have learned that many species spend their lives together in family groups, and there are even documented cases of different species helping each other, as when these humpback whales tried to save a gray whale calf, or in this touching instance of sperm whales adopting a deformed dolphin:


To learn more about these incredible marine mammals visit the American Museum of Natural History website. If you are in the New York area, you might want to drop by and see the museum's interactive exhibit, "Whales, Giants of the Deep", where you can climb inside a model of the blue whale's heart!


Ways You Can Help

Share your ideas, energy, time, talent, resources - together we can establish a worldwide stranding network, and help researchers find solutions to this issue.

story:
Greenpop is on a mission to (re)connect people with our planet. We believe in inspiring a Treevolution. Join us!

Why Trees, why Zambia?

Zambia has one of the highest deforestation rates in the world and this affects us all directly or indirectly. Trees are one of the largest sources of breathable oxygen on earth - if they are under threat, then we are under threat! We believe in getting active about making a change and gathering together as citizens of our shared planet to ensure a thriving future. We plant trees, learn lots, share sustainable solutions and have fun doing it - it's a treevolution!

Greenpop Trees for Zambia is a reforestation and eco-education project based in Livingstone, Zambia. The project aims to fight the drastic deforestation the area is facing by planting trees, spreading environmental awareness, changing mindsets, and encouraging alternative energy resources. 

Launched in 2012, Trees for Zambia is an ongoing campaign with an annual Festival of Action; a large 3-week event that gets hundreds of local and international volunteers active to spread green awareness. During this year's Festival of Action, which will run from June 15 - July 6, we'll do the following:

  • Plant at least 4000 trees at schools, subsistence farms and in deforested areas
  • Host educational workshops for school children and subsistence farmers 
  • Teach community members how to build solar cookers, in an effort to move people away from dependence on charcoal as well as research other sustainable cooking & heating methods
  • Inspire both the Livingstone communities and participants from around the world to live sustainably

Sustainability of the Project 

We do the following to ensure Trees for Zambia is successful, sustainable and thriving: 

  • We believe in education that is memorable, interactive and fun. Through our workshops to school children and subsistence farmers, we spread awareness on the benefit of trees. We are working with education experts to develop the most relevant educational material. 
  • We buy our trees from local small-scale tree growers as much as we can to encourage local enterprise. 
  • We map and monitor all the trees we plant. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need trees! $15 covers for a tree, and all the logistics that are involved in planting that tree. This includes the following costs: 

  • buying the trees and necessary compost from local nurseries in Livingstone 
  • transporting the trees to the planting locations
  • facilitation of the planting workshop with the local community and volunteers
  • environmental education that is an essential part of our project
  • a monitoring program for the trees, so that we can make sure they grow tall and strong! 

We also need educational material, logistics for workshops and resources for monitoring our trees. 

Please note that even if the goal is not reached, all funds will still be implemented. Trees for Zambia is ongoing - we would like to plant as many trees, connect as many people and spread as much awareness as possible! Other sources of income are corporate sponsorship (please contact us if you're interested in this!) and private donations. 

It doesn't matter how much you contribute - every tree counts! Check out our perks for cool things we offer you in return. The most exciting perk is a limited edition copy of Uncle Ben's incredible art work. (Uncle Ben is a highly talented local Zambian artist, as well as our Director of Trees!) Check out Uncle Ben at work: 

Other Ways You Can Help

Join our Treevolution by helping us spread the message! Please share this campaign with anyone you think might be interested in helping us green Zambia! 

You can also come and volunteer with us in Zambia! We fully rely on volunteers to make the project a success, so roll up your sleeves and get your hands dirty! For more information on our volunteer project, send an email to zambia@greenpop.org. 

Thanks for your TREEmendous support!!

Host educational workshops for school children and subsistence farmers 


Teach community members how to build solar cookers, in an effort to move people away from dependence on charcoal as well as research other sustainable cooking & heating methods

Inspire both the Livingstone communities and participants from around the world to live sustainably
Sustainability of the Project We do the following to ensure Trees for Zambia is successful, sustainable and thriving: 
We believe in education that is memorable, interactive and fun. Through our workshops to school children and subsistence farmers, we spread awareness on the benefit of trees. We are working with education experts to develop the most relevant educational material. 
We buy our trees from local small-scale tree growers as much as we can to encourage local enterprise. 
We map and monitor all the trees we plant. 
What We Need & What You GetWe need trees! $15 covers for a tree, and all the logistics that are involved in planting that tree. This includes the following costs: 
buying the trees and necessary compost from local nurseries in Livingstone 
transporting the trees to the planting locations
facilitation of the planting workshop with the local community and volunteers
environmental education that is an essential part of our project
a monitoring program for the trees, so that we can make sure they grow tall and strong! 
We also need educational material, logistics for workshops and resources for monitoring our trees. Please note that even if the goal is not reached, all funds will still be implemented. Trees for Zambia is ongoing - we would like to plant as many trees, connect as many people and spread as much awareness as possible! Other sources of income are corporate sponsorship (please contact us if you're interested in this!) and private donations. It doesn't matter how much you contribute - every tree counts! Check out our perks for cool things we offer you in return. The most exciting perk is a limited edition copy of Uncle Ben's incredible art work. (Uncle Ben is a highly talented local Zambian artist, as well as our Director of Trees!) Check out Uncle Ben at work: Other Ways You Can HelpJoin our Treevolution by helping us spread the message! Please share this campaign with anyone you think might be interested in helping us green Zambia! You can also come and volunteer with us in Zambia! We fully rely on volunteers to make the project a success, so roll up your sleeves and get your hands dirty! For more information on our volunteer project, send an email to zambia@greenpop.org. Thanks for your TREEmendous support!!

story:
This pilgrimage has two purposes; to find the roots of Filipino adoptees Sammy Taggett and Brandi Shigley and to bring clean water to the Philippines and save the lives of thousands of men, women and children without clean water.  Tacloban City, Leyte and surrounding areas will continue to see the spread of waterborne diseases that lead to cholera, typhoid fever and the parasites that cause amoebic dysentery. People will not only continue to get sick, they will continue to die. Even 15 months after Typhoon Haiyan hit the Philippines, Tacloban City continues to see a staggering number of sickness, disease, and death amongst the Filipino people. This is not our first project. Part of this team did a similar project last year in Haiti that changed their lives forever and helped inspire this second project.

** PLEASE, IF POSSIBLE, MAKE YOUR DONATION THROUGH PAYPAL
AS WE CAN ACCESS THOSE FUNDS RIGHT AWAY FOR OUR IMMEDIATE NECESSITIES. IF YOU USE THE MERCHANT PROCESSING
CREDIT CARD ROUTE, WE DO NOT HAVE ACCESS TO THOSE FUNDS
UNTIL JUST DAYS BEFORE WE LEAVE. THANK YOU IN ADVANCE!! *****

We are a small group... just regular people with no agenda beyond truly wanting to help those in need. With your help we can make this beautiful project happen.

Meet the team!

From left to right, Derek Reinhardt, Brandi Shigley, Jason Coates, Sammy Taggett, and Norm Villapando
Jason Coates:

Jason is a world traveler who has traveled to 23 countries in the past 3 years and documented his travels on the social networking sitewww.joinusaroundtheworld.com/. The site and Jason's mission is to connect travelers and build new friendships Around the World. Aside from his travels and love for videography and photography, Jason is passionate about world issues and helping those in need.

In his home town of Denver, Colorado he has organized many clothing and shoe drives for the homeless and after seeing many of the distressed and poverty stricken places of the world, Jason feels there is no better time than now to take those community efforts all over the globe.

When asked, "Why is this project important to you?" Jason responded with, "This project is important to me because I love people, and when I see someone in need I feel like I should do something. When there are innocent children dying and there is something that can be done to stop it, I can't sit back and not try and be apart of that change. I am passionate about this project because I love to film the world and I feel this is apart of the world that needs to be brought to light as much as any place on the globe."

Derek Reinhardt: 

Derek is an extremely dedicated worker who has shined in many fields including; construction, aviation mechanics, creative arts and entertainment and helping build startups from the ground floor. He is also a professional photographer who found what he loved by capturing life and emotion. He truly feels at home behind the lens and capturing the world he sees in front of him.

When asked, "Why is this project important to you?" Derek responded with, “this project is important to me because I have always had a passion for helping people as well as a passion for photography and on a project like this I will be able to bring those two worlds together.”

Sammy Taggett: BornJosilito Ramirez

Samuel John Taggett, was born Josilito Ramirez. and is most affectionately known to his friends, family and fans as SammyT.

A professional touring DJ, Guitarist, and Singer by trade, Sammy is also a serial entrepreneur and heads the production company White Dragon and is a producer for both Mile High House and Collective Culture two of Denver’s Premiere production companies. This is where you will usually find him behind the scenes following one of his other passions cinema.

He is often doted as one of the hardest working entertainers in Denver and this tenacity has helped him accomplish some of the biggest feats in both film and music. Sammy has graced the main stage at Red Rocks on multiple occasions, and you can often find him on tour as the resident Dj for pioneering companies such as Mind Valley, and Maverick1000, where he has been the resident party instigator for their infamous retreats.

Sammy’s early childhood is one of immense tragedy and extreme blessings. Adopted in the late 70’s out of the Philippines, he was fortunate to make it out of an orphanage where the mortality rate was recorded as high as 70%. As many as 7 out of 10 infants would not survive and the fact that in many cases there were multiple cribs per room, helps one to conclude that it was nothing short of God’s grace that Sammy was allowed to be adopted out of such a dismal start. He is a survivor.

Sammy was adopted by Tom and Marti Taggett who grew up in Wisconsin and relocated to Colorful Colorado. Sammy was also the first of 3 adopted children.  Younger brother, Timothy Cheng Khu Taggett, and Katherine O’brien Taggett, would be the next to land in the Taggett household. The beautiful family of 5 would become known as the “TagTen”, home of tennis lessons and racquet restringing. A sport that Mom and Dad had a passion for and passed onto their new family and one that still stays with them today.

As fate would have it both Marti and Tom were both very gifted educators. Marti taught special education 37 years before finally retiring and Tom was not only Sam’s English teacher, he was also the coach for almost all of his after school pursuits. Including, the hobby that would one day become Sammy’s hallmark, playing guitar, and performing as a musician.

Many people find that such an amazing story and upbringing could make it seem like it’s only natural that Sammy would jump at the opportunity to give back, and Sammy would totally agree with you.

“The journey back to my homeland is really one of self discovery, and finding a way to give back to my parents and to the friends and family that have helped me become who I am.

I am often asked if I am looking for my biological parents, and I think it would be amazing to connect with them, however, it’s not the sole intention. I want to help find more purpose from this journey, to connect the dots to why I am so lucky, and how can I serve better. I LOVE that we are able to bring water filters to those that need it as well, as this serves as a tangible piece that we can also leave behind to help those that need it most when we’re gone. “

Brandi Shigley

Brandi’s mission is to turn dreamers into doers. Starting her first company 15 years ago with her handbag business B.Shigley designs, Shigley has learned the ups and downs of being an independent designer and now focuses much of her time on Fashion Denver, a business she started 10 years ago to help designers build their businesses. Through the production of fashion markets, fashion shows, and business development, Shigley is helping to put Denver on the map for fashion. It’s not just fashion that she’s passionate about, but artists, musicians, and creative people with a desire to take their passion to the next level. She has been featured on CNN Money, International Design Magazine, and has also been a featured speaker with TEDx. To learn more, visit www.dowhatyoulove.us

Brandi’s Adoption Story

Brandi Shigley was born “Baby Girl Gonzales” and was abandoned at the hospital. For the first 16 months of her life, she was placed in a couple of different orphanages and then into 2 foster families. After getting sick as a toddler, she was brought to the hospital and it was there that she caught the attention of the Lutheran Family Services adoption organization and subsequently adopted by Maynard and Vicki Shigley. The Shigley family had adopted a baby boy from Vietnam and knew it was time to bring in a sister.

Although Brandi was abandoned as a baby, one things she knows for certain is that she was loved. Pictures of her in the orphanage show her being surrounded by happy smiling people. When she was brought over to Denver, Colorado, the love continued.

“Being adopted was one of the best things that could have happened to me. I grew up in a family that showed me no limits! They supported, and continue to support, every ounce of creativity in me and giving me the freedom to explore all creative sides of me. This in turn has given me courage and the passion to support and encourage other people to let their lights shine.”

When Brandi was 23, she wanted to find out what time she was born. She went down to her files (which she had always had access to, but never cared to look) and discovered letters upon letters that her foster mother had written to the Shigleys, describing her personality, what her first word was (“light”) and the many details of her character. She finally found her birth certificate, discovering that her biological mother was 23 when she had her and that she was born at 2:23. She learned of her parents names (Manuel Gonzales and Erlinda Ignacio) and learned that she had a sibling and that her parents were catholic and her dad was a soldier, orginally born in Zamboanga. It was that night that she realized, “It doesn’t matter what chromosomes make me me, it’s up to me to be me.”

The year she turned 23 she started her first business, graduated from college with honors in communication and became a citizen, truly planting her own roots. The number 23 and 2:23 show up in Brandi’s life on a regular basis always reminding her that she is on the right path.

“To be on this mission to take water filters down to the Philippines is a dream come true. I’ve always wanted to explore my roots and see where I’m from, but I’ve also been afraid. It’s time to stop being afraid. To go down there with my friend Sammy (also an adopted Filipino) and such a wonderful crew to do something that will directly and positively do good in communities affected by the typhoon, makes my heart explode with love. I know that it will be emotional for me. But I’m ready.”

Norm Villapando

Originally from Honolulu Hawaii, Norm moved to Colorado to attend CU in Boulder and obtained both a BA and MBA while at CU. Norm has worked in the IT Industry for over 15 years as a Sales and Marketing Exec.  He currently works at Hewlett Packard and has over 10 years of tenure.  Although Norm has spent the majority of his career with large corporations, he has always had an entrepreneurial spirit and has recently developed a need to help striving entrepreneurs with developing sales and marketing strategies, using his education and over 15 years of sales and marketing experience.

With regard to this amazing project, Clean Water Philippines, Norm was first drawn to this effort a year ago when he attended a fundraiser co-hosted by Sammy T.  He thought it was simply amazing that a group of individuals in Denver, CO would be compelled enough to help the Filipino people from the devastation of Typhoon Haiyan... and actually make a difference by raising money to send water filters to the Philippines. When Norm learned Sammy T., with a group of others (including Jason C., Derek R., and Brandi S.) where raising additional funds to purchase and deliver water filters to the Philippines and to the Filipino people still in need of help from the Typhoon, Norm felt compelled to get involved.  

Norm is 2nd generation Filipino American and has very strong ties to the Philippines.  He has many family members that live in the Philippines and also once lived there himself when he was a child.  

When asked why this project is important to him, Norm replied “I wanted to follow in the footsteps of my mother who spent a large portion of her life helping the Filipino people in many different ways.  She always told me we were very blessed to have been able to live in the US and earn the opportunities to better ourselves through education and hard work.  She told me over 75% of the Filipino people live in poverty and won’t ever have the same opportunities I was given growing up in the US.  We can never forget where we came from and we should always do what we can to give back.  I believe this is my time, my opportunity to give back and to help my fellow Filipinos.”


#CleanWaterAroundtheWorld

story:
Joe Hollis and Mountain Gardens


In 1972 I obtained several acres of woodland in the mountains of western North Carolina  My intention was (and is) to spend my life making a garden which I describe (idealistically) as “Paradise” and realistically as a “botanical garden of useful plants.”  My goal is to meet as many as possible of my ‘needs’ – physical and otherwise – directly from the land.

Forty plus years later, Mountain Gardens is a beautiful, landscape garden composed of hundreds of useful plants (food, medicine, crafts, wildlife, etc.)  We are pioneers in, among other things, growing Chinese herbs in America, naturalizing wildfood plants both native and oriental and introducing and cultivating adaptogenic/longevity herbs.  The garden has generated a seed business and useful plants nursery as well as a well equipped apothecary/herb shop in which we produce a range of herb preparations from garden herbs.  


I currently teach workshops, give tours, host college groups and teach at Daoist Traditions College in Asheville, NC.  When I am not gardening, (in winter), I continue studying about gardening from every possible perspective. Over the years, I have accumulated a great deal of information, practical and theoretical, which I would like to share for others to build on.

Jennifer Noll joined Mountain Gardens as an apprentice in 2013, offering her trade as a videographer in exchange for learning more about gardening and plant medicine. Since then, she has returned several times, for short periods, filming 5-10 videos at a time; currently there are 30. You can view these on our youtube channel:

https://www.youtube.com/user/mountaingardens/videos

Ideally, she will film for an entire growing season, documenting plants at different stages while showing viewers the wide range of projects that go on at Mountain Gardens over the span of a year.


Plant Videos and Weekly Videos

This year, we would like to produce 5-10 minute videos on over 120 plants, some of which will show the plants at different stages of growth, as well as propagation, harvest and preparation. In addition to this, we would like to produce weekly videos from now to mid November. These videos will be both practical and philosophical, reflecting the diversity of inspirations throughout the evolution of Mountain Gardens.

Below is a current list of the plants we plan on filming, and below that is the list of potential topics for the weekly videos. 

Spring has sprung, and the growing season is well on it's way. We have already been working on this project, anticipating that we will have the opportunity to see it to its completion. 


Why Money Would Help

In the past, money has been the limiting factor, but with living expenses paid for, we will be able to focus entirely on this project.

Maintaining and developing is a full time job to run Mountain Gardens for Joe and the apprentices. Because there is a lot of time involved in organizing, filming and editing the videos, much of the filming and editing will need to be done in the early mornings, late afternoons and on weekends. This scarcely leaves time for earning money on or off the property, which is a current necessity, for Jennifer in particular. 

A secondary expense is for a laptop. Currently Jennifer is editing using a 27 inch desktop computer--an impractical computer to be using here at Mountain Gardens, which is run on solar. It's important to note that right now, each 5-10 minute video requires approximately 3 hours of compressing and uploading. The portability of a laptop would also allow Jennifer to edit and upload more quickly and efficiently in other locations. 

The other expense is for a macro lens. This would greatly enhance the educational and artistic aspects of this project. The current 50mm lens we are using limits how closely we can show the plant and all its parts. Incorporating extreme closeups would create an all around more engaging video for the viewer.

Here is a breakdown of where the money will go:

$2,700 will go to Jennifer for bills and living expenses into the winter months.

$1,800 will be used for equipment.

$900 will go to Mountain Gardens, to supplement for the perks we are offering, and to help Joe pay for other expenses that may come up in this growing season.

If we are not able to raise $5,400, the project will be downsized accordingly.

The Perks

We have a number of exciting perks to offer.  You can view all of them in the side panel, but I would like to discuss one that involves you in the actual project!

At the $108 level, you will have the opportunity to either choose a topic for one of our weekly videos, based on a list of potential topics. (If there is something you are interested in that is not on the list, please contact us and we will let you know if it is an option). Your video of choice can also be a plant video about a plant that is not on the list, as long as it is in the garden or in the nearby woods.

Thank you for your support! We encourage you to share this with anyone you think might also be interested!

The current 50mm lens we are using limits how closely we can show the plant and all its parts. Incorporating extreme closeups would create an all around more engaging video for the viewer.
Here is a breakdown of where the money will go:
$2,700 will go to Jennifer for bills and living expenses into the winter months.
$1,800 will be used for equipment.
$900 will go to Mountain Gardens, to supplement for the perks we are offering, and to help Joe pay for other expenses that may come up in this growing season.
If we are not able to raise $5,400, the project will be downsized accordingly.


The Perks
We have a number of exciting perks to offer.  You can view all of them in the side panel, but I would like to discuss one that involves you in the actual project!
At the $108 level, you will have the opportunity to either choose a topic for one of our weekly videos, based on a list of potential topics. (If there is something you are interested in that is not on the list, please contact us and we will let you know if it is an option). Your video of choice can also be a plant video about a plant that is not on the list, as long as it is in the garden or in the nearby woods.
Thank you for your support! We encourage you to share this with anyone you think might also be interested!

story:
About Marilene and Brian

Marilene and Brian Richardson are the founders and owners of SongCroft Farm and SongCroft Self Sufficiency Skills School. They also started the Foundation for Sustainable Community and Snohomish Children's Peace Village. Brian and Marilene have been active in their community and have volunteered for many organizations and causes.

Marilene is a Washington State University Livestock Advisor as well as Master Gardener. She is a certified Permaculture Designer and teacher. Marilene is also a professional herbalist with a background in planetary herbology. 

The Intention

When the Shire is in their care, the Richardsons will continue to preserve it's delicate ecosystem, yet continue to make it available to others through careful stewardship and community programs such as Snohomish Children's Peace Village. In addition, they intend to grow traditional chinese herbs, perennial foods and create a demonstration garden of local indigenous edible plants. They intend for this property to be used for education, farming and forestry stewardship. Each area will be maintained in such a way to not negatively impact the existing landscape or ecosystem, and rather enhance and conserve its natural state. 

What is the Shire?

The "Shire" is a pristine 4-acre landscape of rolling green meadows surrounded by second-growth cedar and hemlock trees. It provides an essential natural habitat for local species like fox, deer, bobcat, cougar, and other wildlife that depnd on the meadow's resources to survive. Beyond its ecological significance, the Shire provides a vibrant community space to bring people together to inspire, to love, and to cherish the earth and all its living things.

The Snohomish Children's Peace Village, one of the many community workshops held here, brings kids together through art, music, and play while encouraging values of peace, social justice, and environmental education. SongCroft Self Sufficiency Skills School joins children and adults in learning about permaculture, wild edible foods, and herbal medicinces to promote essential knowledge on living off the land in harmony with local ecological systems. Wolf College and Fish Camp also take place on this sacred piece of land, teaching earth skills and fishing lessons to local children. 

Saving the Shire

This beautiful land is in danger of being developed, threatening the local ecology and terminating the various community events held on its grounds. We need your help to regain the Shire for our community and our environment. Every little bit helps! Our goal is $98,500, which would ensure the ecological conservation of the land and the continuance of community gatherings that connect individuals with each other and the land. 

If we do not reach the goal to purchase this property, our intention is to lease it, long-term.

What We Need 

We need $98,500 to purchase the Shire and place a yurt on it for retreat gatherings. 

Breakdown of Costs are as follows:

  • $90,500. Purchase of the Shire
  • $6,000. Yurt
  • $1,300 Yurt platform
  • $500 Portable fening for sheep
  • $200  3 Sheep  (otherwise known as lawnmowers)

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Tell friends and family members about our worthy cause, about saving our Shire! Let them know about this campaign and donating to our cause.

Thank you for considering this valuable campaign to save the Shire.

story:
Continental Divide: Wildlife, People and the Border Wall is a collection of photos and stories about the wildlife and people of the US-Mexico borderlands.

Congress needs to know how current policy is destroying wildlife corridors, habitat and human communities--especially now that the recent election has sparked talk of immigration reform.

 

 

 Short Summary

I am a photographer and writer and have been documenting the wildlife and people of the US-Mexico borderlands for that past 8 years. My book, Continental Divide: Wildlife, People and the Border Wall is a collection of photos and stories about the borderlands, and the impact US immigration and border policy are having on them.

Congress may soon be taking up immigration reform and it is very likely some members will try to demand additional border wall, roads, military bases and other infrastructure in exchange for reform. They will ask for the same enforcement measures that have been devastating borderlands ecosystems and communities for the past two decades. 

Help me help them understand how precious this region is--one of the most biodiverse places on the continent, home to jaguars, bighorn sheep, ocelots and pronghorn, and many others who are dependent on the US government finding a better solution than walls, roads and batallions of border patrol in our national parks, wilderness and wildlife refuges. 

 

  • Help me bring the borderlands to Congress
  • One copy of Continental Divide to every member
  • Immigration policy has determined the fate of the borderlands for the past two decades--Congress needs to understand this better before they decide what happens now.

 

For your donation you get:

To bring the borderlands to Congress I need $10,000. I can buy the books for $18 per book which, multiplied by 535 members of Congress = $9630 + shipping costs from my publisher.

Here's what you get in return!

For people who donate $10 I well send out a photo-tweet/facebook photo to you! You will also get a big bucket of thanks on behalf of borderlands wildlife and ecosystems.

If you can donate $35 a "Postcard from the Borderlands" and a photo-tweet, along with some sweet satisfaction that you have helped edumacate Congress.

If you can give $75, I will send you a signed copy of Continental Divide and a "Postcard from the Borderlands"  along with some sweet satisfaction that you have helped edumacate Congress.

For $150:  You will get an 8x12 print of a photo from the book, and I will send you a signed copy of Continental Divide, along with some sweet satisfaction that you have helped edumacate Congress.

For $250: I will send you a copy of my book Whooping Cranes: Images from the Wild; and a signed copy of Continental Divide, along with some sweet satisfaction that you have helped edumacate Congress.

For $1000: I will immortalize you by including your name in the acknowledgement section of the next printing of Continental Divide. I will also send you a signed copy of Continental Divide, along with some sweet satisfaction that you have helped edumacate Congress.

 

If I don't meet my goal: I will use the funds that I do raise to buy books strategically for key members of the House and Senate. Swing votes on borderlands protection will be targeted and prioritized.

If I exceed my goal: I will buy books for members of the Obama administration, state governors and other decision makers. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't afford to contribute right now? You can still help. Please share this campaign on social media and email, and tell your friends! Its easy with the Indiegogo share tools.

You can also donate to the Sierra Club Borderlands team--one of the strongest voices for borderlands protection. https://secure.sierraclub.org/site/Donation2?df...

story:
Carnival de Resistance

   

The newest project by the Affording Hope Project is The Carnival de Resistance- a travelling arts carnival, a village demonstration project, and a school for cultural transformation around the themes of environmental-economic justice, resistance, and radical theology.  The initial run of the Carnival will happen this coming fall and will take place in two locations - Harrisonburg VA - Sept. 13th - Sept. 22nd and Charlottesville VA - Sept 26th - Oct. 6th. In each location we will fill two weekends with experimental theater, live music, ceremony, street art and other forms of community celebration. The weekdays, in between, will focus on service projects, social engagement, education, skill sharing, craft and creative play.

A Mobile Carnival World:

        

Members of the Carnival Crew, a group of up to 30 will live, work, and travel together- collectively manifesting the vision of this project. Together, they will build the village, the outdoor Carnival venue and the Carnival midway. They will animate the Carnival midway, which teaches and entertains with roving performers, face-painters, story-tellers, a mask-making station, interactive installations, and clever twists on old Carnival games. The Carnival Crew will present four unique multimedia productions, each exploring one of the four elements (Earth, Air, Fire, and Water) and invite people to interact with these powerful symbols.

But most importantly, the members of the Carnival Crew will spread throughout the community to offer their unique gifts and support the programming of local organizations. According to the needs and interests of our local allies, we would like to paint murals and work on community gardens; offer workshops in bike repair, drumming, puppet-making, soap-making; help with stream clean-ups and political demonstrations, host story-telling circles for our elders and local food potlucks for all. To learn about the amazing people who have come on board as Organizers or as Carnival Crew, please visit our project website.

Demonstration Village:

A temporary village will be constructed to form the foundation for the events, modeling radical simplicity and sustainable alternatives.  We will consciously look at energy consumption in regard to transportation, food, waste management, footprint on the land and strain on the larger community.  This includes, but is not limited to:

  • Using repurposed material to build camp structures and production material (puppets, props, costumes, stage, set pieces, etc)
  • Cooking together (with food gleaned from local food sources) with solar ovens and rocket stoves, to diminish use of fossil fuels.
  • Travelling by bicycle and a veggie-oil bus.
  • Powering our event sound system with bicycle generators.
  • Practicing conflict transformation and transparency within the group.
  • Operating in the gift economy, with meals that are open to the public, no admission to the events, and freely shared resources and relationships

The Carnival will offer models of life-giving earth care practices that provide for practical needs within our communities.  At the same time, we are embodying a spirituality that is tied to the health of the Earth- a spirituality that has been fueling resistance work for generations. We hope to reinvigorate local leaders and rouse communities, inspiring those new to resistance work and encouraging those who have been holding the torch for some time. Visit the website, to learn more about our influences and the faith element of this project.

What We Need:

So far we have raised $20,900 out of our goal of $53,000, from grants and individual donations.  We are hoping to raise $18,000 on Indiegogo.  Your donations will go towards helping to build:

  • Items for our Community Kitchen & Village:  solar ovens, rocket stoves, solar showers, hand-washing stations, tent structures, etc. 
  • Items for our Performances: a bicycle -powered sound system, materials for mobile stages, costume materials, fire dancing equipment, props, carnival games, etc.
  • Items for our Social Engagement Events:  mural paint, art supplies for puppet-making, mask-making supplies and other skill shares.
  • Promotion Materials:  posters, fliers, website, etc.
  • Logistical Support:  tent and parade permits, insurance
  • Support for the Carnival Crew and Organizers (so that month long participation is possible)
  • Support for keeping ALL the events FREE, so that they are accessible to anyone in the world! 

What You Get:

We have some really creative and generous gifts available if you decide to donate to this fundraising campaign!  Some things are self explanatory, but for those that require pictures or further explanation, here are various links to check them out:

Bartimaeus Cooperative Ministries webinars: http://www.chedmyers.org/blog/2013/01/07/webinars and/or articles http://www.chedmyers.org/catalog.

Jon Felton and Soulmobile http://www.myspace.com/soulmobile                     

Psalters: http://www.geezmagazine.org/blogs/entry/psalters-stir-primal-connection-to-the-earth-each-other/                                                                                       

Leaps and Bounds DVD "The Dance of Exodus on an Age of Growth" http://www.affordinghopeproject.org/the-film/ 

Woodcuts by Julie Jack Scott:  http://carnivalderesistance.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/Apple-tree.jpg http://carnivalderesistance.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/Communal-meal.jpg or http://carnivalderesistance.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/Sunset.jpg 

Images by Tim Nafziger:http://www.timnafziger.com/ 

Learning Pack Selections (11 Books / 3 Magazines / 1 Poem):

  • 1 copy of "Come Out My People" by Wes Howard-Book http://www.abideinme.net/comp.htm 
  • 1 copy of "Seasons of Faith and Conscience: Explorations in Liturgical Direct Action" by Bill Wylie Kellermann http://www.amazon.com/Seasons-Faith-Conscience-Wylie-Kellermann/dp/1556359233
  • 2 books included in the Sabbath Economics booklet bundle: The Biblical Vision of Sabbath Economics (Myers) and Sabbath Economics: Household Practices (Colwell) http://www.chedmyers.org/books/sabbath-economics-booklet-bundle-biblical-vision-sabbath-economics-myers-and-sabbath-economics 
  • 1 copy of "Clothed with the Sun: Biblical Women, Social Justice, and Us” by Joyce Hollyday http://www.amazon.com/Clothed-Sun-Biblical-Social-Justice/dp/0664255388 
  • 1 copy of "Set Them Free: The Other Side of Exodus" by Laurel Dykstra http://www.amazon.com/Set-Them-Free-Other-Exodus/dp/1570754411
  • 1 copy of "Liberating Biblical Study: Scholarship, Art and Action" edited by Laurel Dykstra & Ched Myers http://www.amazon.com/Liberating-Biblical-Study-Scholarship-ebook/dp/B006T10NGK
  • 1 copy of "Who Killed Donte Manning:  The Story of an American Neighborhood" by Rose Berger http://www.amazon.com/Killed-Donte-Manning-American-Neighborhood/dp/1934074403
  • 1 copy of "Widening the Circle: Experiments in Christian Discipleship" edited by Joanna Shenk http://store.mennomedia.org/Widening-the-Circle-P766.aspx
  • 1 copy of "That Holy Anarchist: Reflections on Christianity & Anarchism" by Mark Van Steenwyk http://www.amazon.com/That-Holy-Anarchist-Reflections-Christianity/dp/0615659810
  • 1 copy of "Dreaming Moorish" a book of poetry by Jim Perkinson
  • 2 re-prints of published articles by Jim Perkinson based upon his book "White Theology: Outing Supremacy in Modernity"
  • 1 signed poem by Rose Berger
  • 1 back copy of Sojourners Magazine
  • 2 back copies of Geez Magazine on Christianity & Anarchism
  • 1 copy of Conspire Magazine on the "Green Revolution"

Supporters:

So far we've been blessed to recieve both in-kind support and monetary support from lots of individuals as well as a variety of organizations.  We hope to keep growing this list! 

  • Word & World - http://www.wordandworld.org/
  • Bartimaeus Cooperative Ministries Articles and webinars:  www.bcm-net.org/
  • The Alternative Seminary - http://www.alternativeseminary.net/
  • Presbyterian Hunger Program - http://www.presbyterianmission.org/ministries/hunger/what-we-do/
  • Christian Peacemaker Teams - www.cpt.org/
  • 8th Day Community - http://www.8th-day.org/
  • Cynicism & Hope Conference Fund
  • The Madwoman Project
  • IL Tool Workers Foundation

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you aren't able to contribute money at this time, or if you just want to keep helping us out - we'd love for you to help make some noise about our fundraising campaign and the Carnival itself! 

  • Check out the Indiegogo Share tools and spread the word to your family, friends, co-workers, churches, etc. 
  • Share our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/carnivalderesistance, send some e-mails, and write handwritten letters to those you know would love that!
