Other Ways You Can Help:
If you aren't able to contribute money at this time, or if you just want to keep helping us out - we'd love for you to help make some noise about our fundraising campaign and the Carnival itself! 

Check out the Indiegogo Share tools and spread the word to your family, friends, co-workers, churches, etc. 
Share our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/carnivalderesistance, send some e-mails, and write handwritten letters to those you know would love that!

story:
About Us

In 1983, Dr. Mariam Raqib left Afghanistan as a child refugee for America. When she returned for the first time in 2003 she found her country devastated by war. The trees that she loved and had once played happily under had been wiped out.

Determined to make a difference she set out to replace the trees lost by war. For the past 4 years she has perfected the skills and established nurseries required to produce high quality saplings in increasingly large numbers. Now these skills and knowledge are ready to take a big investment and expand the project to other provinces of Afghanistan and a wide-scale reforesation effort.  This is The Afghan Tree Project. As the multi-national forces leave Afghanistan in 2014, this is a powerful and practical opportunity for everyone to help leave Afghanistan a better place.  To do this we need your help. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need the funds to expand our nurseries which are the engine of the reforestation effort. By expanding the numbers of saplings produced we can provide fruit trees to individual families providing shade and fruit for nourishment. We can replace more of the traditional Deraa's shaded meeting places and begin our work to reform areas of forest which have been depleted by war.  

In exchange we have made efforts to make our gift packages more generous than an average crowdfunding campaign. We've done this because we hope you'll come back and support us again one day and also because we'd like you to be champions of this work to others in your own community.  

Our award-winning designer Johnny Selman based at Google's Creative Lab in New York designed our gift products and they are really stunning. We've designed our gifts around the principles of community and sharing. We want you to have fun flying our kites together and sharing cups of tea in our beautiful chai cups! 

In an age when we are all aware of our carbon footprint, even if we don't do much to manage it, a donation to the Afghan Tree Project provides a multi-impact carbon offset option. The trees not only reduce carbon but make a huge impact to the Afghan people, providing shade, nourishment and employment in a fragile economy.   If this is your motivation we've produced some carefully designed home and car window stickers which will let people know you care about carbon. 

We guarantee that no tree is double counted and the number of trees that you donate towards are the minimum that are planted on your behalf. If we do better we'll let you know that too.  

At the higher levels we are producing hard back coffee table books and personalised products by Afghan craftsmen and women.  Everyone receives a wall certficiate and stickers for your fridge, wall or bike.  

The Impact

Our work has great potential for the well-being of the country and the people.  We receive requests regularly from other communities in the neighboring provinces who know about our work and wish to collaborate with us.  

 The need is great, and yet our current funding situation does not permit us to explore options for growth.  We have spent years developing a successful working model for developing our projects, and these projects  are easily replicated elsewhere in the country.  We will use the funds from this campaign to develop and expand our projects.  We will do this in the following manner:

Plant larger quantities of seeds so that these seeds will then germinate and yield in greater number of tree saplings. The surplus saplings will be shared with communities in neighboring provinces.

The tree planting will mean the employment of additional nursery workers providing work, contributing to the economy and forming a workforce skilled in nurturing trees for the future. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

The best way you can help us other than by a donation is to spread the word of the Afghan Tree Project through word of mouth and social media. Please like us on our facebook page https://www.facebook.com/AfghanTree where you'll find all the latest gift information, news and pictures. We'd love you to share our posts and follow us on twitter @afghantrees where you can retweet us to your networks. We'll always follow you back. Why not hold a kite flying event or other fundraiser at your school or community centre? We'll do everything we can to help you with raffle prizes from our list of gifts and promotional material as well as giving you a big mention on our facebook page and twitter.  

Thanks for visiting the Afghan Tree Project, we're looking forward to our adventure together!

story:
Our Story

We (Kieran, Liam and Thibaut) are living in Bermuda, and we are enjoying our surroundings in our daily teenage lives. Even if we are appreciating our lives, we feel that an environment with less plastic will be better.

As a group, we want to make a change. After many hours of research about plastic pollution, contacting different environmental organizations and hard work, we finally decided our objective for our school project. We want to raise funds to have a third Seabin for Bermuda to fight the proliferation of plastic in the oceans.

A Seabin is a floating bin that collects trash from the water. Every hour, it pumps 25 liters of water into the catch bag. Afterwards, the water is pumped back into the ocean, leaving debris, litter, oil and other pollutants behind. We think that this can reduce the amount of plastic in the ocean.

We are organizing many fundraisers in and outside of our school to collect as much funding as possible for the additional Seabin. The challenging aspect is that one Seabin costs approximately $4000. We will be very happy if we are able to collect all of the funds necessary to purchase a singular Seabin, because we will feel that our Somersfield Academy M3 Community Project will have been a success. 

         

Please donate, and share this link to help us make Bermuda more sustainable and  the world a better place.

story:
My name is Ariane and I want to make the planet safe and healthy--for everyone.

In the past few months, our Congress members--and the 40,000 lobbyists that largely control them--enacted  the Montsanto Protection Bill, a bill that makes the GMO seed company impervious to lawsuits.  (This legislation was surreptitiously added to the March 2013 budget bill that President Obama signed to avoid a larger government shut-down.)

But the battle is not over yet!

This seed money I am raising will be used to print flyers, postcards and bumper-stickers, as well as to pay for advertisements in local newspapers to initiate a GMO boycott--starting in the Bay Area.  

It is hoped that others will be inspired by this work to launch their own boycotts locally thereafter, such that the boycott expands across the nation.

Remember:  Labeling is grossly insufficient, when our corporations are involved in criminal endeavors.  We need real choices.  And the choice is ours:

Let us come together as one human family and save our planet!

story:
The Veteran’s Green Bus, a green way to help educate and train veterans in green technology. We suffered a fire in the under carriage of the bus in Roanoke, Virginia. The fire damaged the bus’ electrical system.  

Veterans Green Bus, a 1980 Crown Coach was converted to run on biodiesel and used cooking oil.  The bus spent four months in Rockaway Beach, NY serving as a command center for relief efforts for Superstorm Sandy.

The crew of veterans were there when the storm victims needed them. Now it is your turn to support the Veterans Green Bus mission to demonstrate alternative fuel technology and provide disaster response when needed.

Roanoke Times columnist Dan Casey detailed Soderberg’s dilemma on March 25th.  Read the story here:Below are links for the Veteran’s Green Bus website and their Facebook page. I have also included their mission statement and a walking otur done by Soderberg when he tarted the conversion. 

http://unitedpeacerelief.ning.com/

 https://www.facebook.com/thegreenveteran 

http://unitedpeacerelief.ning.com/video/the-veterans-green-bus-tour 

Our mission is to demonstrate sustainable energy solutions for disaster response and rebuilding efforts using a self contained vehicle. Our goals are to expand veterans awareness and access to community service opportunities, job training and business opportunities in these industries.

story:
On Paypal I have raised a little over $2,000! Check the most up to date number at http://jenneristau.wix.com/solidarity 

 

Indigenous activism in Guatemala is under threat. Unfortunately, government remilitarization of those indigenous communities hardest hit during the 36 years of violence and genocide has steadily increased in the past four years. The repressive government’s presence poses huge barriers to indigenous civil and environmental activism. The Network In Solidarity with the People of Guatemala has been working since 1981 to make civic engagement possible for these indigenous activists. I will be stationed mainly in the Ixcán region of Guatemala for one year to monitor and report on crucial organizing of indigenous communities around environmental and civil rights. You can read more about the specific accompaniment projects of 2013 below. Will you join me in solidarity? You would be surprised how much your donation can make a difference. My sponsoring community in the United States has already raised $4,380 for the project. I just need  $2,955 more! Check out www.nisgua.org or visit my site at http://jenneristau.wix.com/solidarity for other ways to donate and events.

Other Ways to Act in Solidarity

Not able to make a donation at this time but still want to act in solidarity? Getting out the word is so important! Please let others know the many ways to donate on my website www.jenneristau.wix/solidarity! Send me an e-mail and I’ll give you an electronic copy of this blurb  nisguan.news@gmail.com

 

U.S.A. and The Guatemala Connection 

I moved to Berkeley, California after four years of immigrant organizing in Salem, Oregon. What I found upon arrival in Berkeley was surprising. On the sidewalks of a street not far from my house in Berkeley you will find approximately 85 Guatemalans lining the sidewalks and looking for work. After talking to them more, I found that many of my neighbors had left Guatemala for political and environmental reasons.

 My Guatemalan neighbors in Berkeley are not the only ones. Many rural indigenous Guatemalans are displaced from their home country due to the construction of large development projects and political violence. What is more, as long as those responsible for Guatemala’s 36 years of civil war and genocide still hold power, indigenous activists so adamantly committed to environmental preservation and justice will be denied their right to political participation.

Until civic participation becomes a real possibility for activists in Guatemala, there will be a need for human rights observers. I have decided to commit a year of my life to solidarity with these activists. As an accompanier I will present a physical presence of international solidarity to dissuade government violence. In addition, my work will amplify indigenous voices via an e-newsletter and news articles. 

NISGUA’s accompaniment projects have a record of success. Our Guatemalan partners report an increase in their power to organize as a result of physical international presence in indigenous activist spaces. The president of the Association for Justice and Reconciliation, one of the indigenous-led organizations we accompany once said,

"International accompaniment in Guatemala is a crucial foundation which makes the Guatemalan State recognize not only the participation of the people of Guatemala, but also that the international community supports the process and pursuit of justice in Guatemala"

What Is Needed & What You Get

U.S.-Based Sponsoring Community has already funded $4,380 of my costs

  • Food, lodging, transportation, immigration
  • Travel Insurance
  • Medical Exam, vaccinations
  • Partial Airfare to Guatemala
  • Re-entry Stipend ($500)
  • Administrative Costs for Oakland and Guatemala office

 

What You Fund First:

U.S. based training fee                                                             $900

Transportation to training                                                          $200

Partial cost of round trip airfare                                                  $500

NISGUA’s Guatemala office rent                                                 $200

Emergency Medical Fund                                                           $450

Sleeping bag (donated to NISGUA)                                              $120

Mosquito Net (donated to NISGUA)                                              $25

Hiking Boots                                                                           $160

Language Training*                                                                   $400

 

                                                                                    Total: $2,955

What is Needed Next

*The next $300 will be put towards U.S. congressional visits and educational tours upon return. Above that, donations will go to the non-profit I am working through (Network in Solidarity with the People of Guatemala) and the sponsoring communities to cover their newsletter and fundraising costs.

Your Impact

Although Accompaniers cannot cover every protest and every region, strategic decisions are made in order to use international accompaniment most effectively.

 

Accompanier duties:

 

  • Provide a physical international presence during rallies, peaceful protests and meetings.
  • Accompany genocide survivors testifying in court cases to and from the capitol.
  • Making home visits to indigenous activists to ensure no threats are made against them.
  • Mobilizing the international community to act through e-newsletters and media.

 

Overview of the 3 Key Areas of Civil Rights Your Donation Supports

 

Hydroelectric Dams Exacerbate Human Rights Abuses

A repeat of the Chixoy Dam is about to be reopened. The sister dam of the Chixoy called the Xalala Dam, was originally halted due to the work of the activist groups NISGUA observers accompany. Now the government has put out a new solicitation for construction bids. Even though the project will add 10% more electricity to the national reserve, the dam is implicated in corced indigenous displacement and harm to the delicate Chixoy River ecosystem. An excellent article and an example of the early stages of NISGUA’s involvement in the project can be found here at http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Guatemala-dam-will-bring-money-misery-3210665.php. Details on NISGUA accompanier involvement in the Xalala project in 2013 can be found at http://nisgua.blogspot.com/2013/01/guatemalan-government-restarts-xalala_14.html

 

The Human Rights Cases

The former President Rios Efrain Montt’s case, the highest official to be brought to justice in the America’s, will receive his verdict in July 2013. The lives of the over 200 witnesses in the case will be at especially high risk of retaliation. NISGUA accompaniers have been accompanying these witnesses from the AJR to and from the capitol for 12 years now. When I arrive in July, I will be put to work right away walking in solidarity with survivors. http://nisgua.blogspot.com/2013/02/unredacted-update-on-guatemalan.html

 

Mining and Death Threats

Guatemalan activists are at the forefront of the mining reform movement. San Jose del Golfo and San Pedro Ayampuc are communities protesting Tambor mine owned by EXMIGUA, the Guatemalan subsidiary of the US Company, Kappes, Cassiday & Associates. The protest is one of a series in Guatemala’s indigenous communities pressuring the government to conduct ethical environmental impact reports. The standoff at the mine entrance is also a move to enforce their right as indigenous people to consultation prior to government intrusion. The case of mining truly demonstrates the need for accompaniment as grassroots media personnel and community-based organizations are bombarded with death threats. Activists rely on accompaniers to be present at their now yearlong protest in order to report on the criminal activity of mine employees.  Read more at http://nisgua.blogspot.com/2013/03/la-puya-encampment-celebrates-first.html 

The 2013 Accompaniment Projects By Region

 

Ixcán

The upper third of the El Quiché department at the border of Mexico is known as the Ixcán region. The residents of jungle lowlands of Ixcán are largely Mayans who were dispossessed of their ancestral lands. The Ixcán communities became so successful that political and military leaders saw them as a threat and marked them as communist rebels during the civil war. Mayans and non-violent activsts in the Ixcán region were among the most persecuted and suffered heavily from the scorched earth massacres in the early 1980s. Those who escaped the fires in the Ixcán fled to Mexico.

      2013 Sample Ixcán Projects NISGUA Accompanies

  • Halting the construction of the Xalala Dam and oil exploitation.
  • Obtaining reparations for indigenous people violently repressed and displaced during the construction of the Chixoy Dam.
  • Organizing in Totonicapan for autonomy and free determination, sustainable development projects, demilitarization and an end to racism.

     2013 Sample Ixcán Activist Organizations Being Accompanied

  • Association of Communities for Development and the Defense of Territory and Natural Resources (ACODET)
  • Ixcán Referendum Follow-Up Commission
  • Ixcán Front in Defense of Life and Territory (FIDET)
  • Assorted community representatives

 

Ixil

The Ixil Triangle in the department of El Quiché is small geographically but teaming with activism. The Ixil Triangle refers to the area between Santa María Nebaj, San Gaspar Chajul and San Juan Cotzal. The density of indigenous peoples living in the Ixil Triangle made it one of the prime targets during the genocide.

      2013 Sample Ixil Projects NISGUA Accompanies

  • Non-violent action by the Maya-ixil from San José del Golfo and San Pedro Ayampuc to enforce an ethical environmental impact report for El Tambor mine
  • Unconstitutionality of Guatemalan mining law.

      2013 Sample Ixcán Activist Organizations Being Accompanied

  • Western Peoples Council
  • Community members and media personnel from San José del Golfo and San Pedro Ayampuc
  • MadreSelva Collective
  • The Northern Front of the Metropolitan Area (FRENAM)

 

Rabinal

Is located in Baja Verapaz. Like the people of the Ixcán region and the Ixil Triangle, the indigenous residents of Rabinal were some of the most violently persecuted during the civil war.

 

      2013 Sample Rabinal Projects NISGUA Accompanies

  • Plan de Sanchez organizing for justice in the human rights cases

 

      2013 Sample Rabinal Activist Organizations Being Accompanied

  • Association for Justice and Reconciliation (AJR)

 

                                Other Ways You Can Help

Sign up for the enewsletter on my website www.jenneristau.wix/solidarity

 

Accompaniment Works

As NISGUA accompaniers, we are adamant about the need for allies willing to allow Guatemalan activists to be the voice of their own movement. The founders of NISGUA realized during re-settlement in 1981 that international accompaniment of genocide survivors sizably reduces government-enforced violence. NISGUA volunteers only accompany grassroots organizers who ask for monitoring services. Where NISGUA accompaniers do not work directly is in regions with heavy narco-trafficking as accompaniment dissuasion tactics are less effective.

My commitment to justice in Guatemalan doesn’t stop after my year in Guatemala ends. I will continue to take direct action solidarity upon my return to the United States. Starting in July 2014 I will be engaging United States politicians in the need for solidarity with Guatemalan civil and environmental activists.

 

About NISGUA

The Network in Solidarity with the People of Guatemala (NISGUA) is an established organization with experience. Founded in 1981, NISGUA only accompanies activists who request accompaniment. Most importantly, the organization is fiercely committed to allowing Guatemalan activists to be the voice of their own movement. When you invest in me as a NISGUA volunteer, you know you investing your money into a project designed and led by the Guatemalan people.

I will be one of 5 NISGUA accompaniers. NISGUA is a founding member of an international network of international Guatemalan accompaniers called ACOGUATE. In teams of two, we will be working in four areas: Ixcán, Ixil, Rabinal and Guatemala City. Depending on the changing needs of Guatemalan activists, I will be stationed in one or more of these regions. I will be spending most of my time in the Ixcán region. Every six weeks I will report back to the capitol to report back to NISGUA. If I am moved to the capitol, I will be responsible for observing peaceful protests and accompanying witnesses in the genocide trials.

 

 

2012 Highlights of NISGUA’s Accompaniment Accomplishments:

  • Accompanied witnesses from the organization, Association for Justice and Reconciliation (AJR) for the trial of Efrain Rios Montt and his high military command who faced charges of genocide.
  • • Accompanied witnesses and family members during the sentencing of one ex‐commissioner and four exparamilitary members to 7,710 years in prison for the massacre of 256 people in the community of Plan de Sánchez in July of 1982.
  • •  Celebrated their hard work after the conviction and sentence of those accused in the 2010 murder of Lisandro Guarcax. In 2011, NISGUA observed proceedings in Lisandro’s case in 2011 and mobilized hundreds of supporters to sign‐on to a paid ad campaign calling for justice.
  • • Accompanied organizations working on one of the largest exhumations sites to date at a military base in Coban, Alta Verapaz, where over 400 cadavers have been recovered.
  • • Advocated on behalf of our partners with representatives of the US Congress and State Department to maintain the ban on military funding to Guatemala and to express concern about the deteriorating human rights situation since former general Otto Perez Molina's presidential inauguration.

Many rural indigenous Guatemalans are displaced from their home country due to the construction of large development projects and political violence. What is more, as long as those responsible for Guatemala’s 36 years of civil war and genocide still hold power, indigenous activists so adamantly committed to environmental preservation and justice will be denied their right to political participation.
Until civic participation becomes a real possibility for activists in Guatemala, there will be a need for human rights observers. I have decided to commit a year of my life to solidarity with these activists. As an accompanier I will present a physical presence of international solidarity to dissuade government violence. In addition, my work will amplify indigenous voices via an e-newsletter and news articles. 
NISGUA’s accompaniment projects have a record of success. Our Guatemalan partners report an increase in their power to organize as a result of physical international presence in indigenous activist spaces. The president of the Association for Justice and Reconciliation, one of the indigenous-led organizations we accompany once said,
"International accompaniment in Guatemala is a crucial foundation which makes the Guatemalan State recognize not only the participation of the people of Guatemala, but also that the international community supports the process and pursuit of justice in Guatemala"
What Is Needed & What You Get
U.S.-Based Sponsoring Community has already funded $4,380 of my costs

Food, lodging, transportation, immigration
Travel Insurance
Medical Exam, vaccinations
Partial Airfare to Guatemala
Re-entry Stipend ($500)
Administrative Costs for Oakland and Guatemala office
 
What You Fund First:
U.S. based training fee                                                             $900
Transportation to training                                                          $200
Partial cost of round trip airfare                                                  $500
NISGUA’s Guatemala office rent                                                 $200
Emergency Medical Fund                                                           $450
Sleeping bag (donated to NISGUA)                                              $120
Mosquito Net (donated to NISGUA)                                              $25
Hiking Boots                                                                           $160
Language Training*                                                                   $400
 
                                                                                    Total: $2,955
What is Needed Next
*The next $300 will be put towards U.S. congressional visits and educational tours upon return. Above that, donations will go to the non-profit I am working through (Network in Solidarity with the People of Guatemala) and the sponsoring communities to cover their newsletter and fundraising costs.
Your Impact
Although Accompaniers cannot cover every protest and every region, strategic decisions are made in order to use international accompaniment most effectively.
 
Accompanier duties:
 

Provide a physical international presence during rallies, peaceful protests and meetings.
Accompany genocide survivors testifying in court cases to and from the capitol.
Making home visits to indigenous activists to ensure no threats are made against them.
Mobilizing the international community to act through e-newsletters and media.
 
Overview of the 3 Key Areas of Civil Rights Your Donation Supports
 
Hydroelectric Dams Exacerbate Human Rights Abuses
A repeat of the Chixoy Dam is about to be reopened. The sister dam of the Chixoy called the Xalala Dam, was originally halted due to the work of the activist groups NISGUA observers accompany. Now the government has put out a new solicitation for construction bids. Even though the project will add 10% more electricity to the national reserve, the dam is implicated in corced indigenous displacement and harm to the delicate Chixoy River ecosystem. An excellent article and an example of the early stages of NISGUA’s involvement in the project can be found here at http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Guatemala-dam-will-bring-money-misery-3210665.php. Details on NISGUA accompanier involvement in the Xalala project in 2013 can be found at http://nisgua.blogspot.com/2013/01/guatemalan-government-restarts-xalala_14.html
 
The Human Rights Cases
The former President Rios Efrain Montt’s case, the highest official to be brought to justice in the America’s, will receive his verdict in July 2013. The lives of the over 200 witnesses in the case will be at especially high risk of retaliation. NISGUA accompaniers have been accompanying these witnesses from the AJR to and from the capitol for 12 years now. When I arrive in July, I will be put to work right away walking in solidarity with survivors. http://nisgua.blogspot.com/2013/02/unredacted-update-on-guatemalan.html
 
Mining and Death Threats
Guatemalan activists are at the forefront of the mining reform movement. San Jose del Golfo and San Pedro Ayampuc are communities protesting Tambor mine owned by EXMIGUA, the Guatemalan subsidiary of the US Company, Kappes, Cassiday & Associates. The protest is one of a series in Guatemala’s indigenous communities pressuring the government to conduct ethical environmental impact reports. The standoff at the mine entrance is also a move to enforce their right as indigenous people to consultation prior to government intrusion. The case of mining truly demonstrates the need for accompaniment as grassroots media personnel and community-based organizations are bombarded with death threats. Activists rely on accompaniers to be present at their now yearlong protest in order to report on the criminal activity of mine employees.  Read more at http://nisgua.blogspot.com/2013/03/la-puya-encampment-celebrates-first.html 
The 2013 Accompaniment Projects By Region
 
Ixcán
The upper third of the El Quiché department at the border of Mexico is known as the Ixcán region. The residents of jungle lowlands of Ixcán are largely Mayans who were dispossessed of their ancestral lands. The Ixcán communities became so successful that political and military leaders saw them as a threat and marked them as communist rebels during the civil war. Mayans and non-violent activsts in the Ixcán region were among the most persecuted and suffered heavily from the scorched earth massacres in the early 1980s. Those who escaped the fires in the Ixcán fled to Mexico.
      2013 Sample Ixcán Projects NISGUA Accompanies

Halting the construction of the Xalala Dam and oil exploitation.
Obtaining reparations for indigenous people violently repressed and displaced during the construction of the Chixoy Dam.
Organizing in Totonicapan for autonomy and free determination, sustainable development projects, demilitarization and an end to racism.
     2013 Sample Ixcán Activist Organizations Being Accompanied

Association of Communities for Development and the Defense of Territory and Natural Resources (ACODET)
Ixcán Referendum Follow-Up Commission
Ixcán Front in Defense of Life and Territory (FIDET)
Assorted community representatives
 
Ixil
The Ixil Triangle in the department of El Quiché is small geographically but teaming with activism. The Ixil Triangle refers to the area between Santa María Nebaj, San Gaspar Chajul and San Juan Cotzal. The density of indigenous peoples living in the Ixil Triangle made it one of the prime targets during the genocide.
      2013 Sample Ixil Projects NISGUA Accompanies

Non-violent action by the Maya-ixil from San José del Golfo and San Pedro Ayampuc to enforce an ethical environmental impact report for El Tambor mine
Unconstitutionality of Guatemalan mining law.
      2013 Sample Ixcán Activist Organizations Being Accompanied

Western Peoples Council
Community members and media personnel from San José del Golfo and San Pedro Ayampuc
MadreSelva Collective
The Northern Front of the Metropolitan Area (FRENAM)
 
Rabinal
Is located in Baja Verapaz. Like the people of the Ixcán region and the Ixil Triangle, the indigenous residents of Rabinal were some of the most violently persecuted during the civil war.
 
      2013 Sample Rabinal Projects NISGUA Accompanies

Plan de Sanchez organizing for justice in the human rights cases
 
      2013 Sample Rabinal Activist Organizations Being Accompanied

Association for Justice and Reconciliation (AJR)
 
                                Other Ways You Can Help
Sign up for the enewsletter on my website www.jenneristau.wix/solidarity
 
Accompaniment Works
As NISGUA accompaniers, we are adamant about the need for allies willing to allow Guatemalan activists to be the voice of their own movement. The founders of NISGUA realized during re-settlement in 1981 that international accompaniment of genocide survivors sizably reduces government-enforced violence. NISGUA volunteers only accompany grassroots organizers who ask for monitoring services. Where NISGUA accompaniers do not work directly is in regions with heavy narco-trafficking as accompaniment dissuasion tactics are less effective.
My commitment to justice in Guatemalan doesn’t stop after my year in Guatemala ends. I will continue to take direct action solidarity upon my return to the United States. Starting in July 2014 I will be engaging United States politicians in the need for solidarity with Guatemalan civil and environmental activists.
 
About NISGUA
The Network in Solidarity with the People of Guatemala (NISGUA) is an established organization with experience. Founded in 1981, NISGUA only accompanies activists who request accompaniment. Most importantly, the organization is fiercely committed to allowing Guatemalan activists to be the voice of their own movement. When you invest in me as a NISGUA volunteer, you know you investing your money into a project designed and led by the Guatemalan people.
I will be one of 5 NISGUA accompaniers. NISGUA is a founding member of an international network of international Guatemalan accompaniers called ACOGUATE. In teams of two, we will be working in four areas: Ixcán, Ixil, Rabinal and Guatemala City. Depending on the changing needs of Guatemalan activists, I will be stationed in one or more of these regions. I will be spending most of my time in the Ixcán region. Every six weeks I will report back to the capitol to report back to NISGUA. If I am moved to the capitol, I will be responsible for observing peaceful protests and accompanying witnesses in the genocide trials.
 
 
2012 Highlights of NISGUA’s Accompaniment Accomplishments:

Accompanied witnesses from the organization, Association for Justice and Reconciliation (AJR) for the trial of Efrain Rios Montt and his high military command who faced charges of genocide.

• Accompanied witnesses and family members during the sentencing of one ex‐commissioner and four exparamilitary members to 7,710 years in prison for the massacre of 256 people in the community of Plan de Sánchez in July of 1982.
•  Celebrated their hard work after the conviction and sentence of those accused in the 2010 murder of Lisandro Guarcax. In 2011, NISGUA observed proceedings in Lisandro’s case in 2011 and mobilized hundreds of supporters to sign‐on to a paid ad campaign calling for justice.
• Accompanied organizations working on one of the largest exhumations sites to date at a military base in Coban, Alta Verapaz, where over 400 cadavers have been recovered.
• Advocated on behalf of our partners with representatives of the US Congress and State Department to maintain the ban on military funding to Guatemala and to express concern about the deteriorating human rights situation since former general Otto Perez Molina's presidential inauguration.

story:
Short Summary

Brief description of the history and mission of the agency:

Meadowview Biological Research Station is a world-renowned research station with a mission of preserving and restoring rare pitcher plant habitats, and associated ecosystems, in Maryland and Virginia. The organization was founded in 1995 and has attracted local, regional, national, and international support for its efforts. Meadowview is a grass-roots environmental organization that has developed and sustained itself largely through the development of a unique business model: a conservation organization supported by sales of ornamental pitcher plant cultivars and novel native wetland plants with a supporting membership base. This business model has been successful in funding the organization to date but efforts are now underway to develop an endowment to support operations in the future. Meadowview also has a fifteen-year history of working with local elementary, middle, high school and college students.

Our mission is accomplished through a unique five-step process of discovery, propagation, research, reintroduction, and education. Long-range goals are being met through the development of a preserve system for Virginia’s endangered longleaf pine/ pitcher plant ecosystem. Two preserves have been developed in Virginia: the Central Virginia Preserve in Caroline County and the Joseph Pines Preserve in Sussex County. The Central VA Preserve is protecting the northern-most pitcher plant bog in Virginia with state threatened species while the Joseph Pines Preserve is re-assembling the indigenous biodiversity of the endangered Virginia longleaf pine/pitcher plant ecosystem. Support for these land conservation efforts has been obtained from the Virginia Dept. of Environmental Quality, Virginia Dept. of Forestry, Virginia Land Conservation Foundation, Community Foundation of the Rappahannock River Region, Mary Morton Parsons Foundation, International Carnivorous Plant Society, and worldwide members of the organization.

What We Need & What You Get

What we Need:

The Mary Morton Parsons Foundation awarded Meadowview a $50,000 challenge grant in November 2013 for the purchase of the education and biodiversity center at Joseph Pines Preserve. We must raise a match of $50,000 by November 2014 to receive the grant. This money will be the down payment on the biodiversity center.

This grant success was followed by the Virginia Dept. of Environmental Quality (DEQ) approving our loan request of $449,000 for the project. We received the second highest score in the Virginia for the project from DEQ, just below Natural Bridge. The loan is contingent on acquiring donor or foundation support for the note. Donations exceeding the needed Mary Morton Parsons grant match will be applied to secure and then pay the DEQ loan. The project is outlined in our 2013 newsletter and as a detailed pdf prospectus on our Joseph Pines link (both available on www.pitcherplant.org).

What You Get:

An education and biodiversity center will be established on a 51 acre parcel adjacent to Meadowview’s 232 acre Joseph Pines Preserve. The education and biodiversity center will support the conservation, protection, and restoration of the endangered longleaf pine/pitcher plant ecosystem in Virginia. The preserve is now in conservation easement with Virginia Department of Forestry. The education and biodiversity center will train students and the general public about the need and value of rare plant and animal conservation, support ongoing scientific research and restoration efforts at the Joseph Pines Preserve, and demonstrate how a sustainable lifestyle can support habitat restoration. Purchase of the education center property is part of a conservation plan to acquire almost 2000 contiguous acres and provide one of the largest and best managed examples of a longleaf pine ecosystem in a multi-state area. This property represents the northern limit of the known range of the longleaf pine ecosystem. Habitat restoration has included mechanical clearing, chemical site treatments, prescribed fire, and controlled reintroductions of at least 18 indigenous rare plant taxa (including one federally endangered species). Habitat is also provided for one federally endangered bird species (red-cockaded woodpecker), one state threatened bird species (Bachman’s sparrow), and one endangered fish species (black-banded sunfish). Meadowview also proposes to improve water quality on the 51 acre property which is at the headwaters of the Nottoway River. Water quality will be improved by cessation of grazing activities, implementation of an enhanced 300 foot wetland buffer on Joseph Swamp, restoration of vegetation on a fish pond and outflow stream, and conversion of 35 acres of pasture to longleaf pine seed orchard forest to assist DOF restoration efforts.

The Impact

The objectives of this project are to provide an education and biodiversity center in anexisting 4300 sq. ft. structure and to improve water quality on the Nottoway River. The education center will provide the facilities for intern, student, volunteer, staff, and visitor lodging (currently lacking from the existing Joseph Pines Preserve). 

Water quality will be improved by cessation of grazing activities, implementation of an enhanced 300 foot wetland buffer on Joseph Swamp, restoration of vegetation on a fish pond and outflow stream, and conversion of 35 acres of pasture to longleaf pine seed orchard forest. Specifically, the project will:

* Provide an education and biodiversity center to educate the public about rare plant conservation and provide the facilities to enable regional habitat restoration through an on-site rare plant nursery.

*  Develop a native Virginia longleaf pine seed orchard in collaboration with the Virginia Department of Forestry to assist in regional restoration efforts.

 * Propagate 18 rare plant species as part of an integrated longleaf pine-pitcher plant ecosystem restoration.

* Enlarge the Joseph Pines Preserve by 51 acres towards our goal of acquiring additional land to connect with both Cherry Orchard Preserve and DGIF’s Game Lake to form a total managed longleaf pine/pitcher plant ecosystem preserve and wildlife corridor of over 2000 acres.

* Provide an outside laboratory for research on various aspects of the longleaf pine/pitcher plant ecosystem.

*  Provide optimal conditions for recreational hunting by creating and maintaining habitat conducive to deer, turkey, quail, rabbit and other game animals.

 * Provide opportunities for primitive camping, hiking, bird watching, nature walks, photography, and other recreational activities.

Needs being addressed

Educational

 * Addresses need for environmental education facility identified by the Virginia Outdoor Plan

 * Hands-on training in ecological restoration

*  Research

Environmental and Ecological

*  Rare, threatened, and endangered species conservation and restoration

*  Groundwater preservation and enhancement

*  Longleaf pine seed orchard in collaboration with VDOF to meet state longleaf pine seedling shortage (see DOF letter of support in appendix)

 * Appropriate scope and scale of preserve size to ensure long-term success

*  Recreation

*  State land conservation objectives


Other Ways You Can Help

You can go right to www.pitcherplant.org and donate securely on-line for this cause or mail a check stating you want the funds applied as a match.

With a preserve system of almost 250 acres in central and southern Virginia we’re doing a lot of driving and need equipment to manage the properties.  Our 1997 Toyota 4-runner does a great job hauling heavy loads and going down tough trails but we need a reliable, fuel efficient, passenger car for preserve inspection and everyday use. We need golf carts to facilitate handicap tours of the nature preserve. We need picnic tables and benches. We need a heavy duty multi-purpose tractor.

WE NEED DEQ LOAN SPONSORSHIP. The Virginia Resources Authority will provide financing for the DEQ loan with a maximum of three qualified Meadowview member donor pledges. THE THREE SPONSORS would make seven annual payments of $20,250/year. Philanthropy at this level includes naming rights to the center for bio-diversity Please contact us if you can be one of these donors.

story:
Sunshine Daiquiris

During the New Orleans Earth Day Festival on Saturday, April 19th, the Louisiana Bucket Brigade would like to introduce Sunshine Daiquiris-- solar-powered, eco-friendly daiquiris. 

Solar Alternatives is handling the solar panels that will power the machines, and the daiquiris will be served in Ecoproducts' recycled cups.  

About Us

The Louisiana Bucket Brigade (LABB) is a 501(c)(3) environmental health and justice organization working with communities that neighbor the state's oil refineries and chemical plants. Our mission is to support communities' use of grassroots action to create informed, sustainable neighborhoods free from industrial pollution.

Many of our accomplishments focus on monitoring and documentation because proof of the problem is the first step to solving it. Some of our accomplishments in 2013 include:

  • trained over 500 Louisiana residents to document pollution using the iWitness Map
  • responded to nine chemical emergencies
  • prompted over $2.8 million in fines for safety and Clean Air Act violations
  • prevented refinery expansions in St. Bernard Parish
  • prompted the EPA to require Calumet Refinery in Shreveport to install fenceline monitoring system.

What We Need

$3,000 will cover:

  • double daiquiri machine rental
  • daiquiri ingredients
  • liquor
  • Ecoproducts cups and spoons
  • solar and testing power requirements

The Impact

Earth Day Festival Sunshine Daiquiris is a prototype; we're investigating its potential as a revenue stream for LABB. 

As a non-profit, we rely on support like yours to keep our doors open. By funding this campaign, you are helping the Louisiana Bucket Brigade get closer to financial independence so that we can continue advocating for environmental and social justice.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, please help us by spreading the word on social media, via email, or by telling your friends and family.

If you would like to join the Louisiana Bucket Brigade newsletter, click here. And for additional updates and to find out how you can get involved, please like us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter!

story:
The power of music.  The power of people. The power of media.

These three can change the world.

We are Artists for Media Diversity, A4MD. We're launching our Virtual Album service for community radio stations and are asking for your support.

Virtual Albums support public broadcasters - freedom of speech through the power of music - that's why we started A4MD.

Everyday is Earthday is our way of bringing together environmental organizations with recording artistst to support our public media and community broadcasters. We're planting the seeds now to launch Everyday is Earthday in the spring.

1 Recording Artist + 1 Song + $100 = 1 Track on a Virtual Album.

I'm Barbara K, recording artist from the band Timbuk3, "The Future's So Bright, I Gotta Wear Shades". I founded A4MD with Wolfgang Pracht and Ben Bright.

I love working with Gerald Torres, former director of the Environment and Natural Resources Division of the U.S. Department of Justice. He's a professor, currently the Bryant Smith Chair at the University of Texas Law School and the Vice Chairman of Earthday Network. 

Gerald and I made a video about Everyday is Earthday, you can check it out it in our IndieGoGo Gallery.

 

Our Goal: $10,000

A4MD, a 501(c)(3) tax-exempt nonprofit organization, works in partnership with the National Federation of Community Broadcasters (NFCB) and the Latino Public Radio Consortium (LPRC). We've got three virtual albums in the works the LPRC.

"Artists for Vieques" features songs from musicians who help build a radio station on Puerto Rico's Vieques Island, a former US naval bombing range. By giving a voice to the people, we help rebuild their shattered homeland. This virtual album launches in December. 

 

"Pachanga" features artists who have played the Pachanga Festival in Austin, Texas and want to support Latino radio stations.

"Español Yes! ¡English También!" features musical performances from live radio broadcasts on Latino public radio stations.

"Everyday is Earthday" features songs from artists who care about the only planet we have, the source of every thing we are, our mother, the Earth.

 

Recording Artists and Radio Stations

Recording Artist?  Sign up at https://a4md.org/artists

Radio Station?  Register at https://a4md.org/radio

 

So please, make a contribution. We'll send you a little something in return for your kindness.

If you're an artist/musician, contribute a song. Radio stations will be glad you did.

 

Everyday is Earthday.

Thanks for your support.
story_txt:
The power of music.  The power of people. The power of media.
These three can change the world.
We are Artists for Media Diversity, A4MD. We're launching our Virtual Album service for community radio stations and are asking for your support.
Virtual Albums support public broadcasters - freedom of speech through the power of music - that's why we started A4MD.
Everyday is Earthday is our way of bringing together environmental organizations with recording artistst to support our public media and community broadcasters. We're planting the seeds now to launch Everyday is Earthday in the spring.
1 Recording Artist + 1 Song + $100 = 1 Track on a Virtual Album.

I'm Barbara K, recording artist from the band Timbuk3, "The Future's So Bright, I Gotta Wear Shades". I founded A4MD with Wolfgang Pracht and Ben Bright.
I love working with Gerald Torres, former director of the Environment and Natural Resources Division of the U.S. Department of Justice. He's a professor, currently the Bryant Smith Chair at the University of Texas Law School and the Vice Chairman of Earthday Network. 
Gerald and I made a video about Everyday is Earthday, you can check it out it in our IndieGoGo Gallery.
 
Our Goal: $10,000
A4MD, a 501(c)(3) tax-exempt nonprofit organization, works in partnership with the National Federation of Community Broadcasters (NFCB) and the Latino Public Radio Consortium (LPRC). We've got three virtual albums in the works the LPRC.
"Artists for Vieques" features songs from musicians who help build a radio station on Puerto Rico's Vieques Island, a former US naval bombing range. By giving a voice to the people, we help rebuild their shattered homeland. This virtual album launches in December. 



 
"Pachanga" features artists who have played the Pachanga Festival in Austin, Texas and want to support Latino radio stations.
"Español Yes! ¡English También!" features musical performances from live radio broadcasts on Latino public radio stations.
"Everyday is Earthday" features songs from artists who care about the only planet we have, the source of every thing we are, our mother, the Earth.
 
Recording Artists and Radio Stations
Recording Artist?  Sign up at https://a4md.org/artists
Radio Station?  Register at https://a4md.org/radio
 
So please, make a contribution. We'll send you a little something in return for your kindness.
If you're an artist/musician, contribute a song. Radio stations will be glad you did.
 


Everyday is Earthday.
Thanks for your support.

story:
Intro

I am Mark Agana based in Metro Manila, founded Re-Store Project. It is an online platform where individuals, groups and businesses exchange unwanted items as a way to reuse and recycle. Re-Store.ph is the site where users can post their unwanted equipment, furniture and other usable items. Other users can search for the items and offer to take them off the owner's hands for free.

It aims to build a nationwide gifting movement by matching unwanted goods with individuals who can still use them.

The point is to create a community that exchanges objects that would have otherwise ended in the landfill or worse, in rivers, streets or drainage. It makes recycling and reusing as simple as one, two, click while at the same time helping individuals and businesses save money they would've spent on new items or properly disposing of their old items.


What We Need & What You Get

We believe that the Re-Store Project can lessen the overwhelming amount of trash Philippine cities spew out. Metro Manila alone produces 8,700 tons of garbage every day. Of this, 40% doesn't even have to be thrown away. Around 35% of generated garbage can be recycled while 5% can be reused.

The project is in the prototype development stage now. We already have started to develop the web platform: www.re-store.ph  but team put on hold the development because of some conflict with work and other commitments. We plan to hire or look for web developers/partners who can complete the web platform. 

The idea is very promising and we hope not to delay its development that is why we are sourcing for funds to make this happen. 

In order to realize this we hope to raise $ 3,500 USD for web development. Once we have it live, we will build the community and look for VCs to support the movement and upcycling.

In return for funding and supporting this project, we offer you the following perks (see below).

The Impact

The project aims to build a nationwide gifting movement by matching unwanted goods with individuals who can use them and to create eco-opportunities. Not only does the environment benefit from this system, it will also save businesses and individuals thousands of pesos in waste disposal and procurement costs while forging closer ties among local community.

Its first goal is to raise awareness within the community. The startup aims to have around 10,000 users by the first quarter of 2014. Once it reaches that stage, it will shift to the next phase of development, which will help them generate revenue. That’s when the team will implement an e-commerce aspect to the site. It aims to create new products from recyclable materials that it will sell on the platform and on an upcoming physical store. It will also encourage other eco-friendly stores to use the platform to sell their products.

All the services on the site are free. Members of the Re-Store community can build up "green points" every time they make an exchange. These points can be used to avail of rewards or discounts on products of member businesses and companies.

With enough exchanges, the Re-Store community can lessen the overwhelming amount of trash Philippine cities spew out. Metro Manila alone produces 8,700 tons of garbage every day. Of this, 40% doesn't even have to be thrown away. Around 35% of generated garbage can be recycled while 5% can be reused.


Advocacy with functionality

Businesses can use the Re-Store Project not only as a way to acquire needed equipment or resources, but as a way to build up their Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR).

The site will highlight the business’ green credentials so that members with green advocacies can make informed purchasing or procurement decisions.

Different communities can also come together on Re-Store. Members in the same town, company or building can let their colleagues know their old stuff are up for grabs on the site. Their physical proximity to each other makes checking the item's condition and claiming the item much easier and more convenient.

The bottomline for what will make Re-Store tick is streamlining. If successful, it can streamline not only how one person's unwanted resources meet another person's needs, but how Philippine communities manage their trash and treasure.

Best of all, it may just be the point where advocacy meets functionality, where helping the environment is not only laudable but also practical. 


Other Ways You Can Help

We are currently looking for people who can work /partner with us for this movement/start-up. If you're interested to know more about the project you may contact Mark Agana thru mobile +63 927 754 9036 or email mark.agana@gmail.com

Project References: 

Re-Store Website: http://www.re-store.ph 

Like us: https://www.facebook.com/restore.ph 

Follow us: @restoreph 

Watch Project Video: https://vimeo.com/77478815 

Please support this startup and discover how fulfilling (and easy) it is to live a more sustainable lifestyle!

Join the nationwide gifting movement.

story:
Last year, the Temple at Burning Man 2013 was the inspiration to launch the Temple for Trees initiative in order to raise funds to help replenish the wood the Temple burned. On April 6, 2014, we planted an inaugural Burning Man Grove located in Appalachia which you can read all about in this blog post. This year, we launched ART for TREES so we can build upon this momentum to restore the wood we use to build burnable art and plant more trees! Please consider a donation at any level.BACKGROUND: The awe-inspiring art that we interact with at Burning Man sparks us in a myriad of ways and the addition of fire allows for many of these rapid transformations. As humans, we long for ceremony and closure and, traditionally, fire ceremonies resonate on a fundamental level dating back to the beginning of civilization. Igniting intentional wooden pyres – especially the Temple and the Man – helps facilitate these transcendent experiences, potentially infusing us with knowledge of impermanence and of the cleansing power of conflagration - to let go of an old story and to renew - as we are lifted to new heights of introspection and action.

At the same time, in our now-populous world and annual gathering, we are keenly aware of the need to conserve and to recycle, and that we should not misuse the world’s limited resources. Last year, when we built the Temple, we faced that conundrum when a number of people asked, “How can you burn the Temple?”


Besides the obvious answers – “with fire” and “it’s been the tradition since the first Temple was built in 2000” – that persistent question and ongoing debate prompted us to reflect upon a possible solution that made the artistic process more complete, and ultimately more fulfilling – especially since our overall theme for the Temple of Whollyness was to move towards becoming more “whole” with our world and ourselves.  We examined all the resources we consumed in building the Temple 2013 and looked at ways to replenish them - as well as recycle, reuse and pick up our camp, build and burn site - in a way that extended beyond the literal playa surface beneath our boots. 

So last year, the Temple at Burning Man 2013, the Temple of Whollyness, launched the Temple for Trees initiative to raise funds to replant trees in order to replenish the wood the Temple burned. It made sense that the spiritual heart of the event took this small step.

We surpassed our goal and planted over 2,000 trees with Green Forests Work (GFW) in Appalachia, Kentucky and the National Forest Foundation (NFF) Stanislaus/Yosemite Rim Fire restoration efforts. That amount more than replenished the board feet wood we consumed building and burning the Temple and helped cover other art projects that also burned in 2013. With our community’s help, the Temple replaced what we consumed so there will be trees available for future generations of artists, builders and Burners. Art for Trees’ goal this year is to build upon this momentum.

There is much emphasis in Black Rock City about Matter Out of Place (MOOP) and Leaving No Trace of our visit on this federally protected desert we cherish. It makes us proud to completely scour the land, erasing our physical evidence, and practicing what we know we can accomplish when we diligently adhere to a common sense goal. Taking this one step further, we wanted to broaden the scope of Leaving No Trace to include our planet.

Of course, our playa-life experiment will ripple-out and inspire change only if we take our heightened awareness back to our communities and “walk the walk.” Easy to say, but how do we take those steps? Maybe we should take those steps backwards - to a simpler time when traditional old school values and considerations mattered. No fancy carbon footprint offset calculators or algorithms or Apps.  Let’s begin by practicing good manners. Perhaps by mentally adding a footnote to the Ten Principles of Burning Man – “#11. Radical GOOD MAN(ners): Our community endeavors to take only what they need and tries to replace what they use, and that can be replenished, so there is some left over for others.” Let’s try to pick up after ourselves and not allow the screen door to slam on our future possibilities with variables we do have some control over.

As we are reminded every day at the gas pump, not all we consume is renewable -  but trees actually are.  It is time to reexamine our relationship with the word “green” and simply honor wood, and our living trees, by replanting them where and when we are able.  They are our gifts that will truly keep giving back.

Can you please help replenish the trees from the wood we burn at Burning Man in 2014? Your donation will help replant real live hard and soft wood trees with our 2013 partners (GFW and NFF) as well as one new location (to be announced).

Thank you for your time, attention, consideration and donation.

Be well,
ART for TREES

story:
Protect Hawaii: Fund GMO Ground Zero Community Organization for Policy Work in 2014 Legislative Session

  • My name is Nomi Carmona, co-founder and President of Hawaii environmental and political non-profit Babes Against Biotech and I am an unpaid community organizer in Hawaii focused on GMO regulation and pesticide policy. My mission is to stop global chemical and biotech corporations from poisoning the land and people of Hawaii, and I need your support for the 2014 Hawaii state lawmaking session.
  • Babes Against Biotech (BAB) is a policy oriented, progressive, community advocacy organization that promotes organic living and grassroots democratic action to protect Hawaii from GMOs and related pesticides. We educate our peers on the environmental and health risks of GMOs and pesticides, advocate for voter registration, communicate with legislators, testify in government hearings, act as a community watchdog organization, analyze legislator campaign funding, protect our environment from chemical pollution and create pathways for Hawaii's long term sustainability, governing and local food production.
  • Hawaii is GMO Ground Zero worldwide. We are the home to over 5,000 open-air Genetically Modified Organism (GMO) experiments, exposing residents to massive restricted pesticide use, environmental contamination and genetic experimentation. We desperately need policy change to protect ourselves from GMO agrochemical intensive agriculture and Genetically Engineered (GE) seed production by the largest chemical companies in the world, occurring year round. The GE seeds developed in Hawaii are exported, genetically contaminating food crops worldwide, being engineered for experimental herbicide resistance and producing pesticides. Our air, land, water and health is being heavily genetically and chemically contaminated and we are considered the endangered species capital of the world.
  • The legislative session will release hundreds of bills and each bill has 2-8+ hearings and full votes before the House and Senate. Last year I was in the Capitol almost every weekday testifying and reporting, working overnight, marched through rainstorms across the state of Hawaii and have camped numerous times overnight in lines to testify for hearings when necessary. Everywhere there is a GMO lobbyist or interest at stake, I want to be there, defending and progressing community demands for safe, non-toxic environments.

Funding for Legislative Session Expenses

The $15,000 goal will cover all salary and organizational expenses for full-time support during the 2014 statewide Legislative Session from January through May 2014. During this time I will be focused on:

  • Delivering our powerful, statistic-based in-person testimony at all hearings state-wide related to pesticides and GMOs, including the upcoming Maui County legislation for pesticide and GMO disclosure, buffer zones and impact studies
  • Tracking, reporting on, and promoting all related legislative topics and proceedings for public knowledge and awareness
  • Organizing local communities to take constitutional and democratic actions that support positive legislation and prevent the government from stripping the people’s rights to a clean environment, health and choice
  • Building global awareness of Hawaii’s GMO and pesticide issues by continually growing our 22,500 subscribers, 13,000 members, and over 22,000 social media followers with a weekly reach of over 700,000 on Facebook alone
  • Growing outreach and educational event participation, with a focus on expanding our presence on Oahu and Maui
  • Completing a comprehensive Hawaii Voting Guide based on all elected officials’ voting records, campaign finance records and legislator surveys to drive votes to quality candidates and to reject candidates who do the chemical industry's bidding and fail to protect us – putting immense pressure on our public officials to act in the best interests of their people
  • I am up against a multibillion-dollar global industry with full staffs and millionaire lobbyists that have directed over $515,000 to our elected officials with all the chemical company funding they need to launch massive PR campaigns. I have to budget for everything and have grown our organization tremendously on a very tight budget, and will continue to make strategic use of every dollar.

Our Impact

In the past two years, with no salary funding, I’ve become known as one of the GMO/chemical industries' most public opponents in Hawaii, which is GMO Ground Zero worldwide. I am nearly everywhere they appear regarding policy, opposing their consistent perpetuation of misinformation about the risks of their products, and drawing attention to the amount of money they have given our elected officials and their undue influence. I have done this without any salary and now I am requesting back up. Some highlights of my past work include:

Policy History: I have delivered strong testimony on every measure, assisted in directing policy and attended almost every hearing on GMOs and pesticides in the Hawaiian islands since January of 2012. In 2013, I was in the Hawaii Capitol almost every day of session testifying for pesticide regulation, GMO labeling, the right to regulate GMOs and pesticide abuse, pesticide disclosure and public notification, the right for Counties to protect citizen life and health, school edible gardens and locally grown, non-toxic food for our kids and community members. Last year we saw the most progress on this issue in Hawaii ever. Together, we:

  • Nearly passed GMO labeling for the State of Hawaii
  • Defeated SB727, the chemical industry’s attempt to remove County rights to protect life and health
  • Defeated SB590, their attempt to legally shield themselves from pesticide drift and genetic contamination nuisance lawsuits
  • Passed HB-673, making progress in our pesticide disclosure policy with more public pressure than ever before
  • Enacted Senate Rule 23, to force a GMO labeling hearing in the Senate after I gathered other groups and Senator signatures
  • Blocked Monsanto from diverting 2.6 million gallons of water per day in Honolulu through the Water Commission
  • Passed Resolution 12-57 for GMO labeling in the City & County of Honolulu alongside now Congresswoman Tulsi Gabbard and Councilman Tom Berg
  • Passed GMO labeling measures in Maui, Kauai and Hawaii Counties for the 2012 Hawaii State Association of Counties legislative package
  • Passed Kauai County Bill 2491 for GMO and pesticide disclosure, spraying buffer zones and impact studies
  • Passed Hawaii Island Bill 113 for GMO prohibition

First Amendment Protections: I have been highly involved in, organized, supported, and promoted various community collaboration efforts across the Hawaiian islands, including:

  • Education at over three dozen outreach events across Hawaii in 2013
  • 2012 March on Monsanto, March on Monsanto II, and March on Syngenta, alongside James W. Macey and Hawaiian sovereignty leader Uncle Walter Ritte
  • 2012 GMO Free Oahu’s Aina Fest
  • 2013 We the People Rally & Heleku March on Hawaii Capitol Legislative Opening Day, under Uncle Walter Ritte's leadership with Dr. Vandana Shiva
  • 2013 Holomua for the Right to Know at the Capitol for GMO labeling
  • 2013 Marches in March; a session of marches on all islands, with Hawaii GMO Justice Coalition and pro-surfer Dustin Barca with over 6,000 participants statewide
  • 2013 Waikiki March Against Monsanto, with the support of over 2,500 people and dozens of our non-profit and supporting groups
  • 2013 Mana March on Kaua`i for Bill 2491 with Ohana O Kauai and Hawaii SEED with over 4,000 in attendance
  • 2013 Haleiwa Aloha Aina March of over a thousand people, with Ohana O Kauai, Dustin Barca, and numerous world famous surfers despite the storm and rain
  • In 2013, over 17,000 Hawaii residents in total have marched to remove these hazardous companies from Hawaii with our organization, support and/or promotion

Media Appearances: Featured in Business Week, The Huffington Post, The New York Times, Associated Press, Hawaii News Now, KITV, KGMB, KHON, Fox News Radio, Sustainable Pulse, The Garden Island, Civil Beat, Honolulu Weekly, Honolulu Star-Advertiser, The West Australian, Canberra News, David Cain Has Issues, The Seed Story, Hawaii Tribune Herald, For Ewa Today, The Rick Hamada Show, Health Talk Hawaii, Hawaii's Tomorrow, Soap Box Live, Songs of Sovereignty, 102.7 Da Bomb, Star 101, Hawaii Public Radio and numerous other publications and community shows. Inducted into the Hall of Fame by the Every Day Hero Project in 2013.

Background: I have had tens of thousands of dollars of leadership development and public speaking training and am the former United States Director of Sales for an electrophysiology technology company with products based on Nobel prize winning research and created by the co-inventor of the Pacemaker. I was mentored by my international CEO, the former Director of Estée Lauder and a highly decorated Counterintelligence Instructor in the United States Army. I was a child theater actress and professional dancer in my teens and am a graduate of LACHSA. As an adult, I shifted my focus from the entertainment industry towards gait analysis and muscular sports therapy with a focus on improving athletic performance, completing an internship with a chiropractic upper cervical specialist. After leaving the sales Director position to free more time for Hawaiian cultural studies, I worked for combined years in recruiting rare technical talent for venture capitalist funded start-ups, training, natural food distribution and Community Supported Agriculture. In addition, I held a Director position for a sustainability based curriculum pilot project in West Oahu and I am the former Executive Secretary for the Honolulu City Council, District One, Waianae Coast. 

I was raised in an internationally politically active family, I have to give credit. My Father was an anti-Batista rebel leader in Cuba turned USC graduated history professor who engaged in international relations and founded several global alliances which negotiated for peace in war zones. I traveled to 16 countries with my parents and observed diplomacy between dozens of countries as a kid but they were extremely busy so we had an unconventional democratic method of governing the household. We had a constitution and statutes which were formed through annual mock legislative sessions around the kitchen table. Everything was approved through negotiation and contractual agreements I had to write, even my ballet lessons. These days, we laugh about how ridiculously serious it was for kids and my Mom just says, "Yeah, but, look at you now!"

Other Ways You Can Help

I completely understand if you cannot give financially right now and there are many other ways you can help me accomplish these goals:

  • Share this site with your friends who care about the environment, pesticide abuse and the risks of unregulated genetic engineering and ask them to support. What happens in Hawaii affects the entire world since the bulk of GMO testing and GMO seed industry is occurring here.
  • Volunteer for BAB or collaborate! We need everyone's support on this issue, no matter how small. You can reach me at nomi@babesagainstbiotech.org.

Mahalo!
