story:
Where our idea comes from…

De donde nace nuestra idea...

Thanks for taking the time to review our idea for the construction of solar panels in this small unique village of India, where with our volunteering program we have developed initiatives for the cleaning of the rivers and places where people live, ecological education for children and now taking the project to a new level: renewable energy.

Gracias por tomarte el tiempo para revisar nuestra idea para la construcción de paneles de energía solar en este pequeño y único pueblo en India, en donde con el programa de voluntarios hemos desarrollado iniciativas para la limpieza de la los lugares donde vive la gente y sus ríos, la educación ecológica de los niños y ahora llevando el proyecto a un nuevo nivel: la energía renovable. 

During the past 5 years we have developed the project A Helping Hand for Vrindavan with which we have achieved to contribute to the ecological wellbeing of this particular village, installing grids for the straining of garbage preventing its deposit in the rivers and periodic cleanings with volunteers of the diverse sacred places. We have also collected donations for mobilizations with riksas to clean the city, among many other projects. This time We want to install solar paneles in a temple in Vrindavan, inspiring the community of the locality to follow this example and decrease the use of polluting energy such as We obtain with fossil fuels (used in motors) and noise pollution.

Durante los últimos 5 años hemos desarrollado el proyecto Helping Hands for Vrindavan con el cual hemos conseguido contribuir al bienestar ecológico de este particular pueblo, instalando rejillas para la contención de basuras, el equipo de voluntarios realiza periódicamente jornadas de limpieza de los diferentes lugares sagrados, conseguimos la donación de riksas (bicicletas) para la limpieza de la ciudad, entre muchos otros proyectos. Esta vez queremos instalar paneles de energía solar, con la idea de que otras comunidades de la localidad también sigan este ejemplo y se pueda disminuir el uso de energías contaminantes como la que se obtiene de combustibles fósiles (usado en los motores) y la contaminación auditiva.

It’s a lot more than just a charity program; with your contribution and the help from the volunteer team we can give the first steps towards the use of local energy in Vrindavan, where the community suffers the consequences of a deficient source of energy and the contamination related with the use of noisy motors fed by fossil fuels.

Es mucho más que un programa de caridad, con tu contribución y la ayuda del equipo de voluntarios podremos dar el primer paso hacia la utilización de energía solar en Vrindavan, donde la comunidad sufre las inclemencias de un suministro deficiente de energía y la contaminación relacionada con el uso de ruidosos motores alimentados con combustibles fósiles.

You can be a volunteer, contribute with this pilot plan so it can be replicated in other places and we can show that solar energy is one of the best alternatives to protect the environment.

Tú puedes ser voluntario, contribuir con este plan piloto para que sea replicado en otros lugares y mostremos que la energía solar es una de las alternativas más factibles para conservar el medio ambiente.

Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes...

What we need and what you obtain…

We wish to construct solar panels as an alternative source of renewable energy in the Eco Yoga Village Vrinda Kunja, located in the town of Vrindavan (India).

Deseamos construir paneles solares como alternativa de fuente de energía renovable en la Eco yoga Aldea Vrinda Kunja, localizada en el pueblo de Vrindavan (India).

To acquire solar panels destined to cover the total energy consumption of the community which is of 5kWp, and install the grids to prevent the monkeys (very popular in the village) from destroying them, we require USD 15.000. The expenses relative to the campaign and communications are covered by the team of volunteers of the Eco Village.

Para comprar los paneles solares destinados a cubrir el total del consumo que es de 5kWp, e instalar rejillas para evitar que los monos (muy populares en la comunidad) los destruyan, se requieren 15 mil dólares. Los gastos relativos a la realización y difusión de esta campaña serán cubiertos por un equipo de voluntarios de la eco aldea.


Budget/presupuesto

DESCRIPTION No. UNIT UNIT.PRICE P. TOTAL

Solar PV Array capacity 5000 Wp x 20 Nos. 1 set 11200 11200

Sine wave DSP based solar power conditioning Unit6KVA96V (su-kam make) 1 set 450 450

Tubular battery bank 180AH96V 1 set 220 220

AJB/IAJBs, Hensel Make/ Equivalent 1 set 95 95

Module Mounting Structure 1 set 450 450

Earthimg set for module structure 1 set 126 126

Cables and accesories 1 set 170 170

Still grids 60 mts2 29 1740

Installation of grids 7 days 45 315

Design and service for website 3 pages 100 300
TOTAL CROWDFUNDING
 $15066


Promotion 45 day 13 585

Electric engineer 3 day 35 105

Transportation 13 Tkts 4 52

Food 160 lunch 4 640

Crowdfunding commission Indiegogo 1 10% 1500

Perks 30 tour 40 1200
TOTAL VOLUNTEER HELP
$4082
TOTAL CROWDFUNDING 79% 15066
TOTAL VOLUNTEER HELP 21% 4082
TOTAL  PROJECT 100% 19148

We offer the best perks so that on top of becoming a volunteer with your contribution, you can have a unique experience in one of the eco yoga villages from our worldwide network, which offer volunteering programs, yoga, and mystical retreats.

Te ofrecemos las mejores recompensas para que además de sumarte al equipo de voluntarios haciendo tu contribución, puedas vivir una experiencia única en una de las eco aldeas de la red Eco yoga Village, que ofrecen programas de voluntariado, yoga, retiros espirituales en todo el mundo.  

The impact…

El impacto…

Vrindavan is a town that has conserved a mystical and spiritual tradition for thousands of years. It’s known as the city of 5000 temples and annually receives thousands of pilgrims from around the world. 

Vrindavan es una ciudad donde se conserva una tradición mística y espiritual desde hace miles de años. Es conocida como la ciudad de los 5000 templos y anualmente recibe miles de peregrinos de todo el mundo.

In Vrindavan there are various communities in multiple temples. Among these is the eco village Vrinda Kunja where the volunteering program has been contributing to the town for the past 15 years, through the non profit called Helping Hand for Vrindavan  (www.helpinghandforvrindavan.org).

En Vrindavan conviven varias comunidades en sus múltiples templos. Allí se encuentra la eco aldea Vrinda kunja donde se realiza el programa de voluntariado desde hace 15 años con un impacto en toda la ciudad, mediante la organización sin ánimo de lucro llamada Helping Hand for Vrindavan (www.helpinghandforvrindavan.org).

We are not only thinking in benefit of the specific Eco Village; this project intends through our volunteering program to improve the quality of life of the population and the environment. Some of the projects that have been done are:

-  Construction and maintenance of the Hanuman School: through donations we’ve received and with the constant help of volunteers from around the world, we have constructed the first installations for the Hanuman School, where more than 30 children meet daily in the afternoons and receive English and organic agriculture classes. Some teachers are paid with the donations and others are part of the volunteering team.

-  Cleaning the Yamuna: preventing solid plastics such as bags and bottles to get to the river, using a system of grids installed in the wastewater channels. Daily follow ups are made and cleanings of more than 15 areas with a group of local workers and international volunteers from the Eco Village. These workers are also paid with donations received in the ecological community.

-  Garbage: we´ve installed garbage containers in the most important pilgrimage places. With hundreds of pilgrims in Vrindavan, most of the garbage is not collected appropriately. The installation of the public containers in the main temples generates an improvement for the environment and at the same time is an educational program for the local inhabitants.

-  Recovering areas that represent cultural patrimony for humanity: one of our initial achievements was to motivate local organizers to recuperate a lake that had become dump, transforming it into a beautiful park with clean waters.

-  Restorations: one of the oldest and most important temples of Vrindavan (Radha Gopinath Mandir) was in a state of abandonment since the last Muslim invasion. Currently we have achieved to recuperate two areas and transform them to public gardens. The project continues to grow and important donations have been collected for the restoration of the temple.

-  Posters and art on the streets: some volunteers offer their artistic abilities through street theatre, posters and murals with ecological messages and specially developing educational strategies for the issues with plastic use. As a result from this service from the team of volunteers, we have achieved that the population feels identified with the seriousness of the environmental problem and participates actively in the cleanings.

-  From plastic to natural: due to the constant flow of pilgrims in the many temples of the town, in the past years its becoming popular to use plastic plates leaving aside the traditional practice of organic plates made from palm leaves as well as mud cups. Through an intense educational campaign in relation to the harmful effects of plastic, we have now achieved that most temples return to their traditional use of natural plates.

No estamos pensando solo en el beneficio de una eco aldea en particular, pues a través del programa de voluntariado ya hemos conseguido mejorar las condiciones de vida y ambientales de la población. Algunos de los proyectos que ya hemos realizado son:

-  Construcción y mantenimiento de la escuela Hanuman: A través de las donaciones que hemos recibido y con la ayuda constante de voluntarios de todo el mundo, construimos las primeras instalaciones para la escuelita Hanuman, donde más de 30 niños de la población se reúnen todas las tardes y reciben clases de inglés y agricultura orgánica. Algunos profesores son pagos con estas donaciones y otros son parte del equipo de voluntarios.

-  Limpieza del Yamuna: que los residuos sólidos plásticos como botellas, bolsas, etc., no lleguen al rio Yamuna, usando un sistema de rejas instaladas en los desagües de aguas negras que desembocan en el rio. Diariamente se hace un seguimiento y una limpieza de más de 15 desagües con un grupo de trabajadores locales y voluntarios internacionales de la eco aldea. Estos trabajadores también son pagos con las donaciones recibidas en la eco aldea

-  Instalación de basureros en lugares importantes de peregrinación: Con los cientos de peregrinos en Vrindavan, muchas veces se generan basuras que no son adecuadamente recolectadas. La instalación de estos basureros públicos en los principales templos genera mejoras en el medio ambiente y es a la vez un programa educativo para los habitantes locales.

-  Recuperación de áreas que son patrimonio cultural de la humanidad: uno de nuestros primeros logros fue animar a las organizaciones locales para recuperar un lago que se había convertido en vertedero y transformarlo en un parque muy lindo, con aguas limpias nuevamente.

-  Restauraciones: uno de los templos más antiguos e importantes de Vrindavan (Radha Gopinath Mandir) se encontraba en un estado de abandono desde la época de la última invasión musulmana. Actualmente hemos conseguido recuperar dos áreas y transformarlas en jardines públicos. El proyecto continúa creciendo y se han conseguido importantes donaciones para la reconstrucción del templo. 

-  Afiches y artes en las calles: Algunos voluntarios ofrecen sus habilidades artísticas a través de teatro ambulante, afiches y murales con mensajes ecológicos y especialmente tratando temáticas educativas al respecto del plástico. Como resultado de este servicio del equipo de voluntarios, se ha logrando que la población identifique la gravedad del problema ambiental y participe de las actividades de limpieza frecuentes.

-  Del plástico a lo natural: por el flujo constante de peregrinos en los múltiples templos de la ciudad, en los últimos años se hizo común el uso de utensilios plástico dejando de lado el tradicional uso de utensilios orgánicos como platos de hojas de palma y vasos de arcilla. A través de una intensa campaña educativa acerca de los peligros del plástico, conseguimos que nuevamente la mayoría de los templos eviten su consumo.

The main focus of our services in Vrindavan of education are to local villagers, aiming that they take individual and collective actions that prevent the damage caused to the environment in the day to day habits. As a satisfactory result we have seen growth in the interest of other organizations such as the Braj Foundation, Food for Life, etc. that are motivated to adopt these environmental and educational programs.

El foco principal de nuestros servicios en Vrindavan en la educación son a los pobladores locales, para conseguir que tomen acciones individuales y colectivas que eviten el daño causado al medio ambiente por los hábitos cotidianos. Como resultado satisfactorio hemos visto el creciente interés que otras agrupaciones tales como Braj Fundation, Food for Life, etc, tienen por implementar estos proyectos ambientales y educativos.

Now we want to be an example so that in the future other communities of the locality substitute the use of dirty energy for the consumption of clean solar energy, and due to the trajectory that we have, we are confident that we can achieve our goal thanks to the support we have from the community, who has seen the positive results and the improvement of their village with the program.

Ahora queremos ser un ejemplo para que más adelante otras comunidades de la localidad substituyan el uso de energías sucias, por el consumo de energía solar limpia, y debido a toda la trayectoria que tenemos, estamos seguros de que podemos lograrlo ya que la comunidad en general es muy favorable a todas nuestras actividades y recomendaciones porque han visto el impacto positivo y lo que hemos conseguido.

Risks and challanges…

Riesgos y desafíos…

In Vrindavan there are a variety of animals that have learned to coexist with humans. Among them are the monkeys that wander constantly on the rooftops and could damage the panels. To prevent this, we are planning to install grids to protect the installation.

En Vrindavan existe una variedad de animales que se han acostumbrado a coexistir con los seres humanos, entre ellos los monos que andan constantemente por los tejados, los cuales podrían dañar los paneles. Para evitarlo, estamos planeando la instalación de rejas que los protegen de forma adecuada.

We can be the pioneers in the installation of solar panels in the city, serving as an example to follow and we are willing to give total support and consultation to the rest of the community based on this experience.

Podemos ser los pioneros en la instalación de paneles de energía solares en la ciudad, siendo un ejemplo a seguir para lo cual estaremos dispuestos a prestar todo el apoyo y asesoría a las comunidades, a partir de esta experiencia.

Other ways you can help…

Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar…

You can help us, be part of the project to change the world step by step, make your contribution with a donation or sharing the campaign through the networks. From here you can share this post on Facebook, Twitter and other networks.

Tú puedes ayudarnos, ser parte de este proyecto para cambiar el mundo paso a paso, haz tu contribución ya sea a través de una donación o divulgando nuestro proyecto en las redes sociales. Desde aquí mismo puedes compartir esta nota en facebook, twtter y otras redes sociales.

You can also participate as a volunteer at our organization by contacting our web page

www.helpinghandforvrindavan.org 

También puedes participar como voluntario en nuestra organizacion contactando la pagina:

www.helpinghandforvrindavan.org

for Vrindavan con el cual hemos conseguido contribuir al bienestar ecológico de
este particular pueblo, instalando rejillas para la contención de basuras, el
equipo de voluntarios realiza periódicamente jornadas de limpieza de los
diferentes lugares sagrados, conseguimos la donación de riksas (bicicletas)
para la limpieza de la ciudad, entre muchos otros proyectos. Esta vez queremos instalar paneles de energía solar, con la idea de que otras comunidades de la localidad
también sigan este ejemplo y se pueda disminuir el uso de energías
contaminantes como la que se obtiene de combustibles fósiles (usado en los motores) y la contaminación
auditiva.
It’s a lot
more than just a charity program; with your contribution and the help from the
volunteer team we can give the first steps towards the use of local energy in
Vrindavan, where the community suffers the consequences of a deficient source
of energy and the contamination related with the use of noisy motors fed by
fossil fuels. 
Es mucho más que un programa de caridad, con tu contribución y la ayuda
del equipo de voluntarios podremos dar el primer paso hacia la utilización de
energía solar en Vrindavan, donde la comunidad sufre las inclemencias de un
suministro deficiente de energía y la contaminación relacionada con el uso de
ruidosos motores alimentados con combustibles fósiles. 
You can be a
volunteer, contribute with this pilot plan so it can be replicated in other
places and we can show that solar energy is one of the best alternatives to
protect the environment. 
Tú puedes ser voluntario, contribuir con este plan piloto para que sea
replicado en otros lugares y mostremos que la energía solar es una de las
alternativas más factibles para conservar el medio ambiente.
Lo que
necesitamos y lo que obtienes...
What we need and what you
obtain…
We wish to construct solar
panels as an alternative source of renewable energy in the Eco Yoga Village
Vrinda Kunja, located in the town of Vrindavan (India).
Deseamos construir paneles solares como alternativa
de fuente de energía renovable en la Eco yoga Aldea Vrinda Kunja, localizada en
el pueblo de Vrindavan (India).
To acquire
solar panels destined to cover the total energy consumption of the community
which is of 5kWp, and install the grids to prevent the monkeys (very popular in
the village) from destroying them, we require USD 15.000. The expenses
relative to the campaign and communications are covered by the team of
volunteers of the Eco Village. 
Para comprar
los paneles solares destinados a cubrir el total del consumo que es de 5kWp, e
instalar rejillas para evitar que los monos (muy populares en la comunidad) los
destruyan, se requieren 15 mil dólares. Los gastos relativos a la realización y
difusión de esta campaña serán cubiertos por un equipo de voluntarios de la eco
aldea. Budget/presupuesto

We offer the best perks so that on top of becoming a volunteer with your contribution, you can have a
unique experience in one of the eco yoga villages from our worldwide network,
which offer volunteering programs, yoga, and mystical retreats.
Te ofrecemos las mejores recompensas para que
además de sumarte al equipo de voluntarios haciendo tu contribución, puedas
vivir una experiencia única en una de las eco aldeas de la red Eco yoga
Village, que ofrecen programas de voluntariado, yoga, retiros espirituales en
todo el mundo.  

The
impact…
El impacto…
Vrindavan is a town that
has conserved a mystical and spiritual tradition for thousands of years. It’s
known as the city of 5000 temples and annually receives thousands of pilgrims
from around the world.  
Vrindavan es una ciudad donde se conserva una
tradición mística y espiritual desde hace miles de años. Es conocida como la
ciudad de los 5000 templos y anualmente recibe miles de peregrinos de todo el
mundo.In Vrindavan there are various communities in multiple temples. Among these is the eco village Vrinda Kunja where the volunteering program has been contributing to the town for the past 15 years, through the non profit called Helping Hand for Vrindavan  (www.helpinghandforvrindavan.org).En Vrindavan conviven varias comunidades en sus
múltiples templos. Allí se encuentra la eco aldea Vrinda kunja donde se realiza
el programa de voluntariado desde hace 15 años con un impacto en toda la ciudad, mediante la organización sin ánimo de lucro llamada Helping Hand for Vrindavan (www.helpinghandforvrindavan.org).
We are not only thinking in
benefit of the specific Eco Village; this project intends through our
volunteering program to improve the quality of life of the population and the
environment. Some of the projects that have been done are: 
- 
Construction and maintenance of the Hanuman School: through donations
we’ve received and with the constant help of volunteers from around the world,
we have constructed the first installations for the Hanuman School, where more
than 30 children meet daily in the afternoons and receive English and organic
agriculture classes. Some teachers are paid with the donations and others are
part of the volunteering team. 
- 
Cleaning the Yamuna: preventing solid plastics such as bags and bottles
to get to the river, using a system of grids installed in the wastewater
channels. Daily follow ups are made and cleanings of more than 15 areas with a
group of local workers and international volunteers from the Eco Village. These
workers are also paid with donations received in the ecological community. 
- 
Garbage: we´ve installed garbage containers in the most important
pilgrimage places. With hundreds of pilgrims in Vrindavan, most of the garbage
is not collected appropriately. The installation of the public containers in
the main temples generates an improvement for the environment and at the same
time is an educational program for the local inhabitants. 
- 
Recovering areas that represent cultural patrimony for humanity: one of
our initial achievements was to motivate local organizers to recuperate a lake
that had become dump, transforming it into a beautiful park with clean waters. 
- 
Restorations: one of the oldest and most important temples of Vrindavan
(Radha Gopinath Mandir) was in a state of abandonment since the last Muslim invasion.
Currently we have achieved to recuperate two areas and transform them to public
gardens. The project continues to grow and important donations have been
collected for the restoration of the temple.
- 
Posters and art on the streets: some volunteers offer their artistic abilities
through street theatre, posters and murals with ecological messages and
specially developing educational strategies for the issues with plastic use. As
a result from this service from the team of volunteers, we have achieved that
the population feels identified with the seriousness of the environmental
problem and participates actively in the cleanings. 
- 
From plastic to natural: due to the constant flow of pilgrims in the
many temples of the town, in the past years its becoming popular to use plastic
plates leaving aside the traditional practice of organic plates made from palm
leaves as well as mud cups. Through an intense educational campaign in relation
to the harmful effects of plastic, we have now achieved that most temples
return to their traditional use of natural plates. 
No estamos pensando solo en
el beneficio de una eco aldea en particular, pues a través del programa de voluntariado
ya hemos conseguido mejorar las condiciones de vida y
ambientales de la población. Algunos de los proyectos que ya hemos realizado
son:
-  Construcción y
mantenimiento de la escuela Hanuman: A través de las donaciones que hemos
recibido y con la ayuda constante de voluntarios de todo el mundo, construimos
las primeras instalaciones para la escuelita Hanuman, donde más de 30 niños de
la población se reúnen todas las tardes y reciben clases de inglés y
agricultura orgánica. Algunos profesores son pagos con estas donaciones y otros
son parte del equipo de voluntarios. 
-  Limpieza del
Yamuna: que los residuos sólidos plásticos como botellas, bolsas, etc., no
lleguen al rio Yamuna, usando un sistema de rejas instaladas en los desagües de
aguas negras que desembocan en el rio. Diariamente se hace un seguimiento y una
limpieza de más de 15 desagües con un grupo de trabajadores locales y
voluntarios internacionales de la eco aldea. Estos trabajadores también son
pagos con las donaciones recibidas en la eco aldea
-  Instalación de
basureros en lugares importantes de peregrinación: Con los cientos de
peregrinos en Vrindavan, muchas veces se generan basuras que no son
adecuadamente recolectadas. La instalación de estos basureros públicos en los
principales templos genera mejoras en el medio ambiente y es a la vez un
programa educativo para los habitantes locales. 
-  Recuperación de
áreas que son patrimonio cultural de la humanidad: uno de nuestros primeros
logros fue animar a las organizaciones locales para recuperar un lago que se
había convertido en vertedero y transformarlo en un parque muy lindo, con aguas
limpias nuevamente. 
-  Restauraciones:
uno de los templos más antiguos e importantes de Vrindavan (Radha Gopinath
Mandir) se encontraba en un estado de abandono desde la época de la última
invasión musulmana. Actualmente hemos conseguido recuperar dos áreas y transformarlas
en jardines públicos. El proyecto continúa creciendo y se han conseguido
importantes donaciones para la reconstrucción del templo.  
-  Afiches y artes
en las calles: Algunos voluntarios ofrecen sus habilidades artísticas a través
de teatro ambulante, afiches y murales con mensajes ecológicos y especialmente
tratando temáticas educativas al respecto del plástico. Como resultado de este
servicio del equipo de voluntarios, se ha logrando que la población identifique
la gravedad del problema ambiental y participe de las actividades de limpieza
frecuentes. 
-  Del plástico a
lo natural: por el flujo constante de peregrinos en los múltiples templos de la
ciudad, en los últimos años se hizo común el uso de utensilios plástico dejando
de lado el tradicional uso de utensilios orgánicos como platos de hojas de
palma y vasos de arcilla. A través de una intensa campaña educativa acerca de
los peligros del plástico, conseguimos que nuevamente la mayoría de los templos
eviten su consumo. 
The main focus of our services in Vrindavan of education are to local
villagers, aiming that they take individual and collective actions that prevent
the damage caused to the environment in the day to day habits. As a
satisfactory result we have seen growth in the interest of other organizations
such as the Braj Foundation, Food for Life, etc. that are motivated to adopt
these environmental and educational programs. 
El foco principal de nuestros servicios en
Vrindavan en la educación son a los pobladores locales, para conseguir que
tomen acciones individuales y colectivas que eviten el daño causado al medio
ambiente por los hábitos cotidianos. Como resultado satisfactorio hemos visto
el creciente interés que otras agrupaciones tales como Braj Fundation, Food for
Life, etc, tienen por implementar estos proyectos ambientales y educativos. 
Now we want to be an
example so that in the future other communities of the locality substitute the
use of dirty energy for the consumption of clean solar energy, and due to the
trajectory that we have, we are confident that we can achieve our goal thanks
to the support we have from the community, who has seen the positive results
and the improvement of their village with the program. 
Ahora queremos ser un ejemplo para que más adelante
otras comunidades de la localidad substituyan el uso de energías sucias, por el
consumo de energía solar limpia, y debido a toda la trayectoria que tenemos,
estamos seguros de que podemos lograrlo ya que la comunidad en general es muy
favorable a todas nuestras actividades y recomendaciones porque han visto el
impacto positivo y lo que hemos conseguido. 
Risks
and challanges…
Riesgos y desafíos…
In Vrindavan there are a
variety of animals that have learned to coexist with humans. Among them are the
monkeys that wander constantly on the rooftops and could damage the panels. To
prevent this, we are planning to install grids to protect the installation.
En Vrindavan existe una
variedad de animales que se han acostumbrado a coexistir con los
seres humanos, entre ellos los monos que andan constantemente por los tejados,
los cuales podrían dañar los paneles. Para evitarlo, estamos planeando la
instalación de rejas que los protegen de forma adecuada. 
We can be the pioneers in
the installation of solar panels in the city, serving as an example to follow
and we are willing to give total support and consultation to the rest of the
community based on this experience. 
Podemos ser los pioneros en la instalación de
paneles de energía solares en la ciudad, siendo un ejemplo a seguir para lo
cual estaremos dispuestos a prestar todo el apoyo y asesoría a las comunidades,
a partir de esta experiencia. 
Other ways you can help…
Otras
formas en las que puedes ayudar…
You can help us, be part of
the project to change the world step by step, make your contribution with a
donation or sharing the campaign through the networks. From here you can share
this post on Facebook, Twitter and other networks. 
Tú puedes ayudarnos, ser parte de este proyecto
para cambiar el mundo paso a paso, haz tu contribución ya sea a través de una
donación o divulgando nuestro proyecto en las redes sociales. Desde aquí mismo
puedes compartir esta nota en facebook, twtter y otras redes sociales. 
You can also participate as
a volunteer at our organization by contacting our web page 
www.helpinghandforvrindavan.org 
También puedes participar como voluntario en
nuestra organizacion contactando la pagina:www.helpinghandforvrindavan.org

story:
My name is Rachel Walker. I am a sea kayak guide and an outdoor educator on Canada's west coast. This campaign is important to me for obvious reasons. I love my home, my job, the unique culture and all the creatures that thrive here and provide us food and abundance. At low tide, the dinner table is set. Life is simple here. Your contribution, no matter how great or small, will help me directly help the people on the frontline's of the pipeline blockade. 

I've set a modest goal of $5000 but any amount can and will help. Here is a list from   Zoe at wildcoast.ca of what I've been asked to bring if possible:
- Batteries
- Portable power pack
- Small diesel generator
- Chainsaws and chainsaw parts
- Rubbermaid totes
- Home-canned and wild food
- Snow suits
- Cameras

I will happily except any of these items instead of cash! Especially the home canned and wild food, you can't buy that in the store! Which brings us back to the point. We are protecting and conserving unspoiled nature in all it's glory, now and forever, for future generations. No amount of money can replace that. No oil spill is ever fully cleaned up. In fact, in many cases, recovering 10% of spilled oil is considered “successful” and thus could be coined “world class,” but not necessarily “effective.” The province writes: “[Enbridge] acknowledges that it knows of no techniques to effectively remove dissolved oil from the water column. [Enbridge] acknowledges that the fraction of the total oil volume that sinks can exceed 50%,” and “recovery and mitigation options for sunken oils [e.g. weathered bitumen] are limited.”               I encourage you to do your own research, google the Kalamazoo river oil spill. Don't worry if you can't contribute with cash, please take 5 minutes to spread the word and use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you, thank you, THANK YOU!

ourguiderachel@gmail.com

story:
Pleases view my PREZI PRESENTATION for more information!


Short Summary

About 1.3 million breeding pairs of Magellanic penguins live on the coasts of Argentina and Chile. They are classified as a "threatened species" and the population is declining. Threats include oil pollution, overfishing, bycatch, predation, tourism, and climate change. Penguins are adapting to some of these threats but not at a fast enough rate. Such adaptations include expanding foraging distance, adjusting their breeding season, and moving the colony closer to food sources. 

Penguins adapt not only to threats but also to their environment. This species returns to the same breeding ground year after year to mate. While nesting burrows are reused by the same pairs year after year, some may collapse or be vacant due to mortality. Nesting characteristics may lead to competition among individuals trying to breed. This research will allow us to better understand which environmental and physical parameters influence individual aggression among Magellanic penguins. 

I hypothesize that competition between individuals will vary based upon certain parameters. I intend to record the frequency and magnitude of aggressive behavior between penguin individuals and determine if certain factors including nest features, physiological characteristics (weight, height, etc.), and female or chick presence contribute to aggression. Then, I will create population maps for the colony on the peninsula and determine if nest location and density influences competition as well.

What I Need 

I am beginning my postgraduate studies at the University of Lincoln, UK in September, 2014. For my Master's Degree in Ecology, I will travel to Patagonia Argentina for 2-3 weeks in January/February 2015 to study Magellanic penguins. My academic advisor is Dr. Daniel Pincheira-Donoso. In order to study at Lincoln and successfully complete this project, I need money for:

  • Travel
  • Room & Board
  • Experiment Equipment
  • Tuition

Science is an expensive field, specifically as an international Master's student. I am ready to help the penguins, and all I ask is that you support me in this endeavor. 

The Impact

Everybody LOVES penguins! Not only will this research contribute to the knowledge base of Magellanic penguins but it will spread the word about how important a healthy environment is for animal survival. 

About Me

As I flipped through an encyclopedia in elementary school while working on a science project, I became captivated with a black and white photograph of penguins on a sheet of ice. This chance encounter, through only this single photo, and subsequent participation in numerous penguin encounter programs resulted in my ambition and desire to learn as much as possible about these flightless birds, which persists to this day. 

I graduated from Worcester Polytechnic Institute in May 2013 with a Bachelor of Science degree in Biology and Biotechnology and Bachelor of Arts degree in Environmental Studies. Beginning in September 2014, I will attend the University of Lincoln, UK working towards my Master's Degree in Ecology. 

I have traveled abroad previously to Bangkok, Thailand in 2012 studying the heat impacts on the occupational health of agricultural and industrial workers. This project was a collaborative effort by Worcester Polytechnic Institute (WPI), Chulalongkorn University, Thammasat University, and a global study research occupation heat stress. 

In 2012-2013 I completed 2 more biology research projects. At URI, I studied 

the environmental conditions that may promote the formation of a harmful algal bloom of the species Heterosigma akashiwo. At WPI, I researched the interactions between a local Massachusetts freshwater environment and the invasive crayfish species Procambarus clarkii.

For more information about me and my qualifications, please visit www.rphickcox.webs.com. 

Ways You Can Help

It is my dream to study penguins, but I need YOUR help to do so! Please consider donating any amount of money to my campaign. If you are unable to do so, you can still help! Please forward this campaign link to anyone and everyone you know. Every little bit helps! You can also use the Indiegogo share tools.

story:
"This vanishing world is beautiful beyond our dreams and contains in itself rewards and gratifications never found in artificial landscape, or man-made objects” - Olegas Truchanas

I am incredibly excited to be a part of this expedition to save the Rio Marañon. I am donating my own time and money to make this expedition happen, but I will also need your help to make this project a reality; all contributions will go towards covering project costs.

Short Summary

Rio Marañon is incredibly important. Both socially and environmentally, it is the hydrological source of the Amazon. It is the lifeblood which supports thousands of unique communities and cultures along with an astounding number of diverse ecosystems. Unfortunately there are dozens of dams planned along this stretch of river which threaten to destroy the habitats both at the site and downstream.  

There is growing ecotourism in this area. Currently the river exists in a free-flowing state, and more and more people want to see ‘The Grand Canyon of South America’ before it is destroyed. Our goal is to connect local communities with this growing ecotourism. If we can create more forms of sustainable income there will bee more reasons to keep this river free flowing. 

As part of the Paddling with Purpose project, we are inviting between six and ten Peruvians to join us on a 17 day expedition. These young people will be from the dam affected communities of Menden and Tupen. Along the way we will teach basic whitewater skills and trade understanding of how these dams will change the communities and ecosystems. The skills we share will open up new pathways to becoming professional guides in the future.

Another way communities can profit from tourism is through selling food or goods. Instead of packing all of our food ahead of time we are planning to stop at many of these villages and buy fruit, or other types of food. When enough people start coming down this river providing logistical support to raft groups can become a viable source of income.

                     

This expedition will result in:    

  1. Stronger networks between dam effected communities, and the rest of Peru.
  2. A group of local people with basic whitewater skills. If they are interested in developing these further to become professional guides, we will facilitate this.
  3. The creation of new pathways for local people to become involved in the growing tourism and rafting industry on this river.
  4. A heightened environmental awareness in our group of participants, and for those we meet along the way.
The Paddling with Purpose project is also running an advocacy campaign on a national level. This project is just one part of a larger plan to engage communities, and organize opposition to the proposed dam construction.

A Little About Me       

I have had the blessing to grow up in an extremely adventurous family. My first camping trip I was three months old, and my first backpacking trip I was sixteen months old. Over the course of my life my love for adventure has only increased. In 2010 I got my first taste of raft guiding, since then I have logged over 300 river trips and thousands of river miles. Through raft guiding I have developed a love of sharing the outdoors with people. I find true happiness when I can share new and exciting experiences with others. 


This project combines two of my favorite things, education and the outdoors. I love sleeping by the river and moving at a more natural pace, and I am so stoked to get away from city life and to really feel like I am contributing to a better world. This expedition will be the greatest adventure in my life so far. I cannot wait to share this place with my teammates and the local peoples of the Marañon. 

What We Need 

These are the costs for the entire expedition:

Broad Cost Breakdown:
Equipment Hire $4,000
Transport $3,000
Food $2,000    
I am part of a small group of volunteers who are working hard to make this journey happen. Together, we need to raise a minimum target of $9,000. This amount will allow us to invite six Peruvian participants. if we can raise more money, then we will have more flexibility in the program and the ability to invite more participants.

Challenges 

1. Safety

  • We will make sure that safety is a large part of every day life. When out in the middle of Peru even a broken ankle can prove to be disastrous. We will utilize normal first aid risk management, and have access to a satellite phone if need be. 
  • On the river we plan to teach participants rescue and whitewater safety techniques from day one.
  • Teaching whitewater skills anywhere can be challenging, that is why our participants will ride in a guided raft through difficult sections. The participants training will begin on mellower sections of the river.
  • We have a high ratio of experienced river guides to unskilled participants. The ratio will not exceed two participants to one guide but more likely will be closer to a one to one ratio.
2. Language Barrier 
  • Some of us speak spanish, but not all. Our team of guides are from Peru, and international; we will rely on the Spanish speaking guides to most of the explaining, while others will play a large role in safety and demonstration.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this Link! It's perfectly alright if you are unable to contribute at this time, but please let others know about both this site and why they should help. 
Thank you!

Questions?

For more information please visit paddlingwithpurpose.com
Feel free to email me your questions at loslarson17@gmail.com
story_txt:
"This vanishing world is beautiful beyond our dreams and contains in itself rewards and gratifications never found in artificial landscape, or man-made objects” - Olegas Truchanas



I am incredibly excited to be a part of this expedition to save the Rio Marañon. I am donating my own time and money to make this expedition happen, but I will also need your help to make this project a reality; all contributions will go towards covering project costs.

Short SummaryRio Marañon is incredibly important. Both socially and environmentally, it is the hydrological source of the Amazon. It is the lifeblood which supports thousands of unique communities and cultures along with an astounding number of diverse ecosystems. Unfortunately there are dozens of dams planned along this stretch of river which threaten to destroy the habitats both at the site and downstream.  

There is growing ecotourism in this area. Currently the river exists in a free-flowing state, and more and more people want to see ‘The Grand Canyon of South America’ before it is destroyed. Our goal is to connect local communities with this growing ecotourism. If we can create more forms of sustainable income there will bee more reasons to keep this river free flowing. 


As part of the Paddling with Purpose project, we are inviting between six and ten Peruvians to join us on a 17 day expedition. These young people will be from the dam affected communities of Menden and Tupen. Along the way we will teach basic whitewater skills and trade understanding of how these dams will change the communities and ecosystems. The skills we share will open up new pathways to becoming professional guides in the future.

Another way communities can profit from tourism is through selling food or goods. Instead of packing all of our food ahead of time we are planning to stop at many of these villages and buy fruit, or other types of food. When enough people start coming down this river providing logistical support to raft groups can become a viable source of income.


                     

This expedition will result in:    


Stronger networks between dam effected communities, and the rest of Peru.
A group of local people with basic whitewater skills. If they are interested in developing these further to become professional guides, we will facilitate this.
The creation of new pathways for local people to become involved in the growing tourism and rafting industry on this river.
A heightened environmental awareness in our group of participants, and for those we meet along the way.

The Paddling with Purpose project is also running an advocacy campaign on a national level. This project is just one part of a larger plan to engage communities, and organize opposition to the proposed dam construction.



A Little About Me       


I have had the blessing to grow up in an extremely adventurous family. My first camping trip I was three months old, and my first backpacking trip I was sixteen months old. Over the course of my life my love for adventure has only increased. In 2010 I got my first taste of raft guiding, since then I have logged over 300 river trips and thousands of river miles. Through raft guiding I have developed a love of sharing the outdoors with people. I find true happiness when I can share new and exciting experiences with others. 

This project combines two of my favorite things, education and the outdoors. I love sleeping by the river and moving at a more natural pace, and I am so stoked to get away from city life and to really feel like I am contributing to a better world. This expedition will be the greatest adventure in my life so far. I cannot wait to share this place with my teammates and the local peoples of the Marañon. 
   What We Need 
These are the costs for the entire expedition:
 

Broad Cost Breakdown:

Equipment Hire
$4,000


Transport
$3,000


Food
$2,000    


I am part of a small group of volunteers who are working hard to make this journey happen. Together, we need to raise a minimum target of $9,000. This amount will allow us to invite six Peruvian participants. if we can raise more money, then we will have more flexibility in the program and the ability to invite more participants.
Challenges 
1. Safety



We will make sure that safety is a large part of every day life. When out in the middle of Peru even a broken ankle can prove to be disastrous. We will utilize normal first aid risk management, and have access to a satellite phone if need be. 
On the river we plan to teach participants rescue and whitewater safety techniques from day one.
Teaching whitewater skills anywhere can be challenging, that is why our participants will ride in a guided raft through difficult sections. The participants training will begin on mellower sections of the river.
We have a high ratio of experienced river guides to unskilled participants. The ratio will not exceed two participants to one guide but more likely will be closer to a one to one ratio.

2. Language Barrier 

Some of us speak spanish, but not all. Our team of guides are from Peru, and international; we will rely on the Spanish speaking guides to most of the explaining, while others will play a large role in safety and demonstration.

Other Ways You Can Help


Share this Link! It's perfectly alright if you are unable to contribute at this time, but please let others know about both this site and why they should help. 
Thank you! Questions?
For more information please visit paddlingwithpurpose.com

Feel free to email me your questions at loslarson17@gmail.com

story:
Perchè un video?

Il trailer del TEDx Verona dello scorso anno, girato con la tecnica dei droni, ha riscosso un grande successo di pubblico, entusiasmo e orgoglio cittadino. Unendo le competenze di TEDx Verona, TEDx TorVergataU, Legambiente e l'estro artistico di Roberto Mettifogo, vogliamo creare un mix originale e regalare alla città e a tutti i suoi cittadini un nuovo video. Questa volta però ci concentreremo su un soggetto di inestimabile valore seppur poco noto: il parco delle Mura e dei Forti di Verona. 


Di cosa abbiamo bisogno e cosa riceverete:

Il nostro obiettivo sono 5.000 €, necessari a coprire i costi della realizzazione del video. Contiamo però di superare questa soglia per utilizzare tecniche e attrezzature più sofisticate per poter registrare un filmato ancor più entusiasmante.

In cambio delle vostre offerte abbiamo previsto un sistema di "ricompense", che variano in base all'entità dell'offerta. Un esempio? Avrete la possibilità di trascorrere una esclusiva serata in uno dei bastioni del parco cenando in compagnia della storia (e della persona che porterete!).

Il parco delle Mura e dei Forti di Verona

Il parco delle Mura e dei Forti racchiude la storia di Verona. Qui potete osservare come le differenti dominazioni della città abbiamo cambiato il modo di costruire e di difendere la stessa. Dalle mura scaligere in ciottoli e mattoni del 1300 fino a quelle austriache del 1800 passano 500 e più anni della storia di questa città. Pochi sono i luoghi al mondo che possiedono un tale fascino.

Altri modi in cui puoi aiutarci

Alcune persone semplicemente non possono contribuire, ma questo non vuol dire che non possano aiutare. In particolare potete:

  • Diffondere la campagna, possibilmente di persona e con i propri amici
  • Condividere la stessa con gli strumenti offerti qui da Indiegogo

story:
Taganga is a 400 year old fishing village in the rural area of Santa Marta on the Atlantic Coast of Colombia. Its people are descendants of indigenous tribes that have supported themselves over the last three centuries with a skilled, social fishing technique called "Chinchorro".


The village is nestled in a mountain that juts into the calm and tranquil sea. The whole area is surrounded by a vast expanse of tropical dry forest on the mainland and the coral reef ecosystem longshore.
Tourism and migration, which the local people do not have access to, have developed rapidly in the last decade, to the detriment of the traditional activities of a small fishing village which has generated a number of ecological and social problems. Rapid and uncontrolled coastal development, one of the major causes of reef degradation worldwide, has resulted in more difficulties for this fishing community, including the ability to sustain itself. 


This campaign includes the planning and evaluation of educational activities that involve the community in the conservation projects that connect tourism operators with local technicians in new ways of reef conservation.


FUNDING WHAT ?


Your money pays for education, dive training and direct costs required to Restore a Piece of a Reef Right now.  We have volunteers, from youth in Taganga to international, professional technicians, but we need your help to do it right...to do it safely.  


" You must be the change you wish to see in the world "


Check on our website for more information.

story:
Mindful Art Activism for the Environment 

Your funding will support art-activism to transform burying trash in the environment into creative, neighborhood activity. Your contributions of even $5 will support a focused group of citizens looking for specific actions to prevent glass, and other resources, from being trashed. Residents of remote and wildly beautiful Upper Michigan will work with artists from City Meditation Crew, a fictitious government department, to end current habits of throwing glass, and other refuse, into the garbage. We will develop practical conservation practices: less use, reuse, and recyling. In summer 2014, City Meditaiton Crew will make a symbolic, days-long walk to the nearest recycling station to inspire solid, repeatable local change.

What We Need & What You Get

The possibilities are broad when potlucks are involved. Scientists, nurses, artists, teachers, gardeners, engineers, moms, and others will work together to explore small but powerful actions: perhaps we will establish a way to convert glass bottles into material the community garden can use; we have already begun looking to transform refuse into functional art; we might coodinate a recycle-ride-share system to combine routine trips to urban areas with recycling drop-offs for everyone on our block...new ideas will emerge as we gather and brainstorm. We will make our art actions and community building experiments available to other communities with similar needs through our networks and the internet. 

Perhaps you will find some simple ideas to inspire you to conserve a little more, or take big action.

We need seed money of $1000 to fund carts for collecting glass and tools to transform trashed glass into useful material. For the long sybolic walk, we will need uniforms, lodging and transportation, and support for our media campaign to get the word out about our conservation and art actions.

For $5 we will invite you to our blog and keep you updated on our progress.

For $100 we will send you an art work from the project:a suite of digital images of City Meditation Crew to use as a screen saver and reminder of how attention to consumption, one moment at a time, can foster connectedness with your community. 

A large number of small donations will position us to apply for grant funding.

The Impact: Community Building, Education on Conservation Practices, Art as Action

Creatvity replaces over consumption. Potlucks with zero waste build excellent habits. Living rooms beome incubators. Parents model good conservation practices for children, and vice versa. Science and art-actions unite neighbors in protecting the earth. Everyone on our block brings something to the process. Small steps add up to waves of influence and change.

We understand that some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

Spread the word. Encourage just one or two friends to take a look at City Meditation Crew's webisite www.citymeditationcrew.org  for inspiration to be present, consume less, use and reuse wisely, and connect with other beings and the earth, one moment at a time.

story:
Sunny the Sea Turtle

My name is Sandi White and I write children's books to teach kids about the world around us.  After an eye-opening trip to Fort Myers Beach, Florida, I wanted to spread the word about sea turtles and how they need our help.  

The schools in Michigan (and probably lots of other places) don't teach kids anything about sea turtles, so I wrote a fun, rhyming story about a sea turtle who hatches out of his egg and then gets distracted by the bright lights on the beach, and ends up going towards the city instead of the Gulf.  I started this campaign so I can get illustrations created for the book, as well as get the first printings done.  Once the book is complete, a portion of the proceeds will go to organizations who help and protect sea turtles and their nests, as well as rehabilitate injured turtles.  

Turtles are important to the ecosystem of the ocean, and I think it's crucial that kids understand that what they do when they're on the beach can impact sea turtles.

My daughter and I also wrote a song to go along with the book, in the hopes that it will remind them  that sea turtles need our help.  

The money will go towards the following:

  • An illustrator to draw all of the pictures that will go in the book
  • Printing costs
  • Obtaining an ISBN number, so the book can be sold through retailers

In the event I don't reach the goal amount, I plan to continue with various fundraisers until this book becomes a reality.  I have set a 30-day limit for this fundraiser because I already have an awesome illustrator lined up, and I want to get her going on this project before she gets too busy with other projects and can't do this.  Hopefully, I will raise enough money to at least pay for the first few illustrations, which will at least get things rolling.  

This project means a lot to me because our beaches and oceans have become so polluted these days.  As humans, we impact the ocean in a lot of ways, whether it's leaving trash on the beach, dumping sewage into the water, oil spills, or simply having bright lights on the beach that cause hatchlings to go in the wrong direction.  We all need to do our part to help sea turtles so our children can enjoy all the wonderful nature the universe has provided us.  
This is my third children's book, but this one is completely different from the other books that I've written because this one holds special memories I shared with my family and will benefit wonderful organizations like Turtle Time, a group based in Fort Myers Beach, Florida.
  • Risks & Challenges
  • The illustrator may not be available, which would mean searching for someone else
  • Not raising enough money with this fundraiser, which would mean delays of several months to a year in getting the book in the hands of kids.  

Other Ways You Can Help

I realize you may be one of the many people who are having a tough time financially these days, but there are still ways you can help.  Please share this fundraiser page with your friends and family.  Please check out the gifts that are available for various donation amounts.  I really appreciate you, and I know the turtles will, too.  

If you'd like to be kept up-to-date on the fundraiser, the book and any future projects, check out my website at www.SandiWhite.com.  You can also "Like" my Facebook page, www.Facebook.com/AuthorSandiWhite, or "Follow" me on Twitter at www.Twitter.com/SeaTurtleSunny.

The goal of this campaign is to get the Open Letter published as a full-page ad in The Wall Street Journal.

Read the Open Letter »

The letter has already been approved by The Journal as well as several major papers’ advertising review boards.

All that remains is for people like you to pitch in and help us get this letter in front of the eyes of millions – energizing the conversation about climate change and reframing it as the moral crisis it truly is.

 

More about the campaign Open Letter FAQs

story:
Short Summary

Roy Harker is the Executive Director of the Association of Gay & Lesbian Psychiatrists (aglp.org).  He has done amazing work for our organization over the years, as I can say from personal experience as a Past President of AGLP.  He and Bob have opened their home numerous times for AGLP members and functions.  Now it's time to give back to him and say thank you!

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising $5000 or more to celebrate Roy and Bob's 25th anniversary and let them go on a honeymoon to a place of their choosing.  We don't know if they will be able to get legally married in Pennsylvania by April 2014, but 25 years is worth a big trip in any case!
You will be acknowledged for your gift in the card that will go to Roy and Bob, and will be eligible for a commemorative wristband and/or photo magnet at higher giving levels.  

The Impact

Recognizing and celebrating relationship milestones for gay couples is vitally important.  This gift will be a real demonstration of our thanks for Roy's long service to AGLP and friendship to many of us.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word to anyone you think will want to help!

story:
Campaign Update:

We have reached the lower end of our goal $15,000. However, we are hoping you can help us push it past $20,000! 
Why do we need more? 
We have acquired enough material for a short film but need more money to make it longer and to distribute the film to more communities in Madagascar. 
What have we done so far? 
We filmed enough footage for a roughly 10 min conservation education film. Our on the ground team has trained 24 community members to help monitor forests to protect them from fire. We have also cut over 6 km (4 miles) of fire breaks protecting over 350 ha (nearly 900 acres) of fragmented forest which buffers a large tract of continuous forest. 
What is our plan?
We plan to go back to Madagascar to film more about the project in late October - the peak of the dry season. We will then edit and make the longer film closer to 22 min in the new year. Once edited we will distribute the film to all the communities within Ankarafantsika National Park. We will literally take an ox cart, generator, projector and screen and we will show the film to communities where fires threaten forests. Also as we describe below we will distribute the film to our partners, for viewing in other regions. Finally, we plan to air this film on Malagasy television, to increase its reach and impact. 

Who we are: 

We are Planet Madagascar. We are passionate about Madagascar, its people, and its wildlife. Planet Madagascar is a conservation, education, and community development project, aiming to promote lemur species conservation by building local capacity in communities in Northwest Madagascar.

What we want:

We want to work with local communities in Madagascar to stop fires from destroying lemur habitat.  

Why it matters:

Lemurs are the most endangered mammal group in the world and are found only in Madagascar. 94% of lemur species are threatened with extinction, largely due to the fact that the forest habitats that they call home are rapidly disappearing at the hands of humans.

But it’s complicated: 92% of the people in Madagascar live on less than $2 a day and their survival is intrinsically linked to the exploitation of natural resources. The need for lemur conservation and community development in Madagascar has never been so great.

Urgency:

As you read this, forest is catching fire in Madagascar and lemur habitat is disappearing. Community involvement, education, and direct financial incentives are needed if the lemurs and the remaining forest are to be protected in one of the world’s poorest countries.

How we want to help:

We want to create a powerful film to educate people in Madagascar about how fire is destroying lemur habitat and what they can do to help prevent fire. The film will highlight fire management solutions that our organization, in partnership with local communities, plans to implement. Our broader goal is to find ways of helping people improve their livelihoods while saving lemurs and their habitat.

The ask:

We need your help raising money to make a compelling educational film. We need funds to cover the costs of filming and editing.

The film:

Our film will make a vital contribution towards community involvement and education, by highlighting issues surrounding human-wildlife interactions in Madagascar and illustrating why a healthy ecosystem is beneficial to both humans and wildlife.  The film will be used as an educational tool to empower local communities to prevent fires from destroying lemur habitat.

Madagascar is one of the world’s "hottest" biodiversity hotspots, which means it is home to an extraordinarily high number of species that are found nowhere else in the world. The International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) estimates that 94% of lemur species—all of which are found only in Madagascar— are threatened with extinction, due to human-induced habitat disturbance. Uncontrolled fires play a major role in the loss of lemur habitat in Madagascar.

Unfortunately, Madagascar also suffers from immense poverty, and people often exploit the habitat simply to feed their families. The habitat needed by lemurs is also needed for people. Community involvement, education, and direct financial benefits are needed if the lemurs and the remaining forest are to be protected in one of the world’s poorest countries. 

Meet Mamy Razafitsalama:

Mamy Razafitsalama will be the host of our film. Mamy is a trilingual Malagasy primatologist, who works tirelessly to save the planet's most endangered mammal—the lemur—in one of the world’s most fragile forests. Mamy grew up in a tiny village in eastern Madagascar. As a child, he fell in love with lemurs. His parents—a teacher and school principal—valued education. Mamy studied hard and successfully finished a BSc and DEA (similar to a Master’s) at the University of Antananarivo. Mamy has become a local star in the world of lemur science and conservation in Madagascar.

Mamy helped start the in-country wing of Planet Madagascar, and he currently runs all of our projects in Madagascar. The film will follow Mamy as he works to find practical solutions to conservation issues affecting both lemurs and people. 

How we'll use this film:

We will screen this film in remote, forest-dependent communities in Madagascar. Mamy is running our educational programme on the ground in Madagascar right now. We want to produce this film and provide it to Mamy to use as an educational tool as soon as we can. The film will help local Malagasy communities recognize how their actions have direct impacts on the surrounding wildlife—and ultimately their own livelihoods —and hopefully will inspire them make changes that will benefit both their quality of life and surrounding ecosystems. We will also distribute the film to our partners, for viewing in other regions. Finally, we plan to air this film on Malagasy television, to increase its reach and impact. 

How the money will be spent:

Planet Madagascar has partnered with Chris Scarffe, a renowned, independent, environmental filmmaker who specializes in wildlife, conservation, and community films. We estimate that to make this engaging and inspirational film, we need somewhere between $15,000 and $20,000 to cover production costs. All additional money raised will be fed directly into Planet Madagascar’s work on the ground in Madagascar.

Risks & Challenges

Working in Madagascar is not easy. There are language barriers, transportation challenges, and political issues. Our Planet Madagascar team members have worked in conservation, education, and research since 2007. We have established a formal partnership with Madagascar National Parks and we work closely with our on-the-ground partner, Durrell Wildlife Conservation Trust. Our biggest asset in our fight to help people and wildlife is Mamy Razafitsalama. His tireless efforts astound and inspire us. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We realize that some of you just can't contribute financially, but that doesn't mean you can't help. Here are some other ways that you can help us achieve our goals:

  • Share this campaign with your friends and family.
  • Like us on Facebook (www.facebook.com/PlanetMadagascar).
  • Follow us on Twitter (www.twitter.com/PlanetMada).
  • Check out our website to learn more (www.planetmadagascar.com).
story_txt:
Campaign Update:
We have reached the lower end of our goal $15,000. However, we are hoping you can help us push it past $20,000! 

Why do we need more? 
We have acquired enough material for a short film but need more money to make it longer and to distribute the film to more communities in Madagascar. 
What have we done so far? 
We filmed enough footage for a roughly 10 min conservation education film. Our on the ground team has trained 24 community members to help monitor forests to protect them from fire. We have also cut over 6 km (4 miles) of fire breaks protecting over 350 ha (nearly 900 acres) of fragmented forest which buffers a large tract of continuous forest. 
What is our plan?
We plan to go back to Madagascar to film more about the project in late October - the peak of the dry season. We will then edit and make the longer film closer to 22 min in the new year. Once edited we will distribute the film to all the communities within Ankarafantsika National Park. We will literally take an ox cart, generator, projector and screen and we will show the film to communities where fires threaten forests. Also as we describe below we will distribute the film to our partners, for viewing in other regions. Finally, we plan to air this film on Malagasy television, to increase its reach and impact. 
Who we are: 
We are Planet Madagascar. We are passionate about Madagascar, its people, and its wildlife. Planet Madagascar is a conservation,
education, and community development project, aiming to promote lemur species
conservation by building local capacity in communities in Northwest Madagascar.









What we want:
We want to work with local communities in Madagascar to stop fires from destroying lemur habitat.  

Why it matters:



Lemurs
are the most endangered mammal group in the world and are found only in Madagascar. 94% of lemur species are threatened with extinction, largely due to
the fact that the forest habitats that they call home are rapidly disappearing at
the hands of humans.
But it’s
complicated: 92% of the people in Madagascar live on less than $2 a day and
their survival is intrinsically linked to the exploitation of natural
resources. The need for lemur conservation and community development in
Madagascar has never been so great.


Urgency:
As you read this, forest is catching fire
in Madagascar and lemur habitat is disappearing. Community involvement,
education, and direct financial incentives are needed if the lemurs and the
remaining forest are to be protected in one of the world’s poorest countries.
How we want to help:
We want to create a powerful film to educate people in Madagascar
about how fire is destroying lemur habitat and what they can do to help prevent fire. The film will highlight fire management solutions that our
organization, in partnership with local communities, plans to implement. Our broader goal is to find ways of helping people improve their livelihoods while saving lemurs and their habitat.


The ask:
We need your help raising money to make a
compelling educational film. We need funds to cover the costs of filming and editing.




The film:



Our film will make a vital contribution towards community involvement and education, by highlighting issues surrounding human-wildlife interactions in Madagascar and illustrating why a healthy ecosystem is beneficial to both humans and wildlife.  The film will be used as an educational tool to empower local communities to prevent fires from destroying lemur habitat.
Madagascar
is one of the world’s "hottest" biodiversity hotspots, which means it is home
to an extraordinarily high number of species that are found nowhere else in the
world. The International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) estimates that
94% of lemur species—all of which are found only in Madagascar— are threatened
with extinction, due to human-induced habitat disturbance. Uncontrolled fires play a major
role in the loss of lemur habitat in Madagascar. 
Unfortunately,
Madagascar also suffers from immense poverty, and people often exploit the
habitat simply to feed their families. The habitat needed by lemurs is also needed for people. Community involvement, education, and direct
financial benefits are needed if the lemurs and the remaining forest are to be
protected in one of the world’s poorest countries. 





Meet Mamy Razafitsalama:


Mamy Razafitsalama will be the host of our film. Mamy is a trilingual Malagasy
primatologist, who works tirelessly to save the planet's most endangered mammal—the
lemur—in one of the world’s most fragile forests. Mamy grew up in a tiny village in eastern
Madagascar. As a child, he fell in love with lemurs. His parents—a teacher
and school principal—valued education. Mamy studied hard and successfully
finished a BSc and DEA (similar to a Master’s) at the University of
Antananarivo. Mamy has become a local star in the world of lemur science and conservation in Madagascar.Mamy helped start the
in-country wing of Planet Madagascar, and he currently runs all of our projects
in Madagascar. The film will follow Mamy as he works to find practical solutions
to conservation issues affecting both lemurs and people.    How we'll use this film:



We will screen this film in remote, forest-dependent communities in
Madagascar. Mamy is running our educational programme on the ground in
Madagascar right now. We want to produce this film and provide it to Mamy to
use as an educational tool as soon as we can. The film will help local
Malagasy communities recognize how their actions have direct impacts on the
surrounding wildlife—and ultimately their own livelihoods —and hopefully will inspire them
make changes that will benefit both their quality of life and surrounding
ecosystems. We will also distribute the film to our partners, for viewing in
other regions. Finally, we plan to air this film on Malagasy television, to
increase its reach and impact. 






How the money will be spent: 


Planet
Madagascar has partnered with Chris Scarffe, a renowned, independent,
environmental filmmaker who specializes in wildlife, conservation, and
community films. We estimate that to make
this engaging and inspirational film, we need somewhere between $15,000 and
$20,000 to cover production costs. All additional money raised will be fed
directly into Planet Madagascar’s work on the ground in Madagascar.






Risks & Challenges  Working in Madagascar is not easy. There are language barriers, transportation challenges, and political issues. Our Planet Madagascar team members have worked in conservation, education, and research since 2007. We have established a formal partnership with Madagascar National Parks and we work closely with our on-the-ground partner, Durrell Wildlife Conservation Trust. Our biggest asset in our fight to help people and wildlife is Mamy Razafitsalama. His tireless efforts astound and inspire us.

story:
About me and my project

My name is Filippo Marolla, I am an italian student currently attending the last year of the Master degree course in Ecobiology at the University of Rome La Sapienza. I am carrying out a research on African Grey Parrot Psittacus erithacus in the small (136 km2) island of Príncipe in the Gulf of Guinea.

The African Grey Parrot (henceforth "AGP") is one of the most popular avian pets due to its longevity and mimicry ability. AGP is the object of a US$18 million/year trade business, which takes tens of thousands of individuals from the wild. This massive harvest all along its geographical range (see picture below) is considered, together with habitat loss, the main cause of this species decline. AGP is currently defined "Vulnerable" species by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN).

Scientific evidence is always the basis on which to build and implement endangered species conservation programmes. Even if the Grey Parrot's in-captivity behaviour is well known, few studies about its ecology in the wild are available. Fundamental measures like population size and density are missing for most populations, habitat requirements are almost unknown and harvest of individuals from the wild has been seldom assessed in a reliable way.

Príncipe is an heavenly island designated as Biosphere Reserve by UNESCO. It is home to a large population of AGP with a recently estimated density of about 50 birds km-2, which means the highest density in the entire AGP distribution range. As the island is so small, it can be considered like an open-air lab, offering a unique opportunity to study unknown population dynamics of this endangered species. 

The aim of my Master thesis research is to test the reliability and the feasibility of new methods to estimate density and age ratio of African Grey Parrot populations, in order to identify new widely usable tools for their conservation.

This work is a part of the largest Simon Valle's PhD project named “Population viability and conservation of African Grey Parrots on the island of Príncipe, Gulf of Guinea”. Simon Valle is a PhD student at the Division of Biology & Conservation Ecology of the Manchester Metropolitan University.

The objective of the whole project is to provide reliable scientific data to develop conservation plans for African Grey Parrot in Príncipe and elsewhere. 


Why do I need your help

I am about to come back to Principe for the third fieldwork season, which will start in Agust 2014, and I will spend there at least two months.

As you can imagine, the trip from Europe is not cheap at all. Direct flights from Lisbon leave a few times weekly to Sao Tomè, and only one small charter flight can take you once a day from Sao Tomè to Principe. I need about 1400$ to pay the trip.

Moreover, to move from a place to another in Principe is absolutely not easy.  There are no public transports. Renting a motorbike is not recommended, as roads are not paved and can get very muddy and dangerous after rains. Renting a truck is definitely too expensive. The quickest and cheapest way to move in Principe is to take a lift from "motocarros" - locals who own a motorbike. They are used to drive on dirt patch with every weather condition and they know what to do in case of breakdown of the vehicle. I need about 400$ to pay motorbike lifts during my staying.

If you will help me, you will take your chance to make something really practical and useful for Grey Parrot conservation. I really believe in the forcefulness of this project, otherwise I would not have been asking for fundings (I would have preferred to leave money to other more valuable projects).

My hope is that this project will pave the way to increase control on parrots harvest in Principe. Although it does not seem to affect the population, it feeds an illegal trade managed by unethical people. Poachers in Principe use to catch chicks from nests, dangerously climbing up high trees, and they sell parrots for about 11$. The same harvested parrots will be sold somewhere far from Principe for about 700$. NOT ONLY PARROTS ARE CHEATED, BUT LOCAL PEOPLE TOO!! Hence, our second difficult goal is to involve local authorities and people - farmers, workers, students - in the project, making them aware about how big the trade is and about the importance of Principe Grey Parrot population survival.

In this way, the island of Principe could turn out to be a real model of sustainable management of wildlife, and other countries could follow its example.

Since I earn nothing from this work, I will be not able to get money perks in return to you. If you will support me, I would love to send you as a little present all the best pictures I will take of parrots, Principe landscapes and other endemic birds and to update you about how the work is going on. You will also receive a digital copy of any paper i will publish after coming back to Italy.

Thank you!

Filippo Marolla

story:
Hello everyone,

I am volunteering in Lebanon with Salam LADC, an NGO that helps vulnerable people in the Beqaa Valley. Many Syrian refugees struggle daily to get food, especially in the wintertime when most of their income goes on fuel and warm clothing.

That's why I want to start a new project, called The Greenhouse Project. The Greenhouse Project will enable 7 Syrian families (18 adults and 22 children) from a small settlement to grow their own vegetables throughout the whole year, including the winter months. The people in this settlement live a basic lifestyle in self-made tents and cook over open fires and since they are living in a remote area, the kids don’t have access to school or other services. The settlement is located next to a clean river from which we will pump water for the greenhouse. In collaboration with organisation  Arcenciel, we also want to share knowledge about organic farming so that they can grow their vegetables in an eco-friendly way. 

However, building a greenhouse and the water facilitation (water tank, water pump, pipes) cost money and I therefore would like to ask for your support. It would be amazing if you could contribute to this project so that we can get started in time for winter!

Thanks in advance!

Anno
