story:
The Essentials

These are the quick and dirty details of my adventure.

At the end of August, I will leave for Northern Washington. I'll be solo hiking for 28-32 days Southbound on the Pacific Crest Trail (Rainy Pass to Forest Road 23), totaling 361 Miles. I'm hoping to keep the trip to 3 re-supplies along the route.

This crowdfunding campaign was inspired after conversations with several of you about how you could support my trip and my practical realization of how much food I will need to purchase, prepare, pack, and carry to fuel my way.

Contributions will be used to purchase: food for all of my meals, any remaining gear costs, postage costs to get my supply boxes to my pickup locations, and a potential splurge meal and hot shower during resupplies. If there are funds remaining, I am inspired to add them to my seed fund for a small business that is just beginning to sprout in its planning stage. I am excited to share more about this through updates in the coming weeks! This has been a huge next step that has been inspired by the process of planning/preparing for this PCT adventure.

Other ways to support & connect:

  • Sign up to receive updates from my campaign. This way I can let you know how to follow my adventure. *You can do this without donating funds.
  • Join me in this playful food challenge!
    • Share your tips! I eat fresh, nutrient dense foods daily. How the heck will I eat (and carry) the daily calories I need for this type of trek without leaning into a common backpackers diet of snickers, instant mashed potatoes, and buckets of trail mix? Share your tips (and recipes) about nutrient-dense, light weight foods that are non-perishable.
    • Make a goody box. If you have favorite trail snacks and feel inspired mail some my way, I will happily add them to the beginnings of my food boxes. Also know, if it is something I can get locally, just send your suggestion and I can track it down here.
    • **Note: I'll be happy to share my current menu plan in a future update. 
  • Get out to your local trails. Find a new trail or a new trail hiking buddy. Learn a new plant by name. Learn a new story about a place you have been a million times. Be curious!
  • Check out the gallery of photos on this site. I posted my favorite pictures from my solo and group hikes over the last 3-months. 
  • If you are a Pacific Northwest local or might be in the area late August-September, let me know. Anyone who feels called to join me on the trail for a night or weekend is welcome at my campfire!

Questions, inspirations, curiosities? I'm here: beauty.of.peace@gmail.com

 

Why Backpacking? And for 30 days?!

It was mid-January. The neighborhood streets of Portland were full of neighbors grumbling about shoveling snow while kids were still elated by the unexpected ability to build snow people, huge snow forts, and sled in the local park. In this true feeling of winter, I felt a great hunger for beginning something new that was creative and challenged me. Something that would help me see myself with a new lens, in a new space of confidence and clarity about my purpose and direction.

I chose the PCT. 

Exercise has always been an important part of my mental health. I don't know about you, but I definitely have a wild bunch of monkeys who love the landscape of my mind and cause major damage if I am not mindful. When I exercise, I feel like the monkeys are the ones that exercise and then they get tired and I experience my clear sight and mind...and find a closer sense of connection to myself. Backpacking has been an amazing way to move my body and immerse myself in lands that I love. All this felt perfect for me. 

Then, my dad sent me these photos of himself at age 23. He was stationed at the Air Force Base in Phoenix, Arizona at the time. This was a trip of his to the Grand Canyon. I got chills looking at them. A chord sung inside me. Family medicine and passions sometimes share the same well. 

As my PCT planning continued, I was pulled to revisit memories of previous backpacking trips over the years. In doing so, I found these pictures -- along with a renewed sense of awe and gratitude for my parents taking us on this adventure-- of our family backpacking trip down to Havasupai Falls. Seriously!

My good friend Robert came with us as Nathan chose to stay home. I still get teased about how we carrying our AP Calculus book back and forth in our backpacks so we could do homework on the trail...which I don't actually remember happening. 

Besides weekend trips with friends and partners, my most recent backpacking adventure was my two months in India with Sierra Institute for a Himalayan backpacking field study program in 2005. An incredible opportunity, our studies focused on the geology, natural history and sustainable development initiatives within Ladakh (Northen India). My friend Greta and I did our research on gender and women's access to professional and educational opportunities. We met some amazing women! Climbing peaks and passes over 17,000 ft "topped off" the experience.​

Remembering these stories has helped me realize something. That being out on the trail has always been a part of how I have moved in my life. It has always been a part of what I imagined was possible for me. And as a woman prone to ritual, being on the trail has been a tool for me to honor my own transformation or to hold a question in prayer and know that by the time I step off the trail, something new will be planted within me or something released to the wind. 

When I started planning this trip, I imagined that this would be my big adventure for the year. Standing here in the middle of July, this no longer feels true. This adventure has merely become one of many. I'm back in an academic adventure at Portland Community College to finish my Certificate in Ethnobotany with feelers about Masters programs for next Fall. I've chosen to take 9-months off as a "retirement" so I can tend to my own creative adventures, have the luscious opportunity to spend good quality time with my family and friends, and hike like the wild woman I am! And I'm overjoyed to start the steps to building a joyful and successful business around my passion for everyday ministry and authentic leadership.

So here I am! No matter how you choose to contribute to this campaign, please join my adventure. I can tell you, the views will be spectacular.

Below I've started my list of thank yous that will keep growing. For me, we are all a circle. Without you, I would not be the same blessed woman I delightfully know myself to be.

With gratitude always,

Leah

Circling up the Gratitude!

  • You! Yes, you.
  • To my family. Mama', for spearheading so many family travels and your joyful devotion to the spirit of life. And big thanks to you, Dad, for sharing the love for the long and winding trail. 
  • My beloved circles of friends and family who have supported me on my path- easy and hard, joyful and dark. You light the path all year round.
  • Sydney Weaver for your greatest trail wisdom and countless stories from your PCT days.
  • Anthony Mannello for giving me the PCT bug along with the great crew at Green Drop Garage.
  • Quinn McCabe and the outdoor enthusiast community at the Portland REI.
  • Nicole Porcaro for the gift of your amazing herbal salve and lip balm for my trail First Aid Kit.
  • Tribes, tribal leaders and spiritual guardians for the lands I walk with. May I walk lightly with my good heart, always give back more than I receive, and ask for permission when this is the good way to proceed. 
  • All my plant-spirit-energy teachers. Rita Blumenstein, Marie Meade, Melissa Nelson, my botany and ethnobotany professors, the International Council of 13 Indigenous Grandmothers, the Center for Sacred Studies Ministry family, the White Raven Center family, my Reiki and Healing Touch mentors, and all the influential gardeners, permaculture geeks and wild women in my life. I will use your knowledge on the trail...as I do every day.
  • The spirit of the trail and the good-natured humans who always seem to cross my path, share the best tips for where to go and stay and share from such a genuine space of connection.
  • Last but DEFINITELY NOT least, love to my amazing knees, feet, bones and strong body...and all of my gear that helps to keep me safe and, at times, quite comfortable.

May I always carry beauty in my heart. May my joy for simply doing what I love, be what changes the world. Aho. Amen. 7/21/17

Get out to your local trails. Find a new trail or a new trail hiking buddy. Learn a new plant by name. Learn a new story about a place you have been a million times. Be curious!
Check out the gallery of photos on this site. I posted my favorite pictures from my solo and group hikes over the last 3-months. 
If you are a Pacific Northwest local or might be in the area late August-September, let me know. Anyone who feels called to join me on the trail for a night or weekend is welcome at my campfire!
Questions, inspirations, curiosities? I'm here: beauty.of.peace@gmail.com Why Backpacking? And for 30 days?!It was mid-January. The neighborhood streets of Portland were full of neighbors grumbling about shoveling snow while kids were still elated by the unexpected ability to build snow people, huge snow forts, and sled in the local park. In this true feeling of winter, I felt a great hunger for beginning something new that was creative and challenged me. Something that would help me see myself with a new lens, in a new space of confidence and clarity about my purpose and direction.I chose the PCT. Exercise has always been an important part of my mental health. I don't know about you, but I definitely have a wild bunch of monkeys who love the landscape of my mind and cause major damage if I am not mindful. When I exercise, I feel like the monkeys are the ones that exercise and then they get tired and I experience my clear sight and mind...and find a closer sense of connection to myself. Backpacking has been an amazing way to move my body and immerse myself in lands that I love. All this felt perfect for me. Then, my dad sent me these photos of himself at age 23. He was stationed at the Air Force Base in Phoenix, Arizona at the time. This was a trip of his to the Grand Canyon. I got chills looking at them. A chord sung inside me. Family medicine and passions sometimes share the same well. As my PCT planning continued, I was pulled to revisit memories of previous backpacking trips over the years. In doing so, I found these pictures -- along with a renewed sense of awe and gratitude for my parents taking us on this adventure-- of our family backpacking trip down to Havasupai Falls. Seriously!My good friend Robert came with us as Nathan chose to stay home. I still get teased about how we carrying our AP Calculus book back and forth in our backpacks so we could do homework on the trail...which I don't actually remember happening. Besides weekend trips with friends and partners, my most recent backpacking adventure was my two months in India with Sierra Institute for a Himalayan backpacking field study program in 2005. An incredible opportunity, our studies focused on the geology, natural history and sustainable development initiatives within Ladakh (Northen India). My friend Greta and I did our research on gender and women's access to professional and educational opportunities. We met some amazing women! Climbing peaks and passes over 17,000 ft "topped off" the experience.​Remembering these stories has helped me realize something. That being out on the trail has always been a part of how I have moved in my life. It has always been a part of what I imagined was possible for me. And as a woman prone to ritual, being on the trail has been a tool for me to honor my own transformation or to hold a question in prayer and know that by the time I step off the trail, something new will be planted within me or something released to the wind. When I started planning this trip, I imagined that this would be my big adventure for the year. Standing here in the middle of July, this no longer feels true. This adventure has merely become one of many. I'm back in an academic adventure at Portland Community College to finish my Certificate in Ethnobotany with feelers about Masters programs for next Fall. I've chosen to take 9-months off as a "retirement" so I can tend to my own creative adventures, have the luscious opportunity to spend good quality time with my family and friends, and hike like the wild woman I am! And I'm overjoyed to start the steps to building a joyful and successful business around my passion for everyday ministry and authentic leadership.So here I am! No matter how you choose to contribute to this campaign, please join my adventure. I can tell you, the views will be spectacular.Below I've started my list of thank yous that will keep growing. For me, we are all a circle. Without you, I would not be the same blessed woman I delightfully know myself to be.With gratitude always,LeahCircling up the Gratitude!
You! Yes, you.
To my family. Mama', for spearheading so many family travels and your joyful devotion to the spirit of life. And big thanks to you, Dad, for sharing the love for the long and winding trail. 
My beloved circles of friends and family who have supported me on my path- easy and hard, joyful and dark. You light the path all year round.
Sydney Weaver for your greatest trail wisdom and countless stories from your PCT days.
Anthony Mannello for giving me the PCT bug along with the great crew at Green Drop Garage.
Quinn McCabe and the outdoor enthusiast community at the Portland REI.
Nicole Porcaro for the gift of your amazing herbal salve and lip balm for my trail First Aid Kit.
Tribes, tribal leaders and spiritual guardians for the lands I walk with. May I walk lightly with my good heart, always give back more than I receive, and ask for permission when this is the good way to proceed. 
All my plant-spirit-energy teachers. Rita Blumenstein, Marie Meade, Melissa Nelson, my botany and ethnobotany professors, the International Council of 13 Indigenous Grandmothers, the Center for Sacred Studies Ministry family, the White Raven Center family, my Reiki and Healing Touch mentors, and all the influential gardeners, permaculture geeks and wild women in my life. I will use your knowledge on the trail...as I do every day.
The spirit of the trail and the good-natured humans who always seem to cross my path, share the best tips for where to go and stay and share from such a genuine space of connection.
Last but DEFINITELY NOT least, love to my amazing knees, feet, bones and strong body...and all of my gear that helps to keep me safe and, at times, quite comfortable.
May I always carry beauty in my heart. May my joy for simply doing what I love, be what changes the world. Aho. Amen. 7/21/17

story:
To the Orcas, With Love

This is a story about the whales and the people who live with them and care deeply about them.

 

A documentary Film, "To the Orcas, with Love"
This is a story about the whales and the people who live with them and care deeply about them. Hear from Canadian Environmentalist and CBC Broadcaster, Dr. David Suzuki, as well  biologist and director of Sharkwater, Rob Stewart, whale researchers including Alexandra Morton, native elders, and others who have stories to share about their connection to these whales; as well as my own personal connection to the whales.

Told through the lens of Director, Natalie Lucier, this film has gained the attention and participation of:

  • Dr. David Suzuki; Environmentalist, Scientist, CBC Broadcaster
  • Rob Stewart; Biologist, Director of Sharkwater (2006)
  • Alexandra Morton; Biologist, founder of Salmon Coast Research Station
  • Dr. Paul Spong; Founder of OrcaLab
  • Jackie Hildering; Biologist, Marine educator, Marine Education and Research Society
  • Wayne Alfred; Totem carver, Namgis First Nation

PROJECT DESCRIPTION

Synopsis

The killer whales on the British Columbia coast are endangered. Their habitat is changing and their well-being is at risk because of pollution, boat traffic and global warming. This is a story about the whales and the people who live with them and care deeply about them. Hear from Canadian Environmentalist, CBC Broadcaster and scientist, David Suzuki, biologist and director of Sharkwater (2006), Rob Stewart, whale researchers including Alexandra Morton, native elders, artists and other locals who have personal stories to share about their connection to these whales; as well as my own personal connection to the whales during the time that I lived in a hut on the ocean in very close proximity to them during the summer of 2012.

We are pleased that we have received funding through Ontario Arts Council in support of this film and we are also moving forward with other funders and grant proposals.

 

What motivates you to do this project?

I have always been fascinated by killer whales. Watching them in the wild awakens their patience, grace, presence, and stillness within me. Listening to them breathe, I gain a deep sense of peace;  a greater knowing that everything will fall into place. Living in family pods, very closely connected to one another, I resonate with their sense of family and belonging.- Director, Natalie Lucier

Why is this film important? 

The northern and southern resident killer whale populations of Vancouver Island are threatened. Their survival depends on our actions to help protect them. The ocean and the ecosystems are fragile and are changing fast.

It wasn’t until recently that laws changed to protect Orcas from being shot or captured in Canada. Considered gentle giants, killer whales are the top hunters of the ocean food chain.  In the recent past, their reputation as ‘monsters of the sea’ allowed Canadians to be permitted to shoot killer whales, as their feeding habits were diminishing the human fish supply. Orcas became the ones being hunted.

Orca whales communicate through the ocean waters to stay connected and alive. Boat noise, pollution, and human waste all can disrupt their habitat and natural way of life. They absorb the toxic waste from the water, and it makes them sick. I am concerned for the whales and for their home, the ocean.

In sharing the beauty of these whales in their natural habitat, my hope is that others will see and understand them better. As Canadians, our choices affect the state of our natural world.  A better understanding of their way of life may allow more people to take steps to protect and preserve our oceans.

The stories, teachings and wisdom of the people who live in the home of the killer whales are very powerful. I’d like to share their stories and concern for the whales inspiring viewers to care, take action and change.  - Director, Natalie Lucier

Who is it for?

This project is for Canadian audiences as well as audiences worldwide. The film is most relevant to Canadians, featuring Canadian wildlife, researchers and people, targeting schools and youth, adults and environmental film festivals.

 

THE TEAM:

DIRECTOR: Natalie Lucier

Natalie is a graduate of Advanced TV and Film at Sheridan college 2011. She has also attended the Adventure Filmmakers Workshop in Banff during the Banff Mountain Film fest Nov 2011 and LOVED it! Learning from Keith Partridge - a BBC Cameraman and also Michael Brown of Serac Adventure Films it was a motivating and inspiring experience working with other amazing filmmakers in the magical mountainous place that Banff is. Natalie dreams of creating documentary films that will inspire people to care for our planet and see the beauty in it.

Specialties: filmmaking, documentary filmmaking, photography,

 

PRODUCER: Virginia Hastings

Labour of Love, Virginia’s wildly successful documentary debut about the Race Across America, the world’s toughest endurance race, was an official selection in many film festivals that has spanned over 15 countries including, Transatlantyk Festival, HotDocs Film Circuit, as well as Canadian Sport Film Festival, International Bike Film Festival, Film North International Film. It was also an official selection for HotDocs DocShop where Virginia secured a distribution deal that has catapulted her work onto CBC’s Documentary Zone and for broadcast in Australia, Netherlands, and the middle East. Her work has also been included on the Toronto International Film Festival’s TIFF Film Circuit and Cinefest Sudbury International Film Festival, where she was named “one of 3 of Canada’s young up and coming film makers to watch out for.”

She has been put on panels for the National Film Board of Canada to discuss her work, even though none of her works have been produced by them.

This success introduced Virginia to her undeniable talent of producing engaging documentary stories that entirely alter people and their perspective of the world. Virginia also produced Fairly Foul, Living in Balance, and Turning the Tide.

For the past 13 years Virginia has owned and acted as Producer for Starshine Video Productions, an award winning video production company that focuses on educational videos, social justice and advocacy, commercials and nature and wildlife.

A description of Virginia’s role as the producer on this film:

As Producer of this film, “To the Orcas, With Love” Virginia supervises the making of a film by bringing all the creative, key players, interviews, shooting locations, hiring and sourcing out of industry professionals, raising the funds, schedules, legal permissions, and accounting of the film together to make sure it is made on time and on budget while supervising all the moving parts of the film from start right through to completion and marketing and negotiating the documentary for film festivals and for distribution.

 

EDITOR: J.L. Munce

BFA in Film Production at Ryerson Polytechnic University where he wrote, directed and edited several short films. While Jeremy has worn several hats over the years his love and passion for editing, as well as the immense talent he has in an editing suite, is what brings him time and time again to working alongside teams who create award winning films. His directorial effort, The Alma Drawings, won the award for Best Direction at the Hot Docs Film Festival in 2005. It has gone on to be broadcast on The Documentary Channel, Discovery, TVO and Vision TV. Munce has extensive experience as an editor on dramas as well as documentaries, with 7 features under his belt. Highlights include Bruce McDonald’s ‘Pontypool’, and ‘The Tracey Fragments’ and the infamous underground mock-umentary, ‘Claire’s Hat’, as well as Liz Marshall’s ‘Water on the Table’ which won best film at Planet in Focus.

A description of Jeremy's role as the editor on this film:

As Editor of this film Jeremy works his poetic magic in bringing all of the contrasting layers of this story together to weave them into a tapestry of film that is visually stunning, flows well within both the imagery and in keeping with the information and story being delivered to the viewer.

Jeremy works with the raw footage selecting shots and combining them with music, ambient sound to create a finished product that is a great story.

This film has been in production since the summer of 2012. We are at the final stages of production and we are in need of donations and support to make this film impactful and reach a wide audience internationally. We want to get the message out that these orca whales matter, showcasing them in their natural element in the wild, sharing in the beauty of this place we call home, Canada.

If you are not in a position to make a donation today, please share our story with your friends on social media and help us to reach our goal any way you can.

Our fundraising goal is $50,000 CAN and the funds are needed to help support the production of the film and see it through to completion. Donations will be used to cover the cost of:

  • Music composition
  • Sound engineering
  • Final editing of video
  • Stock footage
  • Colour mastering
  • Production of the DVD
  • Entrance fees into film festivals
  • Marketing materials (posters, flyers, newspaper ads, web, media)
  • Travel cost for the director and producer to attend screenings and Q&A sessions worldwide
  • Website creation
  • Social media intern

story:
Who we are and what we want to do

International Tree Foundation (ITF) is a charity that was founded in Kenya in 1924 to encourage people the world over to plant, care for and love their trees. In 2016 we launched our Centenary Campaign: 20 Million Trees for Kenya's Forests, which will be planted by 2024. The first stage of this project is our work with Mount Kenya Environmental Conservation (MKEC) in Embu County and surrounding areas.

Mount Kenya’s forests are vital – for wildlife, for freshwater resources, and for the materials they provide to local people. Sadly, these forests cover only a fraction of their original area, much of which is degraded in quality. Local people recognise that the forests need to be protected – but they also contribute to the damage, not out of choice but because they have to.

Even today, Kenya’s rural communities are heavily dependent on forests for their livelihoods. Esther Nyaga is a 47-year-old farmer with two children. She owns half an acre of land in Kanja village, Embu County. Her land is largely dedicated to growing tea, a profitable crop she can sell to support herself and her family. Because she has so few trees – less than 30 - she visits the forest twice a week to collect fuel wood and fodder for her cow.

Esther knows the forest is important to her life, and she is one of the most experienced people in Kanja village when it comes to raising and planting trees. For farmers like Esther, planting trees doesn’t just provide fuel and animal fodder. Different species can provide a whole variety of benefits – nitrogen fixing for soil improvement, nutritious fruits such as mango and avocado, shade, timber, and medicinal uses. They also grow native species with which to restore the forest edge.

Esther is one (remarkable) woman. We want to raise £5,000 so that every farmer in Kanja can plant 50 trees on their land – a total of 20,000 trees providing vital resources to rural families while protecting Mount Kenya’s majestic forest.

Will you help?

What we need and what you get

The average cost of raising and planting a sapling in this area, including all the costs of tools, training and so on, is roughly 25p. £5,000 is our goal because it equates to enough for every farmer in Esther's village to plant 50 trees. The money will pay for seeds, materials, and training for local people on how to raise, plant and care for their trees.

We're excited to offer some great perks from some of our friends and corporate partners such as Batelier Handicrafts, Get Laid Beds and Wessanen UK (the company behind Clipper Teas, Whole Earth, Mrs Crimbles, Kallo and Almond Breeze).

If the goal is exceeded, we will be able to plant even more trees! If we don't reach our goal the money will still be going towards our tree-planting projects on Mount Kenya, as part of the 20 Million Trees campaign.

Why it's so cool

The basis of this 'farms and forest' idea is an amazing concept called agroforestry - a system of agriculture where a variety of different trees are used together to provide many different benefits to the farmer. Agroforestry is gaining popularity in Eastern African countries where food security is at risk, as systems incorporating trees are much less vulnerable to weather extremes than traditional agriculture and horticulture. Find out more about agroforestry here.

Up until Christmas, check out our advent calendar on this page where we'll be talking about a different tree species every day!

How else can you help?

Even if you can't contribute, don't forget to share our campaign with your friends and family.

story:
Comme vous le savez probablement déjà, nous sommes complétement gaga de notre petit Elliot chéri !

Les heureux parents du petit trésor : Isa et Max, souhaitant faire leur part pour l'environnement, veulent se lancer dans l'aventure des couches lavables.  Comme vous êtes nombreux à avoir manifester le souhait de les soutenir, voici l'occasion de contribuer sans tracas et surtout sans pression.  

Elliot J. Beaugrand

Né le 21 septembre de cette année, à la maison de naissance de l'Estrie, notre beau, bientôt grand et tant attendu Elliot est arrivé. Portant fièrement le J. en l'honneur de ses deux grands-pères : Jean-René et Jacques, Elliot relève son premier défi avec passion : tenter de distinguer le jour de la nuit.

Le kit full pro 

Le kit de couches visé comprend des culottes moulées et d'autres imperméables. Des couches de nuit, de jour, et qui sait, une couche de luxe pour les grandes occasions :)

Les contributions serviront à financer le fameux kit en tout ou en partie selon le montant recueilli.  Advenant le cas où davantage d'argent serait versé, l'idée d'un fonds d'études (à trois semaines !?) flotte dans l'air. 

Le mot de la fin

Merci infiniment à tous et au plaisir de vous voir bientôt !

story:
Short Summary

Reverdece, is a non-profit organism founded in 2004, that has been developing projects and ideas to contribute to the environmental welfare of our country, Mexico.

We've been developing a national and international network of people concerned with the environmental situation in our country, especially in our region.

However, this campaign will be focused on developing an educational kit used to create forestry awareness in Mexican children and teenagers. This kit, which is actually in a very advanced stage of creative development, will provide the youngster a very easy way to plant trees, vegetables, flowers, etc., and, thus, see how important is to take care of our natural resources.

 This kit will have the following components:

  • 1 EPS (re-usable) container to plant anything the users would consider to plant.
  • A package of seeds.
  • A package of organic soil.
  • A very friendly manual to understand the process of reforestation and the importance of our forests.
  • A proper plastic greenhouse to emulate the conditions required to grow a plant.
  • A portable carton box, used as a recipient for the components.

So, in order to produce this eco-kit we need all the monetary aid we can get from you and any sponsor!

What We Need & What You Get

The total sum of money, will be used in the following points:

$20,000 on the molds required to produce the EPS container, plastic dome and bottom recipient to contain the soil.

$5,000 on the remaining graphic design to make the kit friendly to kids.

$2,500 on transporting the first production (1,000 units) around our regional schools to test the efficiency of this product.

$2,500 on salaries for the personal involved in teacher's environmental training to use the device in the school properly.

As you may see, the molds are the most expensive thing to get, because the design was made especially to fit children's requirements and capabilities. The rest will be used as stated.

By now, we already made a prototype based in another mold. But we really want to expand our educational reach and impact.

Of course, if you contribute with our cause, we will be glad to offer you some perks described on this page. Some of them specially developed for this campaign.

The Impact

Your help will be equivalent to the help you make to others. We really think that children are the future of our world. Unfortunally, sometimes we mislead our resources and think that the established institutions will do their job. In Reverdece, you have the experience + the disposition. 

Some examples are among the projects we have already undertook, including:

  • Preservation of threatened orchid species.
  •  Environmental education, using materials and devices developed by ourselves, i.e., organic soils, interactive nursery models, etc.
  • Counseling institutions, including government and non-government associations.
  • Bringing international experts to Mexico, in order to improve our capabilities   about forestry and related topics.
  • Planting deforested areas around our headquarters in Uruapan, Michoacan, Mexico.

As well, we count with a growing member's team who support us, including some people from the US, Canada and South Africa, to mention some of them.

Other Ways You Can Help

  1. You can visit our twitter and facebook profile. If you like us, follow us.
  2. Spread the word! This campaign will be stronger if we sum our voices.
  3. If you want to collaborate as a member, please let us now. Our contact info is down below.

CONTACT INFO:

FACEBOOK: http://www.facebook.com/reverdece

TWITTER: http://www.twitter.com/reverdece

WEBSITE (Currently in Spanish): http://www.reverdeceac.org

story:
Telling A New Story -

لنروي لكم قصة جديدة

In the popular imagination, Iraq is a desert wasteland, devoid of natural beauty and lacking breathtaking scenery.

In Iraqi's understanding, their country's environment is hopelessly neglected, abused by forces beyond their control.

We want to tell a new story to change these attitudes, and show Iraq's last wild rivers in their true beauty and splendor.

Summary of the Expedition

نبذة عن الرحلة النهرية

Our story has two major chapters.

  • First, we will lead a kayak expedition down the Choman-Rawanduz River of Kurdistan, northern Iraq in the spring of 2014 with a team of professional kayakers, river advocates, and a videographer who will conduct outreach to local communities to raise awareness about river threats and provide tools on how to protect them.
  • Second, the story of the expedition will be retold in a short film, which will chronicle this record-setting first kayak expedition down the full length of the Choman-Rawanduz River in northern Iraq.  The film will be used to raise awareness locally and internationally, showcasing the tourism potential of these rivers and demonstrating how they can be protected and used sustainably.
We've developed a map that shows the area of the expedition and some of the proposed locations for outreach activities along the expedition route using an application called ZeeMaps. Checkout the map at: http://bit.ly/1gbAF09

What we Need & What You Get

ما نحتاجه منكم وما نقدمه لكم

We are raising  $10,000 to fund the videographer on the project and support the equipment and supplies needed for creating the film of the Expedition.  The full expedition cost will be approximately $70,000 for equipment, transportation and logistics and much of this funding will come from within Iraq and/or will be donated by the expedition participants themselves.

What do you get? Depending on the size of your pledge you will receive our copious thanks as well as T-shirts, bumper stickers, autographed photos, a copy of the final film and your name included in the credits. Other perks include in-country birding/hiking trips, in-country kayaking/rafting trips, ACA Membership, producer credits on the film and your very own kayak!  If you are in the U.S., your pledge will be tax deductible.

Why?

لماذا؟

In the fall of 2013 we conducted an expedition down the Tigris River from southeast Turkey to southern Iraq in both traditional and modern vessels.  The Tigris River Flotilla allowed us to reach out to riverside communities and promote the strong cultural connections that the Tigris River has always fostered.  It also gave us the inspiration to continue to do community outreach along the rivers in Iraq.  

The Choman-Rawanduz River is a major tributary to the Tigris and is part of the Great Zab River Basin, the last wild river in the country located in Kurdistan, northern Iraq.  After decades of conflict this relatively stable part of the country is rushing to develop and in so doing is putting its last wild and scenic rivers on the chopping block without realizing what a tremendous resource that they are about to lose.

Engineers throughout the country are building dams that are damaging the rivers. Undiscovered species will be lost forever, water quality is declining and a true paddlers paradise will be submerged and forgotten.  This expedition will demonstrate how rivers that are wild, free and clean can also be an important resource for recreation and tourism in a country that can greatly benefit from these more peaceful pastimes.

In addition to working with the riverside communities along the Choman-Rawanduz River itself, an action-packed film of the expedition will be developed to promote the rivers more widely in Iraq and beyond for eco-tourism and to advocate more effectively for their protection. There are few positive visual tools that can be used for Iraqi river advocacy and education campaigns and Iraq needs such a film to promote eco-tourism in the country that demonstrates a reason for keeping these rivers wild and clean.

Other Ways You Can Help

سبل اخرى يمكنكم مساعدتنا بها

Get the word out! Tweet this page or mention it on Facebook. Talk to us on Twitter. Email us at Waterkeepers Iraq or Nature Iraq with questions and comments.

Who are We?

من نحن؟

Nature Iraq is an Iraqi nongovernmental organization focused on biodiversity conservation and water resource protection. Our founder, Dr. Azzam Alwash, was the recipient of a Goldman Prize for excellence in protecting the environment and was included in Foreign Policy Magazine's list of The Leading Global Thinkers of 2013.

Virginia Tice is the founder and CEO of the Nature Iraq Foundation, a U.S.-based 501(c)3 charity who provides support to the Iraqi conservation organization Nature Iraq and other nonprofit organizations dedicated to the protection, restoration, and conservation of the environment in Iraq and the Middle East region. 

Nabil Musa is the acting Iraq Upper Tigris Waterkeeper at Nature Iraq’s Waterkeepers Iraq Initiative, a part of the international Waterkeeper Alliance and are dedicated to the protection of Iraqi rivers and waterways.

Andreas Bleiker is the founder and operator of Majestic Heights Outdoor Adventures, an eco-tourism company in northern Iraq dedicated to developing the tourism potential of Iraq and protecting the natural resources that support the country’s under-utilized wild and scenic resources.

David Burden is the International Paddlesports Ambassador at the American Canoe Association (ACA), a member based, national nonprofit organization that promotes paddlesports and provides stewardship support to help protect paddling environments in the U.S. and abroad.

اضغط هنا لقراءة شرح كامل للرحلة الاستكشافية بالعربية

story:
The Green Tigers are the environmental club at South High School in Minneapolis. We are network of students who meet once a week before school to plan events, discuss issues, and act on our ideas of how we can make our school, and broader community more environmentally friendly. We do this through spreading awareness (bringing in speakers, hosting movie nights, etc.), putting on action events (Bike to School Week, collecting signed post cards during lunch, installing composting programs in our lunchroom, etc.).  

As high school students, we care about environmental issues for a variety of reasons.  Students at South purchase plastic water bottles everyday from the Dasani vending machines at our school. Countless water bottles are thrown in the trash, and wind up in landfills where they poison the land and the oceans. Hydration Stations will drastically reduce the amount of plastic water bottles purchased and discarded by students and staff, hereby removing our support from water bottle factories. These factories contribute to serious health problems found in the people living close by. Hydration Stations will allow us to keep track of the number of bottles filled up, which will give us the opportunity to track our successes and spread awareness throughout the school.


Buying and installing a hydration station costs around $1000. We have applied for grants through our school and through the Will Steger Foundation, which would both cover part of that sum. We are selling t-shirts and reusable water bottles to raise money as well. But even if we receive the grants, we will need more funding. Ideally, we would be able to install more than one hydration station (one near the lunchroom, and one near the gym). Whether we reach $500 or not, all funds raised will be put towards the purchase of hydration stations. 


Your support will allow us to take this next step towards making our school and our community a healthier, stronger, and safer place. As youth whose voices are often ignored, installing hydration stations is an opportunity we have to act on our valid, educated passion about the world around us. Any amount helps. We thank you in advance for your support!


Please share this page to everyone you know! Thank you!

story:
Chatarra Project Summary

My wife Rachel and I are passionate about our future, which we feel are our children and the environment. We love Baja California Mexico, the people and the land. Each year we work hard to bring awareness to the needs of the orphaned children and fragile environment.

In 2011, we created the Baja Love Ride and rode bicycles from the Pacific Ocean to the Gulf of California, staying at orphanages to raise awareness and much-needed funds for the children. In 2012, we create the Baja Walk and the two of us walked unassisted, the full 850 mile length of Baja California to support various orphanages and environmental causes, but during the 74-day walk we saw the amount of the plastic waste and litter and the growth of the problem. 

This year our focus is litter and plastic waste. Corporations continue to put everything in plastic packaging, yet neither the corporation, many from the United States, the Mexican government, or the local municipalities provide sufficient trash receptacles, trash pickup or environmental education. Therefore, most trash is thrown to the ground, where it makes its way into the sea, ocean, and deserts. So, this year in an effort to capture the attention of the youth, we are building a raft with a paddlewheel and pedaling the craft 600 miles down the coast of Baja California in the Sea of Cortez, stopping in 8 coastal communities to provide bilingual literature and information on the dangers of litter and plastic waste. In addition, we have established our 3 primary goals of Chatarra Project, listed below.

Every donation you make brings us one step closer to a CLEAN BAJA! Your contribution to Baja is important to us, so we would like to provide supporters with our appreciation. To accomplish the goal of the Project Chatarra, ONLY $5000 is needed to be raised, which is asking so little, to accomplish so much.

What is the Chatarra Project Mission?

The project's goal is to increase awareness and public knowledge of plastic waste in Baja and to engage the public in coastal protection and cleanup activities. Project Chatarra will provide a variety of conservation, education and community involvement programs and resources.

Our Goal is Simple: CLEAN BAJA!

Here three ways we want to help with your help:

Our #1 Goal is to create awareness to the problem of waste and litter in Baja California. We want to draw attention to the problem through a variety of activities including the building and the 600 mile Sea of Cortez expedition of the Chatarra Raft, a boat made of repurposed materials, floated on reused plastic bottles and pedal powered. The expedition’s goal is to capture the attention of the youth, and to provide engaging bilingual educational materials in 8 coastal communities of Baja.

Our #2 Goal is work with, support, and or create a network of people in each of Baja’s communities that desire to help CLEAN BAJA! To raise enough funds through the sell of t-shirts to help provide supplies and resources and to bring people and groups together, so others may become aware and support or join them locally.

Our #3 Goal is to establish a CLEAN BAJA DAY that benefits the environment and helps beautify Baja. Participants in a community CLEAN BAJA DAY can include the entire family, both children and adults. The event will bring the community together and create a sense of pride in making the community a better place to live. We will include prizes, games and a Chatarra Plastic Bottle Boat Race.

How is the Chatarra Project Funded?

Until finding Indiegogo, The Chatarra Project has been self funded by the sale of Chatarra Project T-shirts, Donations, and our Supporters, including the Baja Good Life Club, Richard and Joyce Lawrence, Christine Wood, Raine Fisher, Gene Jensen, Steve Sherrod and now hopefully you too.

The Chatarra Project Financial Goal:

Our Marketing Material Needs:

  • 2500 full color, bilingual educational handouts
  • 1000 full color “Keep Baja Beautiful, Don’t Trash Baja” / “Mantenga Baja Beautiful, no tirar basura” stickers
  • 300 giveaway t-shirts, with the same message.
  • 80 signs at 18″ x 24″ printed in full color with the same message for beach and near trash receptacle.

Trash Pick Up Supplies:

  • 5500 Trash Bags – 70 cases of 70 bags of 33 gallon Glad ® Trash Bags
  • 100 Hand Trash Pickers

Chatarra Needs

  • RAFT:
  • 100 – 8 ” Nylon Zip Ties Cord ($3 dlls)
  • 25 – Cargo Straps: 7 feet or 8 feet ($60 dlls)
  • 2 – 4×8 sheet 1/2 plywood ($30 dlls / each)
  • 4 – 4×8 sheet 5/8 plywood ($33 dlls / each)
  • 11 – 1″ conduit ($6 dlls /each)
  • 8 Canopy brackets ($8 dlls / each)
  • 1 gal Impac 500 white sealer ($6 dlls / each)

SUPPLIES & STORAGE:

  • 2 – 5 Gallon Water Bottles ($15 dlls / each)
  • 1 – Igloo Polar 120 Quart Ice Crest ($90 – 110 dlls)
  • 6 Coleman Propane 1 Pound Tanks ($2 dlls / each)
  • 1 – HawkEye® Portable Hand Held Electronic Fish & Depth Finder ($45 dlls)

**HELP – donate it, buy it, or let us barrow it; email us chatarra@bglclub.com or call MX cell 686-230-9933.

story:
HAPPY LITTLE TREES!

Thanks everyone who donated to this campaign!  We have forwarded all funds to the Treebank Foundation!  More happy little trees in OKC!
story_txt: HAPPY LITTLE TREES!Thanks everyone who donated to this campaign!  We have forwarded all funds to the Treebank Foundation!  More happy little trees in OKC!

story:
THE "BTU" IS AN INNOVATIVE & SOCIAL ENTREPRENEURSHIP PROJECT OF WATER TO FIGHT CHOLERA, NOMINATED FOR THE 2014 GLOBAL WATER AWARDS

                                                                                                                                                 

                                                    

                                                    

                                                       

                                                       

                                                     ALL IN THE PRESS

SMG GLOBAL HAITI - WINNER OF THE "2013 BUSINESS PLAN" ORGANIZED BY USAID/PADF UNDER THE LEAD PROJECT


                                                                   

                               


1st BACTERIOLOGICAL TREATMENT UNIT FOR WATER, FRUITS & LEGUMES - to fight cholera, NOMINATED FOR THE 2014 GLOBAL WATER AWARDS: http://www.globalwaterawards.com/water-project-year   

                        

OUR VISION

We believe that the stepping stone to cholera eradication is to provide vulnerable people access to bacteria free water - Let's do it together!            Yes We Can!
                                                                                                                           

OUR GOAL

Introducing in Haiti the OZONE Water Treatment Technology in order to make treated water accessible to the vulnerable population at low cost and achieve the eradication of cholera


WHO ARE WE?

We are a group of Social Entrepreneurs from Switzerland, United States and Haiti . We seek to provide a reference company  in the domain of  bacteriological water treatment in order to provide a solution to the water issues in Haiti and consequently, eradication of cholera. The Bacteriological Treatment Unit (BTU ) aims to address 3 main vectors of vibro cholerae that are:  water , fruits and Legumes, from two natural resources : Air and Solar Energy, hence the chemical reaction:( 0 + 02+ E = 03  ) establishing the Ozone . To achieve this goal, we conceived the pilot project from the cholera eradication program approved by the Ministry of Public Health.The first  bacteriological treatment Unit (BTU ) will be installed in port-au- prince, but the ultimate goal is to have a BTU in thirty local municipalities, starting with the most vulnerable and involving Municipalities and local organizations.


WHAT WE HAVE - WHAT WE NEED 

A physical structure already exists for the installation of the first BTU  in Haiti. The total estimated project cost is $ $400,000; however, the founding members have contributed $ 200,000 . We only need the technical structure including the cost of equipment which is estimated at $200,000 

The requested contribution can be in cash or building  facilities, Feel free to contact directly the Manufacturer & Specialist at the address below:
 Amir Salama Eng, M.Sc,ABT Ph.D

Ozomax inc                                                                                                                            600 Robitaille -QC-Shefford                                                                                                 Canada  J2M 1X2                                                                                                                    Tel: 450-378-6825                                                                                  Website: http://www.ozomax.com                                                                                          E-mail: engineering@ozomax.com                                                               http://www.ozomax.com/Municipal-water-treatment/municipal-water-treatment.htm


THE IMPACT 

The installation of the 1st BTU will have an impact on the well-being of the vulnerable population and allow a 25% reduction in the rate of cholera in the Metropolitan area

FOR AN ASSESSMENT OF THE SCOPE AND IMPORTANCE OF THE FIRST BACTERIOLOGICAL WATER TREATMENT IN HAITI, WE SPECIFY THE FOLLOWING:

-SMG Global Haiti won the contest for the best "Business Plan 2013 " organized by USAID/PADF ( document available ) so the ROI is guaranteed as well as the social aspect, as a percentage of the profit will be used for the installation of the second BTU


- The Chairman of SMG Global Haiti , Swiss citizen , has already experienced these new technologies in Switzerland and Mexico. He has twenty years of experience in the field of water purification, including a dozen in the bacteriological water treatment in Mexico, which had similar problems in the years 2000


-The BTU  enables the vulnerable people of the population to have access to treated water at the lowest cost , while protecting the market and population stability


-There is no structure in Haiti providing the specific service processing fruits and Legumes (vegetables) considered two main vectors of Vibrio cholerae after water, which makes the erection of  BTU  an innovative and profitable project


-Thirty municipalities starting with the most vulnerable are concerned by the project in the medium or long term but they all depend on the first bacteriological treatment Unit. SMG intends to make the first  BTU, a "Success Story"


THE ALTERNATIVE

In case we do not reach the amount of $ 200,000. We are ready to apply for funding. However, if the amount referred is higher, the difference will be directed towards the implementation of the 2nd bacteriological treatment Unit(BTU ) in Petite Rivière de l' Artibonite, vulnerable area, the birthplace of cholera virus.


 All philanthropists, social entrepreneurs, or organizations that have made substantial contributions to the installation of the First BTU in Haiti shall have honorary plaques erected in their names in front of the premises as contributing to the eradication of Cholera in Haiti. 


OTHER WAY TO SUPPORT

People with social sensitivity for the project but who can’t contribute financially are invited to promote it by sharing with friends, parents and social institutions, using Indiegogo tools.

Thank you for having taken knowledge of our noble project that will impact short-term 25% of the vulnerable population, to achieve medium and long-term 50%, as it is known to spread to vulnerable communities.

Amir Salama Eng, M.Sc,ABT Ph.D

Ozomax inc                                                                                                                            600 Robitaille -QC-Shefford                                                                                                 Canada  J2M 1X2                                                                                                                    Tel: 450-378-6825                                                                                  Website: http://www.ozomax.com                                                                                          E-mail: engineering@ozomax.com                                                               http://www.ozomax.com/Municipal-water-treatment/municipal-water-treatment.htm

                 -FRENCH VERSION-

NOTRE VISION

Nous sommes convaincus que l’éradication du Cholera passe obligatoirement par l’accessibilité de la population a une EAU traitte contre toute bacterie.

NOTRE OBJECTIF

Introduire en Haiti la nouvelle technologie de traitement d'eau par l'ozone en vue de rendre l'eau traitée accessible a la population a un prix modique et parvenir a l'eradication du cholera.


QUI SOMMES-NOUS?

Nous sommes un groupe d'entrepreneurs sociaux de nationalité Suisse, Américaine, Haïtienne. Nous avons monté en Haiti une compagnie de référence en traitement bactériologique de l'eau dans le but d'apporter une solution à la problématique de l'eau en Haiti et par voie de conséquence, l’éradication du cholera. L’Unité de traitement bactériologique (UTB)  vise  à  attaquer les 3 principaux vecteurs du vibro cholerea que sont: l'eau, les fruits et les légumes, à partir de 2 ressources naturelles: l'air et l’énergie solaire d'où la réaction chimique: (0 + 02 + E= 03) créant l'Ozone.                                   

Pour atteindre cet objectif, nous avons mis en oeuvre le projet pilote émanant du programme d' éradication du cholera approuvé par le Ministère de la Sante Publique.

La 1ere Unité de traitement bactériologique (UTB) sera installée à port-au-prince mais l’objectif final est d'avoir une UTB dans une trentaine de collectivités territoriales en commençant par les plus vulnérables et en impliquant les organisations et les autorités locales.


Ce que nous avons,ce que nous recherchons

Toute la structure physique existe déjà pour l'installation de la 1ere UTB en Haiti. .Le coût total du projet est de $400.000; cependant, les membres fondateurs ont déjà contribué  à hauteur de $200.000; il ne manque que la structure technique  dont le coût des Equipements est évalué  à  $200.000.

Votre contribution peut être en espèce ou en machinerie &  Equipements. N'hesitez pas à contacter notre fabricant et specialiste à l'adresse suivante:.:

.Amir Salama Eng, M.Sc,ABT Ph.D
Ozomax inc                                                                                                                            600 Robitaille -QC-Shefford                                                                                                 Canada  J2M 1X2                                                                                                                    Tel: 450-378-6825                                                                                  Website: http://www.ozomax.com                                                                                          E-mail: engineering@ozomax.com                                                                http://www.ozomax.com/Municipal-water-treatment/municipal-water-treatment.htm

Au cas ou l'on n'atteindrait pas le montant de $200.000, nous serions prêts  à solliciter un financement .auprès d' une institution de micro finance ou bancaire. Cependant, si le montant visé est supérieur, la différence sera orientée vers la mise en oeuvre de la 2eme Unité de traitement bactériologique (UTB)  à Petite Rivière de l'Artibonite, zone vulnérable qui a vu naître le virus du cholera et ainsi de suite.

A tous ceux qui nous auront fait confiance et aidés à  l’Installation de la 1ere UTB en Haiti, nous  leur réservons des plaques d'honneur avec mention: {Plaque d'Honneur décernée   à Monsieur X ou Mme X pour sa contribution  à l'installation de la 1ere UTB en Haiti et son implication dans la lutte contre le fléau du cholera. Les philanthropes, les entrepreneurs sociaux, qui auront contribue de façon substantielle  à la mise en oeuvre de  l'UTB, pourront être les invités d'honneur à l'inauguration de la 1ere UTB en Haiti.


L'IMPACT- 

L'installation de la 1ere Unité de Traitement Bactériologique aura un impact sur le bien être de la population vulnérable et permettra une diminution de 25% du taux de cholera dans l'aire Metropolitaine.

Pour une appréciation de l'envergure et de l'importance de la 1ere UTB en Haiti , nous tenons a préciser: 

-SMG Global Haiti a remporté le Concours du meilleur "Business Plan 2013" organisé par USAID (document disponible) donc le ROI est garanti aussi bien que  l'aspect social car un pourcentage du profit sera utilise pour l'installation de la seconde UTB

-Le Président du Conseil de SMG Global Haiti, de nationalité Suisse, a déjà expérimenté ces nouvelles technologies en Suisse et au Mexique. Il  à son actif une vingtaine             d'années d’expérience dans le domaine de l'eau dont une douzaine dans le traitement bactériologique de l'eau au Mexique, confronté lui aussi à la problématique de l'eau dans les années 2000.

-L'UTB permettra à la population vulnérable d'avoir accès à l'eau traitée au moindre coût, tout en protégeant le marche et sa stabilité. 

Il n'existe en Haiti aucune structure offrant  le service spécifique de traitement des fruits et légumes considérés comme 2 principaux vecteurs du virio cholere après l'eau; ce qui fait de  l'UTB un projet  innovant et rentable.

Une trentaine de  Municipalités en commençant par les plus vulnérables sont visées à  moyen et à long terme par le projet, d'ou son titre: Pilote; cependant, elles dépendent toutes de la 1ere UTB  celle qui va conscientiser les acteurs des secteurs  Eau, Environnement, Santé. SMG compte faire de la première UTB un "Succès 



AIDER DIFFEREMMENT

Les personnes dotées d'une certaine sensibilité sociale qui appuient le projet mais qui sont dans l’incapacité  de contribuer financièrement son invitées  à le promouvoir dans des cercles d'amis .en utilisant les outils de partage Indiegogo.

Merci d'avoir pris connaissance de notre noble projet qui aura un impact à court terme sur 25% de la population vulnérable, pour atteindre à  moyen et long terme  50%, car il est appelé à s’étendre aux collectivités vulnérables. 

Blessings!

Visit the Manufacturer Website to see the Ozone Water Treatment system http://www.ozomax.com/what-is-ozone.html                                         

http://www.ozomax.com/Industrial-products/industrial-products-overview.html

Please direct your questions to: mblherisson@smgglobalhaiti.com and the technical should be addressed to the manufacturer and supplier: engineering@ozomax.com


                                                    

CETTE PÉTITIONEST UN MOYEN D'ACTION, UN LEVIER ET UNE ESPÉRANCE

        PETITION                                       

       

Alain Boinet, Directeur Général et Fondateur deSOLIDARITÉS INTERNATIONAL

Enfin reconnaître l'eau insalubre comme première cause de mortalité dans le monde(1).

3,6 millions de personnes meurent chaque année de causes liées à l'eau insalubre (diarrhée, choléra, typhoïde, hépatite...). Il est urgent de lutter contre ce fléau plus efficacement.

Revoir sérieusement les chiffres de référence cités par les Nations Unies.

Les Nations Unies font indéniablement progresser l'accès à l'eau dans le monde. Mais leur évaluation selon laquelle 783 millions d'êtres humains n'auraient pas accès à l'eau potable n'est pas juste. Selon des études sérieuses, ils sont en fait près de 3,5 milliards à boire chaque jour de l'eau dangereuse ou de qualité douteuse. L'ONU doit revoir ses modes de calcul et sa communication à ce sujet.

Faire de l'accès à l'eau, à l'hygiène et à l'assainissement une priorité à part entière des Objectifs de Développement du Millénaire (OMD) des Nations Unies pour la période 2015-2030.

Ils ne constituent aujourd'hui qu'une cible secondaire (cible C) de l'objectif 7 dédié à l'environnement, alors qu'il s'agit d'une question de vie ou de mort pour des millions d'êtres humains. C'est donc une priorité majeure qui doit à l'avenir constituer un objectif à part entière.

Augmenter significativement les fonds de l'Aide Publique au Développement (APD) affectés à l'accès à l'eau potable, à l'assainissement et à l'hygiène.

Ces fonds doivent plus que doubler. L'effort de la communauté internationale a été de 7,4 milliards de dollars en 2008, dont 3,5 en prêts et 3,9 en dons, là où il en faudrait au moins 18 selon l'Organisation Mondiale de la Santé (OMS). 5ème contributeur dans le monde, la France a fortement augmenté sa contribution ces dernières années, avec un montant de 600 millions d'euros. Mais 95 % de ce budget est affecté sous forme de prêts à des pays émergents solvables. Nous proposons de consacrer au moins 15 % de ces 600 millions d'euros à des dons pour des situations d'urgence humanitaire pour sauver des vies.

Accroître les fonds dédiés aux crises humanitaires

Apporter rapidement l'eau potable et l'assainissement aux populations menacées par les maladies liées à l'eau (diarrhée, choléra, typhoïde...) est une priorité absolue en cas de conflit, de catastrophe naturelle et de déplacement de populations.

Coordonner effectivement les institutions responsables pour organiser efficacement la transition des phases d'urgence vers les phases de reconstruction puis de développement.

Dans les situations de crise, nous pouvons témoigner que le lien entre les phases d'urgence, de reconstruction et de développement fait défaut parmi les institutions financières responsables qui doivent se coordonner pour mieux secourir les populations en danger avec leurs partenaires (ONG, agences…).

Créer un mécanisme international d'information fiable et à jour.

Cet outil devrait indiquer l'état et la répartition des besoins, les engagements internationaux pris et les actions réalisées, et présenter le suivi des objectifs à atteindre dans un rapport public régulier sur internet.

Faire que le droit humain à l'eau potable voté par les Nations Unies devienne une réalité.

Les propositions de notre pétition ont pour objectif d'accélérer la réalisation effective du droit humain à l'eau voté par les Nations Unies le 28 juillet 2010.

(1) Les maladies cardio-vasculaires, qui provoquent plus de victimes, sont liées à l'âge. Les maladies hydriques affectent une majorité d'enfants de par le monde               

2013 ANNÉE INTERNATIONALE DE LA COOPÉRATION DANS LE DOMAINE DE L'EAU

2005 SOLIDARITÉS INTERNATIONAL
décide de porter son
combat contre la 1° cause
de mortalité au monde
auprès des institutions
internationales et du
grand public.

2008 SOLIDARITÉS INTERNATIONAL
remet sa pétition lancée
en 2007 et signée par
50 000 personnes, à
Bernard Kouchner, ministre
des Affaires étrangères
européennes.

2010 Les
Nations
Unies
reconnaissent
l'accès à l'eau potable
et à l'assainissement
comme un droit de
l'Homme.

2012 SOLIDARITÉS
INTERNATIONAL
remet sa pétition au
ministre de la Coopération
Henri de Raincourt, en ouverture
du Forum Mondial de l'Eau en
mars 2012, devant 142 délégations
ministérielles du monde entier.
103 888 personnes sont
engagées à nos
côtés.

2013-2015  Parce que les objectifs du développement du millénaire (OMD) relatifs à l'eau sont bien loin.
