story:
Kwel hoy': We Draw the Line

The burial grounds and treaty rights of the Lummi Nation are threatened by a proposal to build North America's largest coal terminal on their sacred landscape at Cherry Point (Xwe’chi’eXen.) If built, coal would be dumped on a historic burial site and would pollute the nearby fishing grounds. The Lummi community needs your help to stop this!

Cherry Point is a high bluff above the Salish Sea overlooking the San Juan Islands of Washington State. The waters below are home to one of the best crab fisheries along the coast and provide food for salmon and Orca whales. This fishery sustains many tribal families but those jobs would be lost if up to 55-million tons of coal is shipped over the waters.

And so the Lummi Nation has said 'no' to big coal. Lummi Councilman Jay Julius, in opposing the proposed coal port, has said Kwel hoy’: “We draw the line.” The sacred must be protected. Treaty rights must be honored. Kwel hoy’.

A Totem Pole Journey

Help the Lummi Nation stop coal export by supporting this campaign!

The 'House of Tears' carvers of the Lummi community have created a tradition of carving and delivering totem poles to areas struck by disaster or otherwise in need of hope and healing. Now it is Lummi Nation’s own sacred landscape, Xwe’chi’eXen, that needs hope, healing and protection. The Lummi Nation’s Master Carver, Jewell Praying Wolf James, will carve a Totem Pole of spiritual healing. 

The Totem Pole and witnesses will travel 1,200 miles from September 15-29, from the coal mines in Montana to the proposed coal terminal on the coast in Washington, connecting communities and asking for blessings along the way. Journalists, photographers and a documentary film crew will be invited along for the journey. 

The Journey will conclude in British Columbia, where the totem pole will be placed in the homeland of the Tsleil-Waututh Nation, demonstrating unity with the Canadian First Nations’ position opposing the transport of Tar Sands by pipelines across their territories. There, Tribes and First Nations that have travelled from all directions will meet the totem pole. It will be placed as a means of reinforcing the message: Kwel hoy.’ “We Draw the Line.”

We Need Your Help

You can help the Lummi Nation stop coal export by supporting this campaign! We are looking for $35,000 from this IndieGoGO effort, although full Journey expenses are roughly $190,000 with much of that being in-kind contributions. All funds raised here will go directly to Journey expenses and to carving and transporting the Totem Pole. 

In addition, we need to spread the word far and wide about this important and timely story of the Lummi Nation. Please make some noise! Take a moment and use the IndieGoGo share tools to promote our link on social media, and ask your friends, neighbors and colleagues to join you in support of the Lummi Nation’s opposition to Big Coal!

Together, we can help the Lummi Nation say, Kwel hoy’: “We Draw the Line!”

Join us along the Journey

Please join us at one of the powerful events along the way:

  • Northern Cheyenne: September 18, 10:00 a.m. 
  • Missoula: September 19, 4:00 p.m. Missoula County Courthouse, 200 W. Broadway, Missoula.
  • Spokane: September 20, 9:00 - 11:00 a.m. Tribal. The event is open to the public from 11:00 - 12:00. Havermale Point, east end of Riverfront Park, Spokane.
  • Celilo Village: September 21. Tribal, closed to the public.
  • Yakama Nation: September 22. Tribal, closed to the public.
  • Portland: September 23. 5:00 p.m. Cathedral Park in Portland. N. Edison St & Pittsburg Ave in N. Portland.
  • Olympia: September 24. Noon to 1:00. Tivoli Fountain, northeast of the Legislative Bldg, alongside Capital Way on the west campus.
  • Tacoma: September 25. 11:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. St. Leo Catholic Church, 710 South 13th St, Tacoma.
  • Seattle: September 26. Time and location in progress.
  • Xwe'chi'eXen/Cherry Point: September 27. 5:00 p.m.

The Full Story

Xwe’chi’eXen (Cherry Point) is a sacred landscape in NW Washington that has deep spiritual and cultural significance to the people of the Lummi Nation. Overlooking the world-famous San Juan Islands, it includes ancient reef-net sites and a 3,500 year-old village site. The Hereditary Chief of the Lummi Nation, tsilixw (Bill James), describes it as the “home of the Ancient Ones.” It was the first site in Washington State to be listed on the Washington Heritage Register and is eligible for the National Register of Historic Places.

Coal interests plan to construct North America's largest coal export terminal on this site, above the "home of the Ancient Ones." This proposal would haul 55-million tons of coal, from the Powder River Basin of Wyoming and Montana, to this bluff overlooking the San Juans. These long, heavy rail cars would travel through Montana, Idaho, eastern Washington, up the Columbia River gorge and through Tacoma and Seattle to the NW Washington coast. Once there, coal would be loaded onto some of the largest bulk carriers in the world to ship the coal up the coast of British Columbia and Alaska, to China.

Construction of this massive coal terminal will result in significant, unavoidable, and unacceptable interference with Lummi Nation burial grounds and treaty rights, and irreversible and irretrievable damage to their traditional fishing waters and spiritual values.

Lummi Councilman Jay Julius, in opposing the proposed coal port, has said Kwel hoy’: “We draw the line.” The sacred must be protected. Treaty rights must be honored. Kwel hoy’.

Please visit www.totempolejourney.com for more information.

story:
My wife Beth and I moved back to the country this year with the hopes of building a family and a new life.  Our passion for clean healthy food, the environment, sustainable agriculture and making the world a better place led us to our current project.  12 chickens and a scratch built coop has brought us to this, phase two!


The Problems We Want to Solve

  • Properties that are overgrown with invasive plant species, congestion of streams and ponds.
  • Too few family farms
  • Food supply is tainted with pesticides, antibiotics and more.



Why You Should Care

  • Family farms are better for our economy and our environment
  • Property values and usefulness
  • A clean food supply is vital for our health

Who We Are

  • Brian Gansereit - Christian, Husband, Veteran, Farmer, Nutrition Consultant and Small Businessman
  • Beth Gansereit - Christian, Wife, Personal Trainer
  • We care about God, sustainable agriculture, clean food, liberty, the environment, happy animals and building a bright future for this great nation.


Our Soultion

Our business model will use goats to manage invasive plants, build a strong family farm and provide clean, lean healthy meat for our family and neighbors.  But this is more than a business model, once we are off the ground and profitable we can use these sustainable agriculture principles in areas of the world that struggle with daily sustanance and survival.  This will be our ministry.

Short Summary

Hi my name is Brian Gansereit of Gansereit Farms Goat Grazing.  After much thought and prayer I decided to launch this campaign to raise the funds we need to get 
Gansereit Farms Goat Grazing off the ground.  Quite simply what we do is show up with our goats, dogs and electric fence and clear peoples property of invasive plants.  Here is a bit more about us...

It is my firm belief that through the use of intensive rotational grazing and sustainable agriculture principles that goats are the perfect answer for managing invasive plants like kudzu, thistle, poison ivy, poison oak, etc.  After a year of exhaustive research we have seen a model that works both on the west and east coasts, which use modern portable electric fences, goats, guardian dogs, herding dogs and hard work.  We want to bring this environmentally friendly business model to Missouri and the Midwest.  

With your help we can demonstrate that man can orchestrate nature to solve natures problems, that natural problems don't require poisons and heavy equipment.  We believe that God already gave us the tools, we just have to pay attention and apply them correctly.  Please join us today to bring this project to life.

What We Need & What You Get

Here is what we need specifically and I hope you note we are not being extravagant.  This is a thrifty organization that will value your help.  Our fencing and related equipment will cost us $1346.  Our transportation cost will involve a used truck for $5000 and a used livestock trailer for $2000.  The Anatolian Shepherd guardian dogs will cost about $300.  Our actual goats, those lovely eating machines will cost $5000 for 50 Boer Goats.  Any surplus funds will be used to buy more goats.  If you do the math we have thrown in another $1000 for unforseen costs, but please know we are frugal with every cent you donate.

You can see our perks for donating at the right side of your screen.




If we do not reach our entire goal the funds will be applied to the aforementioned costs for equipment and livestock, we might just have to start on a smaller scale.

The Impact

While this text can not explain the passion we have for animals, small business, and sustainable agriculture please know that any donation you make funds an example of a better way of life.  We don't just use these animals, we respect their need to be goats.  To quote a man I highly respect we want them to express the "goatness of being a goat".  Your donations will also fund a project that desires to demonstrate that hard work and ingenuity still have a place in our world.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can not make a donation today thank you for your time and please spread the word on all your favorite social media sites.

You can see our perks for donating at the right side of your screen.






If we do not reach our entire goal the funds will be applied to the aforementioned costs for equipment and livestock, we might just have to start on a smaller scale.


The Impact
While this text can not explain the passion we have for animals, small business, and sustainable agriculture please know that any donation you make funds an example of a better way of life.  We don't just use these animals, we respect their need to be goats.  To quote a man I highly respect we want them to express the "goatness of being a goat".  Your donations will also fund a project that desires to demonstrate that hard work and ingenuity still have a place in our world.


Other Ways You Can Help
If you can not make a donation today thank you for your time and please spread the word on all your favorite social media sites.

story:
Summary


Updated on 29-11-2013 : The definitive legs of the stellarator have been designed, fabricated, assembled and validated. The central ring to accurately locate the 3D printed pieces has also been installed. Five new photos have been added to the Gallery !!. 

Next week a second 3D printed piece will be ordered!. 1/3 of the stellarator will be almost finished!!.

___________________________________ 

Updated on 22-11-2013 : One of the six marvellous 3D-PRINTED pieces has been received and initially assembled to other pieces received. Amazing photos and videos have been added to the Gallery !!. Soon more photos and videos!.

I would like to thank from the bottom of my heart to all the contributors, to all the people who is helping in spreading the word and with information and contacts.

___________________________________ 

I am the only person in the world who alone designed and built a stellarator (an amazing device to produce energy). See UST_1 stellarator in www.fusionvic.org. It was built in a garage using mostly second hand pieces from ebay, much work and some pocket money. Radical innovation was concocted to reduce 10 fold the usual cost.

I am a senior MS Engineer professionally working (now on leave of absence, no salary) in a public fusion energy research centre (CIEMAT) as fusion engineer. 

The stellarator type fusion devices need a complex twisted toroidal (Doughnut) shape surrounded by convoluted coils. Energy will be produced inside the device similarly to our beloved Sun produces the energy.  

   Photo, real stellarator device.                      Figure. Being built with your help !!!


Updated on 22-11-2013 : The amazing gorgeous 3D printed sector of UST_2 just received and preliminarily assembled, ... and me !!. 



Updated on 29-11-2013 : Construction status of the stellarator. The central positioning ring and legs have just been installed. Accurate positioning has been obtained.



Figure 1


Aimed UST_2 stellarator


In the current UST_2 project a combination of three concepts will be applied to much reduce the cost: 3D printing, light enveloped truss structure, and moulding plaster into the envelope for strength. And much work!. The objective is to reduce the cost of fusion machines to produce cheap and clean energy !!. 

Simultaneously, 3D printing methods will be boosted and an appealing 3D-printed complex and accurate structure will be produced. Join the 3D printing revolution!!.

I need your help to buy the 3D printed pieces and other components.

                      

Cheap and clean energy for the world is an invaluable cause!. We are a lot of humans and growing, each one spends or wants to spend increasingly more energy, coal burning is growing in spite of the exponential development of renewable energies. Our environment cannot and will not allow it. Your contribution is important!.

 

What We Need

Very innovative fusion energy developments are uncommonly privately or publicly funded nowadays. That’s why I need your help.  

Donations will pay for:

- The 84 coil grooves distributed in six identical 3D-printed pieces, see Figure 1 above, 14 coils per piece. Six flat coils. 

- Other components: Vacuum fittings, dental plaster, copper sheet and tin solder for the vacuum vessel, bolts, the base and legs of the device, etc.

I spent only ~4000€ in all UST_1 facility, and ~3000 hours of work!. Again, I will work hard to build the device 10 times cheaper than usual !!!.

  

What You Get

We offer UNIQUE perks!. 

Such exclusive rewards are a remind, but not only a remind. Much of them are a limited edition. Such items will be wished afterwards if the campaign is successful !. It is the only opportunity to get them!

And the pleasure of being a contributor of this truly invaluable cause!.


If the full goal is not reached:

- The reward pieces still will be 3D printed and sent to the contributors. Also acknowledgement in web, and live connection will take place.

- I will send 3 hi-resolution images of the part produced, not the full stellarator.

- Acknowledgement in journal publication hardly would occur.

- If enough contributors, I will produce 1/6 or 1/3 of the torus (The torus is composed of 6 equal parts). 


If the full goal is surpassed:

Then 1/3 of the funds surpassing the goal would be donated to other innovative projects aimed to the early availability of fusion energy or other clean energies, particularly such appearing in Indiegogo.

The remaining funds may allow manufacturing the vacuum vessel with stainless steel in a specialised company (If the goal is not surpassed I will solder copper sheets with Tin in my personal laboratory, much worse than a steel vacuum vessel).


Extra conditions and information on some perks:

* A limited numbered series will be produced, similarly to artistic lithographs.

** Made of white nylon only (without vacuum vessel, copper and plaster). A marvellous replica!. Only the external visible shape is replicated. Some minor details are not replicated.

NOTE! : Free shipping up to 15€ except for '3D printed microStellarator!!' reward. Taxes and customs not included. Shipping cost over 15€  has to be added.


For '3D printed microStellarator !!' reward: A nice bit made of white nylon about 5 cm external diameter, see figure below. It can be easily painted. The thin grooves on the piece will be less detailed than in the figure due to the small size. Shipping cost not included. Previous to shipping, the shipping cost has to be added.


Updated on 22-11-2013 (photo above) : Photo of the first microStellartor 3D printed. This is the marvellous reward that will sent to the contributors of '3D printed microStellarator !!'. See more photos in the Gallery.


 

For '3D printed scaled Coils !!' reward: You receive a 3D printed portion of the UST_2 stellarator you contribute to build. Scaled-down ~0.6. Piece of external envelope around 10x8x8 cm. See photo of the piece below and in the Gallery (some details will fade with respect the photo). It is a stunning twisted shape of three of the complex coils of the fusion device.

For '3D printed Coils !!' reward: You receive a 3D printed portion of the UST_2 stellarator you contribute to build. Scale 1:1, that is, the same size as UST_2 stellarator. Piece of external envelope ~17x14x14 cm. See photo of the piece below and in the Gallery. It is a stunning twisted shape of the complex coils of the device. It will be the same piece shown in my presentations in PPPL (Princeton Plasma Physics Lab., Princeton, NJ, USA), ORNL (Oak Ridge National Lab., Oak Ridge, Tennessee, USA)  and Columbia University, New York, NY, USA.

Photo of the '3D printed Coils !' reward, same as shown in the promotional video. Piece similar to the '3D printed scaled Coils !' reward.


For 'UST_2 scaled !!' reward: You receive an about 1/6 scaled-down 3D printed UST_2 stellarator** you contribute to build. Piece of external envelope roughly 15x15x12 cm made of nylon. A figure of the piece will be shown in brief. It is an amazing convoluted structure that would produce huge amounts of energy if somewhat larger and enhanced. 


Impact

UST_1 stellarator inspired many people. The web site is at top of Google.com search for ‘Stellarator’ word. Such ideas have been utilized in research centres in USA, Costa Rica and Germany, to my knowledge. All the know-how obtained from UST_1 is publically available in www.fusionvic.org/LastResults/LastResults.htm


Similarly to UST_1, from UST_2 project the world will benefit from:
- Clean and cheap energy sooner.
- The stellarator will be successively lent to interested universities or R&D centres for plasma research and fusion engineering research. 
- The information about UST_2 development will be publicly available. 


This is a non-profit project. All the funds received will be dedicated to UST_2 project, and in case, 1/3 of the over-the-goal funds in other non-profit energy projects.  


Other ways You can help, if you cannot contribute financially

You can still help by spreading the word in Facebook, Tweeter and e-mail  !!.

Also sharing my Indiegogo page using the Indiegogo share tools.


Thank you very much!.


Acknowledgement

I would like to thank all the researchers and people which have helped during the development of the project, particularly to Jesús A. Romero, Antonio Lopez-Fraguas, Gerardo Veredas, Víctor Tribaldos, Jose A. Ferreira, Juan A. Jiménez, Cristobal Bellés, Jeffrey Harris, Donald Spong, M.I. Mikhailov...Jürgen Nührenberg 31st Conf. on Plasma Phys., London 2004, ECA Vol. 28G, P-4.166 2004, Harry Mynick, other not listed, and CIEMAT. Without them UST_2 design would have been impossible or much more difficult.

story:
Who I am:

I grew up in and around Yosemite National Park, CA as an active outdoor adventurer and nature-lover.  I currently work in Yosemite Valley, and enjoy educating people about the environment. I am an avid artist (pen, graphite, watercolor media mainly), and an amateur biologist/conversationalist. 

 I have been accepted into an African penguin rehabilitation program in Cape Town, South Africa starting next April.  This non-profit organization gives people like me the opportunity to help birds in need, while also teaching significant leadership roles and conservation methods. These birds are currently on the endangered species list and need as much aid as they can get. After this program I will be going back to school to finish my Bachelor's degree in Science and continue to seek opportunities all over the world for conservation organizations.

Help me get there.

Why I'm Doing This Fundraiser:

The program fee is $1395, which includes housing costs, and donation to the program.  The travel expense is what I'm most concerned with, a roundtrip flight costs about the same, roughly $1400.  I have never traveled out of country before, and this trip will be life changing.  

Let's Make it Happen:

Every donation makes it possible for me to see South Africa and participate in a program that works hard to preserve an endangered species.  Not only will I be using this experience for educational purposes, I will be actively creating new works of art inspired by this change of scenery.  I will use my art and newly acquired knowledge to educate others about the importance of volunteer work and the impact every individual has on the world around them.

story:
Aim:

The aim of this funding project is to provide the 1500 inhabitants of Banana Island with the equipment and necessary education to implement a sustainable lifestyle for the future.

The introduction of a waste management system and a self-maintained permaculture site are two simple ways that will ensure the preservation of the islands environment and provide a sustainable way of life for the Banana Island community.

The Problem:

Over the last 3 years I have spent a substantial amount of time on Banana Island speaking with community leaders about the importance of sustainability and accountability when it comes to waste management. There is a general understanding of the problematic issues and a belief that something needs to change for the benefit of the youth, however there is not yet a solution or system in place that targets these issues. 

Being in a remote part of Indonesia the average wage for a working male is five dollars a day. This sort of income dampens innovation and the progression of the overall island society. When your main priority is to feed your family on a day to day basis, the act of throwing your garbage on the beach to be washed away with the tide is an easy solution. This needs to change!

https://mapsengine.google.com/map/edit?mid=zQcj...

ROLE schooling and its place in creating a sustainable Banana Island:

Bobby is a 17 year old local who we are excited to be sending to Bali to be trained as an environmental warrior.
He will be attending the ROLE school for 9 months where he will be equipped with the knowledge and tools he will need to train others in his community in permaculture farming practices, sustainable tourism and most importantly setting up recycling and waste management programs on Banana Island and the surrounding coastal communities in Southern Sumatra. This is one small step in the right direction
http://www.rolefoundation.org/

Where will the funds be used?

  • Bobby's training in Bali in additional transport and living costs during this time.
  • The purchase of organic and non organic bins which will be provided to the inhabitants of the island, for daily collection
  • The purchase of pull carts for waste collection
  • The purchase of a small parcel of land and construction of a recycling center and permaculture site. 

If we do not reach our funding target the money that we do raise will be used to send Bobby to School and create as much headway as possible towards our goal of a clean green Banana Island.

Bobby's role in the community:

Krui is the closest major town to Banana Island, it has a fledgling surf tourism industry and beaches that are covered with plastic.

Bobby is in the perfect position to interact with local fisherman who are major contributors to the degradation of the marine environment, often seen throwing oil bottles, cigarettes and other waste into the ocean. He is well known in the community as he works after school hours carrying fish-rice and other sundries on and off various boats in the Krui Harbor.

Coming from a family of four Bobby has one younger brother and two younger sisters. Kids are schooled on the island until age 15 and sent to Krui until the age of 17 if they are lucky enough to afford further education. Working with the schools, Bobby will begin  the implementation and delivery of environmental education programs for the children in the area.


The BIGGER picture:

Southern Sumatra and Lampung province both contain one of the last remaining strips of untouched Sumatran rainforest
Bukit Barisan Selatan National Park  has a total area of 3,568 km², and spans three provinces: Lampung, Bengkulu, and South Sumatra. Together with Gunung Leuser and Kerinci Seblat national parks it forms a World Heritage Site, Tropical Rainforest Heritage of Sumatra. The park has recently lost 20% of its forests to illegal agriculture, according to the WWF, who found more than 450 km² of park land is being used for growing coffee.

The sooner people can be educated about the importance of these sights and the value of Eco tourism, the more likely it is that the forest will remain intact and not be lost to illegal logging and unsustainable farming. 

http://indahnesia.com/indonesia/PARBUK/bukit_barisan_selatan.php

Indonesia is a paradise wrapped in plastic. With education this can change.

It seems inevitable that this area will swell with surf, nature and adventure travelers seeking an Indonesian experience outside of Bali. It is our long term ambition to implement a system that benefits the community and the environment; a clean and green campaign focusing on education and creating lasting change for generations to come. 

EVERY LITTLE BIT HELPS:

If you do not feel you can contribute financially help us by sharing this campaign with your friends, family, work buddies and push a link out through your social media networks PLEASE.

story:
Synopsis: The Algonquin Wildlife Research Station (AWRS) has been at the forefront of ecological research for 70 years (1944-2014), training students and providing evidence-based science for policy makers. Called a "priceless asset to field biology", the AWRS has made invaluable contributions to our understanding of plants and wildlife in natural and human-impacted systems.  Aging infrastructure and funding shortfalls threaten to close the Station and halt biological study by international research teams. We are asking for your support to help the not-for-profit AWRS reach financial sustainability - for students, public education, and future generations.

Please continue to read on below for the full story.

Welcome to the Algonquin Wildlife Research Station (AWRS)! It is here on the shores of Lake Sasajewun (native Algonquin tongue for little rapids)  where students and researchers have come to study the natural world, all creatures great and small, since 1944.

Nestled in the heart of Canada's famed Algonquin Park, the AWRS has been home to some of the world's most celebrated naturalists (e.g., Bruce Falls), accomplished researchers in biology and ecology (e.g., Robert MacArthur), and renowned artists (e.g., Robert Bateman). Tucked discretely between the towering pine trees are modest red and white cabins and lab spaces. They may not look like much, but they are called home by eager young minds.  

The gong has sounded as a reminder of meal time and at the rustic Cookhouse researchers are abuzz with their most recent wildlife observations and findings. How are pollinating insect communities faring in light of pesticide use? Are logging practices sustainable for forest birds, amphibians, and black bears? What can small mammal populations tell use about forest and ecosystem health? Are Algonquin wolves unique? Is fire a help or a hindrance to breeding bird communities? What does climate change mean for the seldom seen Spotted Salamander? How long do turtles live and what does this mean for the 7 of 8 Species At Risk turtles in Ontario? Here at the AWRS we are striving to learn more about the Science Behind Algonquin's Animals!



The AWRS had been renowned worldwide as one of the world's largest and most accomplished outdoor laboratories, affording the unique ability to study plants, animals, and the whole ecosystems in which they interact. With over 1000 peer-reviewed publications, hundreds of Master's theses, Doctoral theses, and Technical Reports, the AWRS has made invaluable contributions to our understanding of plants and wildlife in natural and human-impacted systems. International teams from across Canada, Germany, the United Kingdom, and the United States have visited the AWRS to pursue research opportunities (and we are always looking for more partnerships!). At any given time the AWRS may host students working on a summer research positions,  graduate students undertaking thesis studies, and college and university students taking accredited field courses. 



The AWRS has assembled some of the most impressive long-term research datasets, critical to monitoring long-term changes from anthropogenic effects, like climate change, on small mammals (60+ years of study), turtles (40+ years of study), birds (50+ years of study), salamanders (10+ years of study), frogs and insects in Canada (with far reaching implications worldwide) and has done so on a very modest budget. Now our Station needs your help!


The Plight of Biological Field Research Stations In Canada

In recent years, biological field research stations in Canada have fallen on hard times (see articles in Canadian Geographic, and other media sources). Government support for environmental research has dwindled and so too has informed science-based policy and decision-making.

At the AWRS we think it is critically important that the public be engaged and understand the importance of ecological research. Among research stations, the AWRS has been innovative in running an annual Meet the Researcher Day and Meet the Researcher Weekend public education and outreach events to raise awareness of the importance of environmental research. The events have been an incredible success with over 600 attendees annually! We are now looking to reach a much larger audience through continued research at the AWRS!


What We Need

Owing to its age (70 years!), the AWRS has a rich history. Also as a result of age, the AWRS has rotting floorboards, leaky roofs (and a leaky dish sanitizer!), a testy stovetop, drafty windows, slumping staircases, and a shortage of outhouses. The basic infrastructure of the AWRS is aging - lab spaces, cabins, teaching portable - and in need of critical repair. The little field equipment that the AWRS has on reserve for students and researchers, namely our small fleet of canoes critical for  access to remote research sites within Algonquin Park, is in desperate need of rejuvenation.


How You Can Help

The AWRS is seeking donations and in-kind support to allow for infrastructure improvements (labs, cabins, cookhouse, et cetera) that will ultimately continue to support research and facilitate student learning. By donating to the AWRS, you will be directly contributing to the research and conservation efforts of AWRS researchers. We greatly appreciate your support and ensure that 100% of your donation will be put towards wildlife research in Algonquin Park. The AWRS is a registered not-for-profit organization in Canada.


We appreciate and thank you for your contribution!


Where is your money going?

It is estimated that the AWRS will require $70,000 (CDN) to complete infrastructure improvements. Through this campaign we are looking to raise as much funding as possible (minimum $5,000) to support these improvements. Your donation will help making the following possible:

  • The continued study and protection of wildlife and wild spaces
  • Improve the learning experience and training of college and university-level students studying in the fields of biology, conservation, ecology, and environmental science
  • Inform natural resource policy and decision-makers with science-based evidence
  • Public outreach and education on wildlife and biological research in Algonquin Park and well beyond its borders
  • Even if the AWRS does not meet its funding goal, all money raised will go directly into repair and maintenance of this world-class biological research facility!

The Impact

Your financial or in-kind contribution will make a difference in the following ways:

  • The AWRS will continue to lead Canada and the international community in our understanding of the natural world!
  • The AWRS will continue to train generations of young biologists and foreword thinkers in the environmental sciences!
  • As it has done for the past 70 years, research conducted at the AWRS has informed policy on wildlife and natural resource management in Ontario, Canada, and around the world! 
  • Public education reaching the over 1 million Algonquin Park visitors every year!


    Other Ways You Can Help

    You can support the Algonquin Wildlife Research Station in many ways:

    • We kindly ask that you share the Save the Algonquin Wildlife Research Station campaign with your family, friends, and on your social media outlets
    • Consider offering your in-kind support by donating canoes, paddles
    •  Please do not hesitate to contact us at pmoldowan1@laurentian.ca (student campaign lead) or wrs@vianet.ca (AWRS directly) with inquires


    Thank you for your interest and support of the Algonquin Wildlife Research Station and the education of young researchers in biology!


    Take a few minutes to view our partnered educational wildlife videos:

    Snapping Turtles with Dr. Ron Brooks


    A Love of Birds: Doug Tozer's Algonquin Park Bird Research

    Algonquin Park Through the Seasons

    The Natural Brook Trout Lakes of Algonquin Park

    An Algonquin Beaver Pond

    Meet The Researcher Weekend
story_txt:
Synopsis: The Algonquin Wildlife Research Station (AWRS) has been at the forefront of ecological research for 70 years (1944-2014), training students and providing evidence-based science for policy makers. Called a "priceless asset to field biology", the AWRS has made invaluable contributions to our understanding of plants and wildlife in natural and human-impacted systems.  Aging infrastructure and funding shortfalls threaten to close the Station and halt biological study by international research teams. We are asking for your support to help the not-for-profit AWRS reach financial sustainability - for students, public education, and future generations.
Please continue to read on below for the full story.


Welcome to the Algonquin Wildlife Research Station (AWRS)! It is here on the shores of Lake Sasajewun (native Algonquin tongue for little rapids)  where students and researchers have come to study the natural world, all creatures great and small, since 1944.
Nestled in the heart of Canada's famed Algonquin Park, the AWRS has been home to some of the world's most celebrated naturalists (e.g., Bruce Falls), accomplished researchers in biology and ecology (e.g., Robert MacArthur), and renowned artists (e.g., Robert Bateman). Tucked discretely between the towering pine trees are modest red and white cabins and lab spaces. They may not look like much, but they are called home by eager young minds.  
The gong has sounded as a reminder of meal time and at the rustic Cookhouse researchers are abuzz with their most recent wildlife observations and findings. How are pollinating insect communities faring in light of pesticide use? Are logging practices sustainable for forest birds, amphibians, and black bears? What can small mammal populations tell use about forest and ecosystem health? Are Algonquin wolves unique? Is fire a help or a hindrance to breeding bird communities? What does climate change mean for the seldom seen Spotted Salamander? How long do turtles live and what does this mean for the 7 of 8 Species At Risk turtles in Ontario? Here at the AWRS we are striving to learn more about the Science Behind Algonquin's Animals!






The AWRS had been renowned worldwide as one of the world's largest and most accomplished outdoor laboratories, affording the unique ability to study plants, animals, and the whole ecosystems in which they interact. With over 1000 peer-reviewed publications, hundreds of Master's theses, Doctoral theses, and Technical Reports, the AWRS has made invaluable contributions to our understanding of plants and wildlife in natural and human-impacted systems. International teams from across Canada, Germany, the United Kingdom, and the United States have visited the AWRS to pursue research opportunities (and we are always looking for more partnerships!). At any given time the AWRS may host students working on a summer research positions,  graduate students undertaking thesis studies, and college and university students taking accredited field courses.

Among research stations, the AWRS has been innovative in running an annual Meet the Researcher Day and Meet the Researcher Weekend public education and outreach events to raise awareness of the importance of environmental research. The events have been an incredible success with over 600 attendees annually! We are now looking to reach a much larger audience through continued research at the AWRS!

What We NeedOwing to its age (70 years!), the AWRS has a rich history. Also as a result of age, the AWRS has rotting floorboards, leaky roofs (and a leaky dish sanitizer!), a testy stovetop, drafty windows, slumping staircases, and a shortage of outhouses. The basic infrastructure of the AWRS is aging - lab spaces, cabins, teaching portable - and in need of critical repair. The little field equipment that the AWRS has on reserve for students and researchers, namely our small fleet of canoes critical for  access to remote research sites within Algonquin Park, is in desperate need of rejuvenation.





 

How You Can Help
The AWRS is seeking donations and in-kind support to allow for infrastructure improvements (labs, cabins, cookhouse, et cetera) that will ultimately continue to support research and facilitate student learning. By donating to the AWRS, you will be directly contributing to the research and conservation efforts of AWRS researchers. We greatly appreciate your support and ensure that 100% of your donation will be put towards wildlife research in Algonquin Park. The AWRS is a registered not-for-profit organization in Canada.

We appreciate and thank you for your contribution!

Where is your money going?
It is estimated that the AWRS will require $70,000 (CDN) to complete infrastructure improvements. Through this campaign we are looking to raise as much funding as possible (minimum $5,000) to support these improvements. Your donation will help making the following possible:


The continued study and protection of wildlife and wild spaces

Improve the learning experience and training of college and university-level students studying in the fields of biology, conservation, ecology, and environmental science
Inform natural resource policy and decision-makers with science-based evidence
Public outreach and education on wildlife and biological research in Algonquin Park and well beyond its borders Even if the AWRS does not meet its funding goal, all money raised will go directly into repair and maintenance of this world-class biological research facility! 

  The Impact Your financial or in-kind contribution will make a difference in the following ways:

The AWRS will continue to lead Canada and the international community in our understanding of the natural world!
The AWRS will continue to train generations of young biologists and foreword thinkers in the environmental sciences! As it has done for the past 70 years, research conducted at the AWRS has informed policy on wildlife and natural resource management in Ontario, Canada, and around the world! 
Public education reaching the over 1 million Algonquin Park visitors every year!

story:
ClickClick is a Patented Water & Energy Conservation Solution that is simple and inexpensive to connect to any shower head. Just installing ClickClick reduces all shower heads to 2 GPM, but it also has a SuperSaver mode which will allow the user to reduce water flow down to 1 GPM during times that high flow is not needed - like lathering time. 

Showers consume 20-25% of the average indoor home water usage, so if you cut that by 33% then you cut the overall indoor home water usage by 6-8%!!!!

California is in the midst of the most severe drought in recorded history…if ClickClick was to be installed across the state it could save 1600 gallons per user in a year…or…60 billion gallons of water (15,000 acre feet of water). 

ClickClick brings every household shower into compliance with EPA WaterSense Standards of 2.0 GPM (gallons per minute) flow without changing the shower head. This allows the everyone the freedom to keep their favorite shower head. ClickClick is small with a sleek design that installs within minutes.

WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU GET:

ClickClick is fully patented, has been tested and certified.  US Innovations needs to place a minimum order for our manufacturer to do a production level run.  That means we need to have $50,000.

-  $1 if you just believe in what we are trying to accomplish!

-  For $15 we will send you a ClickClick!

-  For $25 we will send you 2 ClickClick parts for your home!

-  Multiple progressively larger amounts listed for universities, property owners & management companies, hotels, motels, municipalities, etc!!!

Orders will be filled by June 2014.

WE NEED YOU:

We developed this product from a drawing on a napkin and after multiple years we are finally close to the finish line. 

However we need your help to get there!  We need to raise the remaining funds to place an initial order from the manufacturer, so we can have the inventory to meet customer demand. 

You can also help us get our brand out there by sharing your interest in our product with friends & family.  Please email friends, follow us on Twitter https://twitter.com/clickclick2014 and share on Facebook - 

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Click-Click/601647729906883?ref=settings

IMPORTANT STATISTICS:

By installing ClickClick and engaging the SuperSaver mode for 4 minutes out of a 12 minute shower the user will save 33% of water consumed per shower, which is equivalent to approximately 10 Gallons per 12 minute shower. Showers consume 20-25% of the average indoor home water usage, so if you cut that by 33% then you cut the overall indoor home water usage by 6-8%.

In California nearly 30% of total power consumption is for water, so even though most people initially recognize ClickClick as a water conservation tool (which it is), the majority of the cost savings is actually in energy reduction.

Based on DOE and EPA calculators, installing US Innovations ClickClick product could reduce America’s CO2 emissions by 27 Million - 38 Million Tons per year, which is equivalent to taking 5.3 Million - 7.2 Million Passenger Vehicles off the road per year or saving the equivalent of 64 Million - 88 Million Barrels of Oil per year.

THE IMPACT:

By contributing you are making a conscious decision to conserve natural resources, reducing the impact of our society on the environment, cutting your carbon footprint and saving money. 

Too much water is diverted out of our rivers and lakes, which is contributing to the environmental degradation as well as water quality and exacerbating Climate Change!

Users are also removing millions of gallons of waste water that is discharged from treatment planets directly into our rivers, lakes, bays and oceans.

We ALL have a responsibility to be good stewards of this planet!  This is an effortless way to move towards that mindset. 

GET THE WORD OUT:

We can each achieve a positive impact by reducing our individual usage of natural resources, but there are so many applications for this product that would have an even larger scale impact. 

Each of our communities have schools with dorm housing, gyms, community recreation centers, hotels/motels, and property management companies…we ask each of you to motivate the larger water users in your community to adopt ClickClick as a way to combat drought and climate change. 

With the public support we can have an enormous collective impact.

story:
Here's the Plan:

I aim to take a naturalist and literary approach to documenting the enormous and fragile environment that is the world’s ocean. Throughout a six-month voyage aboard a small sailboat, I will capture the animals and habitats, as well as people and communities, that call the ocean wilderness home. The resulting images and reflections will be released as an e-book and a limited run hardcover. The book is part of an effort to provide a tangible narrative of marine life and culture for a broad public audience. 

My book will feature photographs, accompanied by short essays, that attempt to bring you along on a sail-powered journey from French Polynesia to New Zealand. Or at least bring back what feels important, and maybe provide some permanence to it.

Changing ocean temperatures, rising sea levels and accumulating trash are compromising not just the south Pacific but open water and coastlines everywhere. Still, for most of the public it's barely on the radar. I hope this book can help people that can’t explore the ocean develop an appreciation and sense of stewardship for it. 

The goal of this project is to make marine environments a little more real, to tell a story about the people and animals that have called them home for millenia. 

The beauty of supporting this project is that the cost of the trip is already covered. The boat is ready. The project will provide only as many books or prints as supporters order, so the funding threshold is low.  

What your support will be used for:

The main expense of the project is the printing and shipping costs of the hardcover editions, prints and postcards. When you buy a perk you are advance ordering your hardcover copy, digital edition or print. A note on the perk decriptions: 'Tradewinds' is a working title for the book that I used in the descriptions.

How your funds will not be used:

The cost of the voyage itself will be completely self-funded. Your support will not be used to feed the crew, pay for moorage or fuel costs, immigration fees or flights. The trip is a unique opportunity for this project to happen, the perfect vehicle really, but will be made whether the project is funded or not.

About the Author:

Tyler Hoecker is a graduate of Willamette University in Salem, Oregon as well as an alumnus of the Sea Education Association. After earning his bachelors in Environmental Science he worked for the U.S. Forest Service and a private consulting firm monitoring habitat of endangered salmon and trout in the Pacific Northwest. He has published articles and photographs in Dirt Rag magazine and online for TrailGroove and Backpacking Light.

story:
The little actions that changed the world

Hi! My name is Federico García. I´m 24 years old and I'm from Montevideo, Uruguay. Montevideo is a capital city and, for this reason, produce a lot of trash per day. The people ignore it, but not all. Me and a group of six persons, all Fridays, go around Montevideo, principally in the "Centro" zone, the most populated area. In a white van, we try to collect trash that we can recycle. Why? Because if we don´t recycle a part of this trash, it goes to a dump that produce pollution and the contamination of the zone. This is a terrible future for our sons, and their sons. In fact we help the environment and help our self. 

  Felipe Cardoso Dump, with more than 3.000.000MT of trash

   

We collect Cardboard, bulbs, plastic, glass and a lot of things. A really famous company in Montevideo buys this and make crafts, but now this company is in bankruptcy and we try to make these products. These are the little actions that changed the world and for this we are very happy!


We need this, you need this

We want to continue recycling and making the world a better place to live. For this, we need $700, or more. Why? We need equipment like bags, shovels, brooms and others. As well we need money to pay the transportation, because before we pay this with money that we earn selling the cardboard and plastic, but now we don´t have this money. Also we need money to buy materials like paint, brushes, pens and other artistic tools. Finally we want to rent a garage for all the trash, because actually is in the house of Emilia, one of the most important person in the team. It cost $150 per month. When we buy all of these things, we can sell our products in the different markets in Montevideo and earn money with this to continue our job. 

To achieve this goal, you have to help us! 

If you collaborate with one dollar ($1), Thanks! You help to make our job all Fridays and the team loves you! You make the world a better place!

If you collaborate with five dollars ($5), you are going to receive a Special Thanks with your name in our page of Facebook and Twitter. You are going to be famous for save the planet!


If you collaborate with ten dollars ($10), you are going to receive a Beautiful Purse, made with recycle leather. This is a great step to help us, to help our community!

If you collaborate with thirteen dollars ($13), you are going to receive a Great Gold photo-frame, made with recycle Cardboard. You will love it and we too!

If you collaborate with fifteen dollars ($15), you are going to receive a Premium , Cup of the team, made with recycle ceramic. In the breakfast you remember that you help the environment!

If you collaborate with fifteen dollars ($15), you are going to receive a Modern photo-frame, with recycle Cardboard and Paper. Your photos are great there, and also the planet is great!

If you collaborate with seventeen dollars ($17), you are going to receive the Originals Eco-Bulbs (3), made with recycle bulbs, wood and candles. If you need peace, you only have to light the candle and remember that this bulbs aren´t in the environment!

If you collaborate with twenty dollars ($20), you are going to receive the T-Shirt of the team, made with recycle cotton. Congratulations! Now you are part of the team! You help all the people in the planet!

Our Team

We are seven persons all Fridays. We are a fantastic team!


The Eco-Products help me, you and all

This project not only help Montevideo, help the world. Not only recycle a lot of trash, help the people to recycle and reduce all the contamination in the world. This is a serious problem, that affects everyone. Now I invite you to help me, but I invite to copy this, to copy the idea about recycling. If everyone in the planet make this, is an excellent solution, try it and help me to continue!

The trouble is in America, in Europe, in Africa, in Asia, in the world. Please share the project with this link igg.me/at/ecotrashproject

 If you save the planet..

 This is our goal! With this money, we are going to continue for one month. In this month we are going to do a lot of products! At the end of the month (November-December) we are going to sell these products in the principal markets of Montevideo. With the money that we are going to collect in the markets we continue recycling!


About products

The shipping is going to be available at the end of November. The price NOT INCLUDE shipping cost.

If you collaborate with thirteen dollars ($13), you are going to receive a Great Gold photo-frame, made with recycle Cardboard. You will love it and we too!


If you collaborate with fifteen dollars ($15), you are going to receive a Premium , Cup of the team, made with recycle ceramic. In the breakfast you remember that you help the environment!


If you collaborate with fifteen dollars ($15), you are going to receive a Modern photo-frame, with recycle Cardboard and Paper. Your photos are great there, and also the planet is great!

If you collaborate with seventeen dollars ($17), you are going to receive the Originals Eco-Bulbs (3), made with recycle bulbs, wood and candles. If you need peace, you only have to light the candle and remember that this bulbs aren´t in the environment!

If you collaborate with twenty dollars ($20), you are going to receive the T-Shirt of the team, made with recycle cotton. Congratulations! Now you are part of the team! You help all the people in the planet!







Our Team
We are seven persons all Fridays. We are a fantastic team!



The Eco-Products help me, you and all
This project not only help Montevideo, help the world. Not only recycle a lot of trash, help the people to recycle and reduce all the contamination in the world. This is a serious problem, that affects everyone. Now I invite you to help me, but I invite to copy this, to copy the idea about recycling. If everyone in the planet make this, is an excellent solution, try it and help me to continue!
The trouble is in America, in Europe, in Africa, in Asia, in the world. Please share the project with this link igg.me/at/ecotrashproject
 If you save the planet..

 This is our goal! With this money, we are going to continue for one month. In this month we are going to do a lot of products! At the end of the month (November-December) we are going to sell these products in the principal markets of Montevideo. With the money that we are going to collect in the markets we continue recycling!

About products
The shipping is going to be available at the end of November. The price NOT INCLUDE shipping cost.

story:
Conservation and Restoration Work in the U.S. DOES Create Jobs!

We're the American Restoration Industry Research Group. We're a seasoned team of natural resource practitioners and academics from around the U.S. that care about the economic benefits of conserving and restoring natural ecosystems, especially when it comes to job creation.

Unfortunately, environmental laws and conservation and restoration efforts are often associated with being bad for business, and bad for jobs. In fact, the American media and many members of the general public often believe that job creation will only occur by allowing more development and environmental impacts. 

We don't believe there needs to be a tradeoff. 

We want to understand the job creation associated with conservation, restoration and mitigation actions linked with industrial development – the activities of this relatively new industry we're calling the “Restoration Industry.” Think large-scale tree plantings and wetland restoration.  

Previous studies in the U.S. have identified ‘green job’ creation through renewable energy, energy efficiency, or recycling investments. However, the economic output of the jobs generated due to the conservation and restoration of natural ecosystems has not been systematically tallied. Attempts to date have been small-scale, focusing on a limited set of programs, specific projects, and individual funding sources. We’re aiming to change this.

We've already raised 75% of the funds we need - and we need your help to get us to 100%!

In order to make our case we need support to conduct research and to communicate our findings to the right people through a national survey and outreach campaign.

Our two main goals are to:

1)    Create national awareness about restoration economy jobs.  We will conduct outreach to our conservation partners, policymakers and others about the jobs (and ultimately the quality of those jobs) associated with conserving and restoring natural ecosystems.

2)    Catalyze more public and private dollars flowing into the sector to realize the significant economic activity, including jobs, associated with the restoration economy. 

Why the Indiegogo Campaign?

With the $35,000 we hope to raise from this campaign we will be able to embark on the Phase II (outreach phase) of this project. We will:

  • Create an interactive website to host all of our research findings, maps, infographics, video testimonials and other resources for policy makers, media, conservation groups and the general public to access information and participate in discussions;
  • Create powerful maps showing major Restoration Industry job locations around the country; and,
  • Perform outreach to key players, including national conservation organizations, to share findings and promote effective dialogue through roundtable discussions to begin changing the debate.

We have given ourselves the goal to have phase I of the project completed by fall 2014. This means that once we get through Phase I we need to move quickly to do outreach to engage key players in the restoration economy discussion.

We’re turning to our strongest supporters to ask for contributions. In exchange, we’re offering a number of perks, including polar bear, ocelot, bald eagle and penguin stuffed animals, wildlife notecards, and a tree planting (everyone who donates will get their name listed on our website). 

Here's a little information about the tree plantings: The Conservation Fund has planted over 1 million trees at Upper Ouachita National Wildlife Refuge in northern Louisiana, where they are helping to restore the natural hydrology and historic floodplain of the Ouachita River. As these new trees grow, they will provide cleaner air, cleaner water and more room for the Louisiana black bear to roam.

Note: please add $20 for orders shipped outside of the U.S.

The good news is we’ve already raised most of the funding we need for Phase I of the project through private foundation grants from the Walton Family Foundation, the blue moon fund, and The Conservation Fund, which is allowing us to:

  • Cover the costs of an initial scoping study to create a working definition of the ‘American Restoration Industry’ and how many jobs are incorporated;
  • Perform a literature review; and,
  • Establish and implement a formal survey methodology to actors in the restoration economy and a write report of our current findings with key case studies.

What’s really cool about Phase I is that it will result in a baseline that can be used in the future to assess the jobs associated with the restoration economy as it continues to evolve (and we believe, grow) over time.

Your contribution will help us continue developing this innovative and groundbreaking methodology, spreading the word, and recognizing the incredible economic impacts of the restoration economy for existing and future jobs, and our planetary health.

If you are involved in the restoration industry, we would also love to hear from you - we are looking for more research on jobs and economic impacts, so please send any information our way!

We’re also seeking “conventional” Foundation funding that will be used to help with the outreach phase of the project. Check back here at Indiegogo for updates on our progress with this!

Thank you so much!

Follow our progress:

We will be sharing updates on the results of our preliminary study, the survey, and out outreach efforts through our Facebook and Twitter pages.

Bios for our campaign team members:

Adam Davis (Research Director)

Adam has twenty-five years experience in applied environmental economics with a focus on practical applications of ecosystem services theory. He combines his personal interest in environmental solutions with expertise in conservation finance, incentive structures and cost-effective compliance.   His particular interest is finding practical ways to get landowners and land managers paid for the conservation and restoration of environmental features on their property. 

Adam is a member of the Advisory Council for the Aldo Leopold Leadership Program that provides training for environmental scientists from across the United States in public speaking and communications.  He works closely with the Woods Center for the Environment at Stanford, andhis work was recently featured in The New Economy of Nature, by Gretchen Daily of the Woods Center and Pulitzer prize winning writer Kathy Ellison.  He received the Ecological Society of America corporate award for “his contribution to the understanding of connections between recycling, resource recovery and ecosystem health.”

Adam has been an active participant in the Conservation Leadership Dialog program organized by the Lincoln Institute for Land Policy, andauthored a chapter in From Walden to Wall Street (Levitt, 2005) that came out of this work.  He also co-authored chapters in The Endangered Species Act at Thirty (Scott, Goble, and Davis, 2006), and People and Land in an Age of Consequences: A Blueprint for Conservation that Works(Knight and White, 2008) both from Island Press.  He gives regular public talks on ecological economics and applied ecosystem service theoryand has guest-lectured at Stanford, Yale, Cornell, UC Berkeley and the Presidio School of Management. 

Dr. Todd K. BenDor (UNC-Chapel Hill Lead Researcher) 

Dr. BenDor is an Associate Professor of City and Regional Planning at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. His research and teaching interests focus on environmental and ecosystem markets, urban growth simulation modeling, and environmental conflict resolution. His recent work has centered on understanding the role of urban and land use planning in emerging ecosystem markets, as well as exploring the social, economic, and ecological impacts of using environmental restoration as offsets to new urban development.

He received a Ph.D. in Regional Planning from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign in 2007, a M.S. in Environmental Science from Washington State University and a B.S. in System Dynamics from the Worcester Polytechnic Institute.

Dr. T. William Lester (Labor Economics Researcher)

 Dr. Lester is an Assistant Professor of City and Regional Planning at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. His research is primarily in economic development, focusing on the development of the ‘green’ economy, and the role of labor market institutions in fostering greater equity at the urban and metropolitan scales. His is an expert on the impact of minimum wage and living wage policies on urban economic development.  

Dr. Lestor employs quantitative and qualitative methods drawn from the fields of labor economics, political science and regional development. While his research on the minimum wage and living wage has garnered national attention recently, he continues to broaden his research agenda within the field of economic development.

Avery Livengood (Graduate Research Assistant)

Avery is a graduate student in the City and Regional Planning program at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill and the Environmental Management program at Duke University. As a graduate research assistant, Avery is contributing to research on stormwater management policy implementation and the economic impacts of the restoration industry.

Prior to graduate school, Avery worked to design economic development and housing solutions for coastal Mississippi, with the Gulf Coast Community Design Studio.  Avery also worked as an independent consultant, providing outreach and planning services in Sacramento, California, the San Francisco Bay Area.  She has contributed to a variety of community-based economic development initiatives including the City of Oakland’s Business Improvement District Program, the Liestal Alley Activation Pilot Project, and the Greater Broadway Partnership of Sacramento.

Avery graduated with high distinction from the University of California, Berkeley in 2007.

Logan Yonavjak (Campaign Manager and Consultant)

Logan been an independent consultant since 2012. She has worked with HIP Investor, Inc., a boutique investment advisory firm based out of San Francisco, to apply their triple bottom line scorecard methodology to corporations, organizations, and investment strategies. Logan also consults with the Conservation Private Capital Group, a team of conservation finance experts working to launch a new U.S. fund for land conservation. Logan is also a freelance writer for Nextbillion.net, Ashoka Changemakers, and Forbes. 

Before consulting, Logan was the Business Development Officer for New Ventures, the center for environmental entrepreneurship at the World Resources Institute, working to assist small and medium enterprises in key emerging markets to compete in a global economy. Logan was also a Research Analyst with WRI’s Southern Forests for the Future project, which seeks to scale up economic incentives -- such as forest carbon offsets -- for private landowners in the southern U.S. to conserve and sustainably manage their forests. 

Logan received her B.A. with Distinction from UNC-Chapel Hill in Geography with a concentration in GIS. She is a 2012 Startingbloc Fellow, a 2012 Property and Environment Research (PERC) Fellow, a 2013 Kinship Fellow, and a Fellow with Tule Partners. She is also a class of 2015 Master of Forestry candidate at Yale.

story:
Our Story - we are GreenXC

We are an organization of young professionals in the fields of public relations, marketing, photography, journalism and business and we are LOVERS OF NATURE, TRAVEL AND ADVENTURE determined to make an impact on the preservation of our National Parks and Forests.


At the end of July, we are setting out on a three-week mission to get cross country using only ride-shares and conduct a national outreach and awareness campaign for parks and forests with the support of USDA National Forest Services. Stopping at various destinations along the way we will be documenting our travels and taking our followers along our journey through our website.


“National Parks are America's Best Idea; GreenXC's cross-country ride-share is a close second. It's a wonderful, simple and exciting idea to help save our National Parks. Can't wait to hear of your travels.”

–Eileen Novak

“It is important to keep forests standing. I hope this will help.”                                                   

-Monica


"You're doing more to help raise awareness with your campaign than us in natural resources management have in a long time. Thank u! You are reaching more people on a 1 to 1 level than most biologists."

–Josh


We noticed that with  all the new technologies and social networking sites like Facebook and Twitter the people of our generation and younger are more glued to their computers and spend a lot more time indoors. This can prove hazardous to the future of National Parks and Forests, several of which are already endangered.

We want to educate them on the beauty that is our National Parks and Forests and take the internet platforms that they frequent and have them come along a journey cross country that we will take via ride-shares. The reason we are selecting ride-share is so that we reduce our own carbon footprint and promote carpooling and sharing rides. As we go to each national park or forest, one of our team members is a professional travel photographer and writer so we will write about the parks and show video footage and imagery to get our readers/viewers excited. With each park we visit, people will be able to donate through out website directly to their national park or forest of choice. 100% of all donations made through our website will go to national parks and forests. 

The whole goal of this project is to 1. Promote Ridesharing/Carpooling to reduce the nation's carbon footprint 2. Promote our National Parks and Forests to the younger generation 3. Raise money to be donated directly to the parks and forests 4. Tell the story of people we meet along the way and raise awareness for Green Businesses.


We will be doing this through our website, http://www.greenxc.com and through our social networks 

Twitter: @GreenXCountry and Facebook


What is Ride Sharing?

 video explanation on youtube

The Impact


GreenXC seeks to address two major problems.


As our nation’s deficit continues to grow, government funding for national parks and forests diminishes. With the increasing environmental risks threatening our parks and forests today, it is even more imperative to strengthen wildlife protection. Without sufficient funding, both parks and forests will be unable to sustain operations.


At the same time, the young generation has little awareness of the treasures contained in the national parks and forests and knows even less about the hardships they are facing. They are the driving force behind future social and political policies of our nation, and without their support, the outlook for protecting nature looks bleak.


To make an impact, we must tap into America’s young generation and work to instill in them the value of this cause.


What We Need & What You Get

We need everyone's help in raising money to get us cross country and make this campaign possible. The money we receive through indiegogo will be going to production and execution of this project (website, hosting, any additional production costs), money for gas for our ride-shares, food and lodging throughout our journey and entrance fee to get into the various parks we visit along the way. Any money left over will be donated directly to the National Forests and Parks.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't help with donations at this moment? There are other ways you can help!


Share a Ride –  help us achieve our goal.


The success of GreenXC and the future of the National Parks and Forests is in your hands. For both to succeed we need you. Help us get to our nations parks and forests and across the country. Join us on our adventure and from our hard work and planning it is sure to be an exceptional time.


Contact us if you could give us a ride along the way. You get to participate in our plans and get featured in our website articles. Have a story to tell? Come share it with us as we drive along. We want to get to know the people of our country and the fascinating personalities.


Spread the Word –  help us reach out to the world.

No money to offer, no car to share, no problem!


You too can still be part of the GreenXC team and create real change. Help us spread the word of the great adventure we are embarking on and the help we are building for the National Parks and Forests.

Do you blog? Give us a shout out.


Are you a redditor ? (one of us is an addict) Please tell your favorite subreddit about us and upboat GreenXC posts.


Twitter got you hooked? Send us some love @greenXcountry.


Of course when procrastinating on Facebook, come over to our page check out the latest and share with your friends and facebook buddies.


And always get in touch with us directly.


Be a Part of Something Great - We Can Come Together and Protect Our Future!

story:
Short Summary

Disasters on the scale of the typhoon in the Philippines require an army of professional volunteers to rebuild infrastructure and services. These volunteers are often just regular men and women with unique skills who take leave from their jobs to serve on short notice, often far from their families and the comforts of home. 

This campaign is an opportunity to serve one such professional. It is an opportunity to serve a servant and his family.

Alan Bowling is a civil engineer, a husband, a father of four, and a personal friend. He wouldn't tell you this, but he's taken a few weeks off with unpaid leave to serve with an organization in the Philippines helping to restore clean water and sanitation. As if that wasn't awesome enough, he's doing this right in the middle of the Christmas season, and all with the full support of his wife Maggie. 

Wow. 

He's doing a really good thing for folks in need, and I'd like to get people in this community on board to help cover some of his income while he's gone. I think it's important we support folks like Alan who have unique skills and willingly sacrifice their time and resources to help those in dire need. This gesture will be a help to both Alan and his incredibly supportive wife and family.

As a Christian, I believe what he's doing demonstrates the hands and feet of Christ. As a citizen, I believe it's our responsibility to serve the servants among us. 

What We Need & What You Get

What do we need? I've set a goal of $1,000 for this campaign, but I'm sure we can beat it! Remember our goal here is simply to help cover some of Alan's income while he's gone. 

What will you get? You will receive the comfort, assurance, and joy of knowing that you have helped "serve a servant". That you have spurred him on to know that in the future, we'll have his back when the opportunity arises to serve again.

The Impact

If this campaign is a success, I'd like to see the same concept extended to other professionals on a broader scale. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't in a position to give monetarily, there are other ways you can help. You can:

Forward this to others to get the word out!

Pray for Alan and his team as they work to restore clean water and sanitation to the people of the Philippines. 

Thank you!!!

story:
Hi Everyone!

This summer I am hoping to travel to Norway through the WWOOF (World Wide Opportunities on Organic Farms) to assist an agricultural, Norwegian couple farm their vegetable garden and also build a segment of their log house. I also will have the opportunity to share my music through small music/arts events that my Norwegian host-family provides at their home throughout the summer.

My goal is to raise the necessary finances to get a round-trip plane ticket and cover the essentials of what I’ll need when I’m there (food, transportation, etc.).

As many of you may know, I love to travel and also love to spread my music. I will have the opportunity to do both AND try something new, which is living and participating in farm work daily for 4 weeks. Each and every contribution helps, and will do SO much for my experience.

 

 

80& of the funding I receive will contribute toward my plane ticket and the remaining 20% will help cover the essential expenses – food, in country transportation, farming gear & clothing, etc.

 

My unique perk for contributors who give $100+ will be an original piano composition I write especially for them! I am looking forward to doing this very much!!

 

If the goal is reached, excellent! If it is exceeded, even more excellent! The surplus will assist me with the other essentials I'll need while in the country. 

 

The impact of this campaign is not only personal but it is also helping the world become more green and inhabitable for our future. Some of the benefits of organic farming are:

Air and climate change. Organic agriculture reduces non-renewable energy use by decreasing agrochemical needs

Sustainability over the long term: Organic agriculture considers the medium- and long-term effect of agricultural interventions on the agro-ecosystem. It aims to produce food while establishing an ecological balance to prevent soil fertility or pest problems

And a quote:

“The impact of organic agriculture on natural resources favors interactions within the agro-ecosystem that are vital for both agricultural production and nature conservation. Ecological services derived include soil forming and conditioning, soil stabilization, waste recycling, carbon sequestration, nutrients cycling, predation, pollination and habitats.”

More information can be found here: http://www.ifoam.org/growing_organic/1_argument...

 

Thank you all already! Please help me get the word out and share this with colleagues, friends, family…who ever!

 

Warmly,

Coleman

 

P.S. - ABove is the picture of the home in Winter time!!

story:
Pollinators in Peril

Pollinator species, (bees, butterflies, hummingbirds, and other native species), need our help. With varroa destructor mites, pesticides, weather extremes, habitat loss, and lack of food to forage on, pollinators are dying off at alarming rates. We've lost 90% of Monarch butterflies since 1996, the Rusty patched bumblebee is listed on the Endangered Species Act, and honeybee populations have declined about 40% each year for the last decade. This is especially concerning, considering that pollinators are responsible for fertilizing 1 in every 3 bites of food that we eat and are vital to both our food system and natural ecosystems. With urbanization and industrial farming, there are less and less flowers- especially native flowers- for pollinators to feed on. When pollinators do find flowers, they are usually ornamentals, which tend not to produce as much pollen and nectar, and they could be contaminated with toxic pesticides. 

You Can Help

Providing more healthy, abundant wildflowers such as cosmos, milkweed, calendula, bachelors buttons, coneflowers, bergamot, phlox, sunflowers, clovers, fleabane, asters, beebalm, and many others, gives pollinators a buffet full of nutrition to boost their immune systems, protect them from pesticides, and gives us a colorful season-long show. Wildflowers are easy to manage, repel pests due to increased biodiversity, and are self-sufficient. They do not require reseeding, fertilizers, herbicides, or supplemental watering. Mowing them down once at the end of the growing season takes care of reseeding and saves on mowing costs for landowners.

The funds raised in this campaign will help provide wildflower seeds, tiller rental (if applicable), organic compost, and the labor necessary to plant the wildflowers, to businesses and organizations that accept the offer and generously give their land to help our pollinator species.

Alternatively, businesses on Main Street, or others without available land, could receive planter boxes with soil and seeds to establish wildflower gardens. Not to worry though, bees are very docile and do not seek to harm you, as they will die if they do. When looking for food, they have nothing to protect and just want to do their job. 

If our goal is not completely met, we will establish as many pollinator gardens/meadows as funds allow.

 

At least one business/organization has already expressed their interest and communication is happening with others to expand the project as far as we can go.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can always help the pollinators and our campaign in ways that aren't through donation. 

You can plant wildflowers in your gardens at home, seed your lawn with clover, leave your dandelions, don't apply pesticides or herbicides to your property, and PLEASE SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN!!!

 

Thank You So Much for your help to save vital species to our livelihoods and ecosystems.

 

 

 

Great resources on Pollinator Conservation and Information-

https://xerces.org/pollinator-conservation/

https://www.fws.gov/midwest/endangered/insects/...

https://www.nrdc.org/save-bees
